item.title: 2026-02-06 - Weekly Scholarship Universe Update - Lindley
item.description: Lindley Davis Fri, Feb 6, 5:34 PM (5 days ago) to Alison, meHello! This week consisted of wrapping up our cycle - lots of checks on scholarships with low/no matches, outreach to targeted populations, first contact with reviewer groups, and setting up the system for over 200 faculty members to start reviewing next week. Our final communication to students about scholarship deadlines went out today. I'll be monitoring the Finaid queue in Slate over the weekend to assist any students applying at the last minute. I'll have updated final application counts next week. I've put a few things in place to make this process easier for the future, including standardizing the committee registration template that goes out to all colleges. I've created a feedback survey for committees, which will be linked in their reviewer portal, along with their PDF guides. We use this information to build next year's applications and tailor the review process. I also wrote a sql query that will save us from having to look up individual Banner IDs in order to add reviewers. We have had good preliminary feedback from committees that we spoke with this week. The College of Business has been resistant to review in the system but the meeting Wendy and I had with Tracy Reed was very productive, and we plan to meet with several of their chairs next week. Ellucian added an enhancement portal, and I've been making good use of it, adding requests for features that will continue to improve our processes. We've begun discussing award methods with Lauren. We intend to start awarding students with renewable scholarships over the next few weeks. Let me know if you have questions or want details on anything we've been working on! Lindley DavisFinancial Aid Business Systems Analyst Office of Student Financial Aid and University Scholarships Appalachian State University 828-262-8687 Phone 828-262-2585 Fax
item.guid: Finacial Aid Tech Notes/2026-02-06 - Weekly Scholarship Universe Update - Lindley.md

item.title: 2026-01-23 - Scholarship Universe Weekly Update
item.description: From: Lindley Davis To: Alison, me Date: Jan 23, 4:58 PMGood Afternoon!This week has been busy.Bailey and I are exporting all rubrics used in Blackbaud so we can establish them in Sandbox. We have a review environment set up in Sandbox and are testing a few review and nomination methods for our committees. Scholarship administrators are receiving training this coming week.Committee spreadsheets went out to each college so we can begin creating the groups in PROD. There are a few key differences in the Blackbaud and SU processes. I'm creating an institutional guide to go with the videos provided by SU. I anticipate sending this guide out to faculty committees late next week. We don't have the bandwidth to host departmental trainings for each committee this year, but we will have multiple ways of providing support throughout the review process!I updated each college on application statuses this week and began sending targeted communications to students in specific departments if they have scholarships with fewer than 5 matches. 4,201 students from CAS and CFAA received these emails today. We get immediate feedback from these emails (See example below). I'll be addressing other colleges over the next few days.I hope you guys have a great weekend and stay safe! Let me know if you need any other info.Best,From: Alison Rabil To: Wendy, Lindley, me Date: Jan 28, 12:07 PMLindley Thank you for the incredible work you're doing getting this up and running. I know it's a lot and I appreciate how detailed you are. Wondering if there is an M: drive folder where the documentation from Ellucian and your training guides etc live? We keep things in many places and I want to be sure, especially when this is wrapped up for this cycle, that the record keeping is in our permanent place of record on M rather than a google drive with selective access.Not something to deal with now, but something I want to be sure we take care of before you head out on maternity leave (have you decided on a name yet??!!!). Thanks again, Lindley. AlisonFrom: Lindley Davis To: Alison, me, Wendy Date: Jan 28, 12:52 PMThank you! That means a lot. It's a lot but I love this kind of work. Never boring!At the moment, most resources I've created are on the Scholarships Office Google Drive so college administrators can access the information they need. I am in the process of creating an institutional user guide that covers the student experience, reviewer role, and awarding steps (16 pages in so far...) I can copy all of these materials over to the M: drive so they are accessible to the rest of the office!The Ellucian materials live in the Customer Center but I have been downloading relevant articles and linking them in the user guide. I can download their full guide and add it to the M: drive for anyone who does not have Customer Center access. All emails from Lauren have been saved and once we get through this cycle, my plan is to go back through those, organize, and add to our internal documentation. Currently, we are jumping from implementation meetings to system setup to administrator training so quickly that there hasn't been downtime to give these the attention they deserve. If you'd like me to prioritize this sooner rather than later, just let me know and I'll make sure it happens.So far the frontrunner is Darcy...the jury is still out on a middle name. Ideas???Would you like me to convert this into a formal PDF or perhaps draft a reply focusing on those middle name suggestions?
item.guid: Finacial Aid Tech Notes/2026-01-23 - Scholarship Universe Weekly Update.md

item.title: 2026-01-26 - How Purdue Automated ELM Private Loan Processes
item.description:
From: Alison Rabil To: Jennifer, me, Jonathan Date: Jan 26, 12:05 PMThis is just an FYI, how Purdue "automated" their process using Banner and ELM with a lot of custom jobs, of course. Something for down the road but thought the documentation and the explanation could be helpful for both our schools down the road at some point. AlisonFrom: carlh@purdue.edu cosuaa-members@listserv.unc.edu
To: Coalition of State University Aid Administrators cosuaa-members@listserv.unc.edu Date: Mon, Jan 26, 2026 at 12:00 PMHi everyone,I reached out to our IT support team and here is what they shared with me regarding our private loan processing with the ELM files. If you have any questions about the below, I can put you in touch with our main IT support person. Thanks!HeidiA while back we posted our code and overview to Banner communities in the Community Code Sharing form. As a Banner school you should have access to it. It’s not a very user-friendly interface, so I’ve posted the high-level description in this email. However, if you want to see the code, you’ll need to get that from the forum. The thread is titled "Private loan process using files from ELM done at Purdue”.Below is a description of our process-to-process private loans and attached are packages, table definitions and general packages used in Purdue written processes. We use UC4 to automate the process. Private loan process using files from ELM: Use UC4 to pull the files from ELM around 7:30am each workday. Some of the files are just reports used by Financial Aid and/or Bursar. The files that we will load to Banner are .SP2, .SUP and .DS2 Certification requests (.SP2 files from ELM) are loaded to a Purdue created table (RZTPRLC) with a few additional fields determined, such as aid year. This step is done in one of our budget jobs as we want these students to be added to the popsel to be assigned a financial aid budget in Banner (since many are non-FAFSA filers). In order to know the Banner fund tied to the lender requested we have created a lender table, RZTPLL. Although most of this data is in Banner there were a few pieces of information that we are expected to check that don’t exist in Banner. Run RZKBDGT - Load requests from ELM to Purdue Created table. Run RBRPBGP - Create budget if student doesn't already have one. Run RZKPRLC – Purdue created process to create the award in Banner on RPRAWRD/RPRATRM. We have many checks in this process, so awards are only created if the student meets certain conditions. Run RPRELAP (Banner process) to create electronic loan application record on RPRLAPP/RPAELAP Run RZKPRLD – Purdue created process as there are a few fields needed on RPRLAPP that aren’t populated when RPRELAP runs Run RZKPLLE - Purdue created process to keep loans from extracting that need a manual review. This process will create a popsel of all the loans we want to be extracted Run RPRELAX (Banner process), using the popsel created from the prior step, to extract the loans (creates ELAPyyIN_####.DAT) Run RPRHDRL (Banner process) to extract loan release file (creates HDRL_####.DAT) Run RPRELCT (Banner process) to extract loan correction file (creates ELCTyyIN.DAT) Run RPRLNAG (Banner process) to create the aging report of non-disbursed loans Run RPRELRU (Banner process) to load the SUP files from ELM Run RPREFTL (Banner process) to load DS2, DSB, RST or EFT files (we normally receive DS2 files from ELM) Send files to ELM using UC4 process: ELAPyyIN, HDRL, ELCTyyIN That’s the end of our automated process. However, there are a couple of manual steps to complete the EFT processing. The Bursar office has to confirm the payment on RPAEPMT and then RPREFTP is manually ran to post the money to the student record. Would you like me to convert any other email chains or summarize the technical steps listed here into an Obsidian task list?
item.guid: Finacial Aid Tech Notes/2026-01-26 - How Purdue Automated ELM Private Loan Processes.md

item.title: 2026-01-30 - Scholarship Universe Weekly Update
item.description: From: Lindley Davis To: Alison, me Date: Jan 30, 2026, 5:36 PMGood Afternoon,Scholarship administrators are officially in the production environment. I held training for all five college scholarship administrators this week. They were introduced to basic system functions and the reviewer portal. We had great all-around feedback!I'm building out our award manual as we continue implementation meetings with Lauren. My plan is to have very thorough documentation available by the time I go on leave.All Blackbaud rubrics have been exported and I've started the process of building them into Scholarship Universe.Reviewer guides and timelines are going out to faculty groups on Monday. I'll be tracking the length of time it takes committees to finish assignments. One of my goals is to reduce the turnaround time between reviews and awards. We're currently using the same timeline as last year while faculty get adjusted to the system and will look at shortening it next year.I've continued sending targeted communication for scholarships with low applicant numbers. We reduced the number of scholarships with <5 applicants by 29% using these messages.We met with Becky, Angie, and Jonathan. I have a few reports to create to help them start the process of adding outside scholarships to the system and I am creating an implementation timeline for us. I'll be shadowing Becky at some point in the next two weeks to make sure I understand what we need to make happen for them.Have a great weekend!Would you like me to format another email chain for you, or perhaps help you set up a template in Obsidian to house these updates?
item.guid: Finacial Aid Tech Notes/2026-01-30 - Scholarship Universe Weekly Update.md

item.title: 2026-01-30 - Process Calendar Meeting - Transcript
item.description: Wendy Ray: Good morning.Wendy Ray: I can't hear you.Sheila Burleson: How about now?Wendy Ray: Can hear you now. How are you?Sheila Burleson: Ugh! I'm lazy sleepy today. I was so comfortable in my bed this morning that I just was like, no, I'm not leaving my bed. Ever. And I was like, you have a child that has to be picked up in 20 minutes, and you must shower. So I did. Yeah, it was definitely one of those days here. Boom.Sheila Burleson: Allison was just sending that Condition 2 is in effect through Saturday. What does that do for your interviews? Are you still doing them?Wendy Ray: I'm hoping that we can still do it. Since it's virtual, I feel like all the faculty are ready and willing. Allison, Bailey and I, Anthony and Sydney, will all be working tomorrow, even though it's a condition 2. It'll be notated somewhere, I guess, that that's happening, but we'll be there, working. We gotta get through this. We can't keep postponing.Kenneth Kirksey: Huh.Sheila Burleson: If you need help, Wendy, let me know, I'm around.Wendy Ray: Okay. I will. I think we're pretty good. We've got, for the most part, Chancellor's is ready to go. They're done. I've got two or three students I'm trying to get interviews scheduled for for Beaver, but other than that, I think we're pretty good to go. But I'll let you know.Alison Rabil: What are you looking at, Kenneth?Kenneth Kirksey: I'm looking at the converting estimated awards to actual. I just need to share the document with y'all.Alison Rabil: Okay. I know we wanted to look at summer at some point, but what was the other thing that we wanted?Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah, you had mentioned you wanted to look at this. Because we were getting ready to send out… I'll pull the... I just put a link to the document in the Zoom chat. When are we planning on regarding the actual award?Alison Rabil: Well, the reason I brought it up was because we have the state aid stuff out. We know that it's gonna stay the same, right? So is that the only thing at this point that is estimated in our packages? The rest of it is…Sheila Burleson: Is Pell solid?Alison Rabil: Yeah, I don't think it's gonna change. And we're not gonna award SEOG to the first-year students until possibly later, because we've got so little of it anyway, I don't think it'll make that much of a difference. But that's not in the packaging rules, so I don't think we have to worry about that piece of it.Sheila Burleson: So, once we get the state, which is our last thing that we usually wait on, is that correct? We should be able to.Alison Rabil: And we have that. It's not gonna change. It's the same…Sheila Burleson: Oh, right, but is that our… is that for our future planning, when the state is concrete, we can go to actual?Angie Daugherty: Usually state and Pell, when we get the notification about that. We award, and it's been early March.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah, I was looking. Last year, it was in March sometime.Alison Rabil: Well, we can wait until early March, but since they told us about the state, I wanted to see if we wanted to at least walk through whatever we need to do. So that even if we sent it early March, I don't want to send out another set of estimated awards in February if we already know we're going to send… you know what I mean? If we can pretty much, maybe at the end of February, go ahead and send out our actual awards to our first years. Or to our prospective first years, and then we could kind of keep spitting those out, I guess.Alison Rabil: But we don't mail those, which is probably good. And then we would need to figure out the communications, if we're not mailing them, to let people know that new stuff is out there. And I would want to notify parents, if we can, include the parents. I don't know what we've done in the past, in terms of how we've notified people. And it wouldn't go on my Mountaineer, right?Sheila Burleson: No, but if we have estimated awarded, and we update that—for example, state from the $2,000 up to the $3,026 for a zero—that automatically sends a message to a student that something has changed on their account. It's very generic, it just says, check your student account, something has changed, or your financial aid.Alison Rabil: Yeah, but most of these kids are not going to have access to AppalNet. They're never gonna look.Sheila Burleson: Right, I'm saying…Alison Rabil: I'm wondering whether…Sheila Burleson: I'm saying the generic message would not help them anyway. So for communication, we could grab the students and whatever parent information there is from Slate, I guess, or maybe from Spaden, if they've listed a parent contact? Or from the FAFSA, I guess.Alison Rabil: Is there a way—maybe this is a question for Bailey upstairs—is there a way to update MyMountaineer without necessarily sending out a new award letter or anything, just to update the award, so that if they go into MyMountaineer, they'll see the updated award, and we can push them to My Mountaineer as opposed to…Wendy Ray: I think there is.Alison Rabil: If there is, then that could be helpful. Because the state awards are going to be, in many cases, more than what we actually estimated, which would be to our benefit.Sheila Burleson: How does that information get pushed into Slate, into My Mountaineer?Kenneth Kirksey: The job runs every day.Wendy Ray: Yeah.Kenneth Kirksey: And it looks for any changed awards and pushes that over to Slate.Kenneth Kirksey: Well, that's perfect, then. It would update my Mountaineer portal, right?Sheila Burleson: Cool.Kenneth Kirksey: Now, I don't know how Bailey decides what emails to send, when to who.Alison Rabil: Well, we could work with her to send out a special one that says, "Hey, your award's been finalized." I would want as many of Wendy's awards in there as possible. So Wendy, for her first years anyway, after this round, would most of yours be in for first years after next week?Wendy Ray: Yeah. Yeah, by the end of next week. All of them will have their initial offer out. They will be done.Sheila Burleson: So we could go earlier than usual, and that would be good.Alison Rabil: Yeah, if we aim for mid to late February or whatever, we're not in a huge rush.Alison Rabil: That begs the question, then, how do we get set up for actual awards?Kenneth Kirksey: And that's what the document I just sent to y'all is about. The thing we would need to do before we started running it is that point four, "check the regular packaging setup." We just need to review all of those things to make sure everything is set up correctly. So, I'd say let's schedule a meeting, or we could use one of our regular Fridays.Alison Rabil: I think that'd be good. It's probably good to have Jonathan here, too.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah. Okay, let me make that a note. The process is we've got all these estimated awards out there. So we run a pop sel to get all of the people that have estimated awards that are in that packaging group, and we set a null package date. We don't cancel it. And then, right now, we have the estimated rule.Sheila Burleson: rule.Kenneth Kirksey: When we're running 26-27, it sees that estimated rule, runs it first, and then stops. So nothing else happens in 26-27 package. Once we deactivate that ESTFR rule and run packaging, then it's going to start doing the regular packaging process. So, the basic flip over is find everybody that's got an estimated award, set a null package day for all those awards, disable the ESTFR rule, and we're done. Then we start running regular packaging.Alison Rabil: And then, I still would want to leave it off in banner so that they can't see it, right?Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah, and Info Access is off globally for 26-27.Alison Rabil: Yeah, I wouldn't turn that on until we turn it on for everybody. Okay.Kenneth Kirksey: As far as the summer awarding process, let me pull up our chain. I'll share that. Of course, it timed out on me right now, and I need to see it. Okay. So, this is the summer awarding chain. And I am going to review all of this. I've got all of the steps in my notes with Jen to figure out what we need to do to update it for 25-26. I think it's mostly just going to be changing some parameters. And, I'm also working on a document that explains each one of these steps so that everybody can kind of understand what it's doing.Kenneth Kirksey: Question I had… The Summer State Grants killed us last year. We were never able to get that working correctly. And I just got off the financial aid UNC Leeds meeting, and there, apparently, there is a way to… what killed us was we were trying to calculate the amount of the awards and match what was on the state grants portal. We couldn't get the data from the state grants portal. This year, we can get the data from the State Grants Portal. And there is a way to have Tracy at the UNC System Office automatically generate our file every day and put it on their FTP site. And then we can automate downloading that file and then running it through the state grant awarder. So, we don't have to manually download it, we don't have to calculate it, it should just go. And I volunteered to be on a working group for state grants with some of the other UNC financial aid people. So, I will keep y'all up to date on what we figure out.Alison Rabil: We also had the issue of we awarded it… didn't we award our aid alphabetically, as opposed to when they actually registered or something? And we can't do that. It needs to be by the date that they actually register.Kenneth Kirksey: That was…Sheila Burleson: Oh my god.Kenneth Kirksey: That was for ACOG, wasn't it?Alison Rabil: It was, but we got rid of that. So, is ACOG even in this? It would be nice if we could do summer ACOG and just award it out of the… whatever it is, 8053, or whatever the heck number it is. But it would have to be by the FAFSA date and not by their… whether their name started with A, otherwise we can't do it.Sheila Burleson: That was just an error, and we fixed it. But we fixed it by sort of taking it off and then reposting it, and I don't…Alison Rabil: So if we can actually build it into the formula, is what I mean.Kenneth Kirksey: I will make a note.Sheila Burleson: I think we took it out, or thought about not putting it in, because we didn't know if we were going to have any money.Alison Rabil: But we have money this time, and we have about as much as we had last year. We have, like, $1.3 million or something, so we have a fair amount.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah, it wasn't part of this automated process.Sheila Burleson: That's because we didn't know what we were doing with it last year. Can we make it a part?Kenneth Kirksey: I will, when I review this, I will figure that out.Sheila Burleson: That would be great.Kenneth Kirksey: Now, I think the issue is because we have to look at how much we have and then award it based on who was here first. We might be able to automate it as a separate process, but I don't think it would work as part of the daily process, because ACOG doesn't get awarded like that. We usually award ACOG in that one big chunk, correct?Alison Rabil: For our regular packages, you mean? It gets awarded based on a need criteria, like they have a… I think for 26-27, it's less than $1 SAI or something like that.Sheila Burleson: $1.Alison Rabil: And we're just gonna… but then we shut it off when we ran out of money. That's why we actually had more money left over, because we never turned it back on, which we should have, but that was my fault. Anyway.Angie Daugherty: And it gets… it gets awarded, though, with regular packaging.Kenneth Kirksey: Correct.Angie Daugherty: It's not separate.Sheila Burleson: Right.Alison Rabil: Right, it's not separate during the year. So if we package this summer on a… So it's based on registration date for summer, not on the FAFSA receipt date. And so, I'm wondering…Sheila Burleson: So that's the difference. The other criteria would be the same, but the regular year does not take into consideration a date range that we want for summer. So we would have to just add in the same criteria, but with a date in addition…Alison Rabil: I have a question. If we packaged on a daily basis for summer and use the same need criteria—so they're high-need kids, however we define that in terms of the SAI—if we repackaged on a daily basis, wouldn't it pick up whoever registered?Sheila Burleson: Theoretically, yeah.Alison Rabil: So that that would handle the…Sheila Burleson: We wouldn't have to write in a…Alison Rabil: ...need to manage the people who registered first. They would get packaged first, because if you were doing it on a regular basis, you would be packaging whoever fell into the registered summer group. So wouldn't that theoretically take care of it?Kenneth Kirksey: No? So, question is… As far as the automated, yeah, we can award ACOG daily, like we do fall-spring. But is there a chance that when we do our first run, we're gonna use up all the ACOG funds?Sheila Burleson: There's a chance.Kenneth Kirksey: Because that's where the problem is. Because if we run it through the automated process, that's not going to look at their registration dates. You can't sort them by registration date.Alison Rabil: Right. Well, maybe we could just look at how many people were registered, and how much we have, and who would qualify, and sort of see how many that would be. And we could cost that out pretty easily if we just knew how many people have fallen into that first summer aid run. But if we started fairly soon after registration opened, as opposed to waiting a couple weeks and then having a massive group, if we could start when registration starts, that would be better, right? And that would mean smaller groups of people would become eligible every day.Sheila Burleson: If we did that, and we package as we go, what problem do we run into with change in registration, drops? Is that impactful in any way anybody can think of? That's typically why we wait, is so that they can get as solid as can be. So, is it more impactful to do that and have to constantly update someone's… and will it constantly update someone's packaging if they've made changes up until the drop-add point? And in that case, is that going to mess us up in terms of packaging as we go and using the date as our common denominator to award the ACOG? Do we write a rule in there for the ACOG, or do we do it this way?Kenneth Kirksey: The way it works, those first pop sels look for anybody who has registration has changed.Sheila Burleson: Okay.Kenneth Kirksey: And then it runs them through the process. Now… we've got the cancel offers, but those are for sub and unsub loans. And you remember, too, on this summer process, we are totally bypassing the regular packaging process. We're not using RPE pack today. So, all of the awards are getting added manually… well, not manually, but not through RPE package.Sheila Burleson: A custom job, Kenneth Kirksey.Kenneth Kirksey: No.Alison Rabil: Well, it's like we post the aid, right? So it's pretty much… Okay. So…Kenneth Kirksey: So, I'm not sure that this is set up for removing aid.Alison Rabil: Or adjusting it based on…Angie Daugherty: I think the Pell adjusts, but the other…Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah, the Pell does, because we run it through RPE Pell, J.Angie Daugherty: Right, but I think the other does not, and then we just adjust after drop-add.Alison Rabil: In chunks, right? So we let people register, and then we award it. When we get enough people that we spend all of our money, we award it. And then two weeks later, we check registrations, and we sort of do an adjusted award. I mean, we would have to sort of regularly adjust specifically ACOG and not put it in. I don't know.Kenneth Kirksey: I'll look and see how we handled it last year.LeeAnn Barnes: If it doesn't adjust, it may create Discreps too, right? So…Alison Rabil: Yeah, the goal would be to touch it as little as possible, and by as few people as possible.Kenneth Kirksey: The Biz-Ops team, and…Alison Rabil: Alright. Maybe it's a point between registration and when the bill is due for summer, because they start registering for summer pretty, like, what, March?Wendy Ray: April 1st.Alison Rabil: Okay. And when's the bill due? Anybody know when summer bill is due? Like, maybe we could do a post right before the summer bill is due.Wendy Ray: I can look up Adam's calendar, hang on.Alison Rabil: In any case, that would be a good date to work around, so that if we're gonna award the ACOG, then their bill would at least reflect the most money we can give them for summer based on whatever their registration is at that point, right before the bill, so that the bill can take it into account, I would think, right?Wendy Ray: Memo aid is 4/17, first bill is 4/22.Alison Rabil: So, something around 4/15.Kenneth Kirksey: Okay. Well, I will review my packaging documentation and answer these questions, and if my documentation doesn't answer it, I'll check with Jen. And then also schedule a meeting to review the packaging setup for 26-27. So, I guess all of us, plus Jonathan, should be involved in that. So, we might make that our next Friday. That sounds like a good plan.LeeAnn Barnes: I was looking back at last year, and it looks like they sent the Dear Colleague letter, or whatever, about the Pell on January 31st. February 1st is the deadline for them to do that. It can change if Congress decides to go back in up until March 14th, so that could be why we wait till March, but usually they don't.Sheila Burleson: My fear this time would be that they would decrease it. But hopefully they're not going down that road.Kenneth Kirksey: While I'm pulling up my calendar... Registration for Summer One opens in April.Alison Rabil: It was April 1, right?Alison Rabil: And when did we say that the aid gets memoed?Wendy Ray: For Summer 1, Memo Aid is 4/17. And summer 2 is 5/29.Alison Rabil: And so, do we want to put in a placeholder date for posting summer aid by 4/15, at least the first round or something like that, so it hits before memo?Kenneth Kirksey: 4/15…Alison Rabil: Yeah, 4/15, so it would be before the memo hits. Just so we remember, I guess.LeeAnn Barnes: You want to do that lock Pell before you start the awarding process, just so the Pell doesn't calculate wrong. So I know you have it the same day, but that should go above. You'll lock both, fall and spring.Alison Rabil: I don't think LeeAnn would be alone.LeeAnn Barnes: I'm very protective of my Pell numbers. I want them to stay accurate.Alison Rabil: And that does not go unappreciated.Kenneth Kirksey: What would the RPDSBJ for summer be? I don't have that on here. When do we start disbursement?Wendy Ray: For Summer 1 is 5/17. And summer 2 is 7/1 on his calendar.Angie Daugherty: Doesn't the RPDSBJ run memos, too, though?Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah.Angie Daugherty: Then it needs to start before that, if we're memoing on 4/17.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah, this one started 4/18 last year.Angie Daugherty: So that one should be 4/17.Alison Rabil: I thought we weren't running RPJ for summer.Kenneth Kirksey: No, disbursements, yeah.Sheila Burleson: memoing.Alison Rabil: Oh, okay. Just not packaging. Okay, got it. I got all my RPs and DISBs all mixed up.Kenneth Kirksey: What was the date that you were looking for? Registration for Summer One?Alison Rabil: Oh, okay.Kenneth Kirksey: Last day to add a class summer…Alison Rabil: Summer 1 is… May 27th.Angie Daugherty: But it is drop-add. First day of classes is the 26th, and the last day to add is 27th, so that is our drop-add.Alison Rabil: And then Summer Two, it's July 7th.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah, we're doing it by date, because that's when… basically, anything for summer goes… spring is from January 1st through, I think May 15th. Then summer 2 is May 15th through July 29th. Fall is 8/1 through 12/31. Okay. Do we have an updated bill for…Wendy Ray: What are you looking for? Sorry.Kenneth Kirksey: Updated bill.Wendy Ray: He doesn't have that listed on his calendar, it's just his first bill.Angie Daugherty: The updated bill is usually after drop-add, when we adjust. So it would be after class is start.Alison Rabil: We should put Flight Path on there, too. That May 26th date for the first date is good for Flight Path, too. That's the first day of summer for Flight Path.Angie Daugherty: Allison, we try to forget them.Alison Rabil: I'm sorry. I'm trying to be good about not being like, "shit, we forgot them again." What is their last day to add? Is that the same, too? It says, summer day, last day to add, last day to drop, May 28th for them. So they're one day different. How friggin' annoying.Kenneth Kirksey: I ran CPOS test yesterday, and it looks like BR Test 9 banner is talking with Degree Works. It didn't throw a bunch of errors, but it also didn't process any students. So, at least that's progress. I'm working on… Jen doesn't have CPOS access. So, I submitted a ticket this morning to get her access so she can take a look at things. And Sheila, I will probably be scheduling a meeting next week with you, me, and Jen to continue on the CPOS.Sheila Burleson: Cool.Alison Rabil: Can you just put me in there? But don't schedule it around me, schedule over whatever's there, but if I can make it, I'd like to just listen in. Because I told the UAC people that I would let them know what the steps were. Not that Sheila can't do that, but I want to just sort of listen in, see what needs to happen.Kenneth Kirksey: Will do.Kenneth Kirksey: And also shared yesterday, I emailed y'all, I put those reports on the Flight Path dashboard for people that were admitted as PKH, but they're not in a PKH budget, or people admitted as not PKH, but they are in a PKH budget. There's none of the latter at this point. But we do have a lot of PKH that are in, like, no admin, standard, cancel, etc.Alison Rabil: And we should look through…Sheila Burleson: Yeah, why are they like that, and what do we need to do?Alison Rabil: Angie, can you work with Jonathan to kind of take a look and see what the story is there, and let us know what we need to do?Angie Daugherty: It is where they get… it's where they switch back and forth, and it doesn't get picked up, their new switch. I don't know if that's something Banner does, or if we just have to manually do them. We have been manually doing them, but if there's 4,000 PTH students and they keep doing it, it's probably something we need to look at about a system doing it. I just have been manually updating.Alison Rabil: But even so, it's only going to get bigger. They're asking us now, which makes total sense, to start thinking about those things that we may only have 10 right now, we may have 150 a year from now. So if we can think of ways to adjust that now while the numbers are still small, it's going to be to everybody's benefit, because if this takes off like they want it to, then we don't want to be doing this a year from now for that many students.Sheila Burleson: Is that affecting all packaging, budget, and tracking?Angie Daugherty: It doesn't impact their raw rec tracking, but it does budget, it does awards.Sheila Burleson: Those groupings, the packaging and the budget groups that are affected, okay.Kenneth Kirksey: Well, when you review those, I might want to be in on that meeting.Angie Daugherty: Okay, I'll set up something with Jonathan and you next week, and we can go over your list.Kenneth Kirksey: Okay. Sounds like a plan.Alison Rabil: Which just made me think, for summer, we need to take PKH out of there. We need to take online programs out of there, and PKH out of there. So we just need to make a note that if we're packaging people, we're not including them in the grant aid stuff. So I don't know how that works.Kenneth Kirksey: So, no PK packaging?Alison Rabil: Well, we need to package them, but they only get… they would get Pell, State… they wouldn't get any institutional aid.Sheila Burleson: And we did that across the board for online, didn't we?Alison Rabil: Anybody online, including PKH.Kenneth Kirksey: Alright, so they only get…Alison Rabil: They get everything except institutional, so they would get Pell, they would get state aid, they would get loan aid. Yeah. That'd be it. What they get now, basically.Kenneth Kirksey: Okay, it's 10:59. I can go ahead and add these. Y'all won't have to stay on the line. We'll just pick up next week.Sheila Burleson: Thanks, all!Kenneth Kirksey: Yep, thank you very much. We've got a process here.Alison Rabil: Yay, I'm gonna go get my car.Kenneth Kirksey: Okay. Y'all ready for it to snow?Alison Rabil: Yeah. Ready as we're gonna be.Sheila Burleson: I'm not going to Charleston this weekend, either.Alison Rabil: I'll have to let people know whether I'm gonna make it in next week, too, so we'll see.Kenneth Kirksey: Alright. See y'all later. Thanks.Alison Rabil: Bye.Kenneth Kirksey: Bye.

item.title: 2026-01-30 - Process Calendar Meeting - Summary
item.description: Alison Rabil Kenneth Kirksey Sheila Burleson Wendy Ray Angie Daugherty LeeAnn Barnes Impact of Condition 2 Weather Status: Discussion on the virtual nature of upcoming interviews and confirming that staff (Wendy, Allison, Bailey, Anthony, Sydney) will continue working through the weather condition. Conversion to Actual Awards (26-27): Strategic planning for moving from estimated to actual financial aid awards for prospective first-year students, specifically focusing on the stability of State and Pell grants. Communication and Portal Updates: How to notify students and parents of award updates via Slate and the MyMountaineer portal. Summer Awarding (25-26): Review of the summer awarding chain, including automation of Summer State Grants and the strategy for awarding ACOG funds. Technical System Updates: Updates on CPOS (Course Program of Study) testing and resolving budget discrepancies for PKH (Pathways) students. When are we planning on regarding the actual award? (Asked by: Kenneth Kirksey) The team aims for mid-to-late February or early March, as State and Pell figures are now stable. (Answered by: Alison Rabil & Angie Daugherty) Is there a way to update MyMountaineer without necessarily sending out a new award letter? (Asked by: Alison Rabil) Yes, a job runs daily that pushes changed awards from Banner to Slate, which updates the MyMountaineer portal. (Answered by: Kenneth Kirksey & Wendy Ray) How does the information get pushed into Slate/MyMountaineer? (Asked by: Sheila Burleson) A daily automated job identifies changed awards and pushes the data. (Answered by: Kenneth Kirksey) Is ACOG included in the summer awarding process? (Asked by: Alison Rabil) It was not part of the automated process last year, but Kenneth will investigate building it into the formula for this year. (Answered by: Kenneth Kirksey) What problem do we run into with change in registration or drops if we package summer aid early? (Asked by: Sheila Burleson) Pell adjusts automatically, but other aid may require manual adjustment after the drop-add period to avoid discrepancies. (Answered by: Kenneth Kirksey & Angie Daugherty) What is the first bill date for summer? (Asked by: Alison Rabil) The first bill is due on April 22nd. (Answered by: Wendy Ray) Condition 2 Operations: Virtual interviews will proceed as scheduled; designated staff will work tomorrow despite the weather condition. Actual Awards Timeline: The office will aim to send finalized awards to prospective first-years in late February. ACOG Strategy: ACOG will be awarded based on registration date for the summer term, rather than FAFSA receipt date. Online/PKH Summer Aid: Online and PKH students will be excluded from institutional grant aid for the summer but will remain eligible for Pell, state aid, and loans. Pell Locking: Pell grants must be locked for fall and spring before starting the summer awarding process to ensure accuracy. Task: Finalize and share the document explaining the steps of the summer awarding chain. [Owner: Kenneth Kirksey, Deadline: Not Specified] Task: Coordinate with Bailey to create a special communication for parents/students regarding finalized awards. [Owner: Alison Rabil/Wendy Ray, Deadline: Late February] Task: Schedule a meeting with the team and Jonathan to review the regular packaging setup for 26-27. [Owner: Kenneth Kirksey, Deadline: Next Friday] Task: Participate in the UNC System working group to automate the daily State Grant file download. [Owner: Kenneth Kirksey, Deadline: Ongoing] Task: Investigate how ACOG was handled last year and if it can be automated for Summer 25-26. [Owner: Kenneth Kirksey, Deadline: Prior to April] Task: Set a placeholder date of April 15th to post the first round of summer aid (prior to the April 17th memo date). [Owner: Kenneth Kirksey, Deadline: April 15] Task: Schedule a meeting with Sheila and Jen to continue CPOS testing in the BR Test 9 environment. [Owner: Kenneth Kirksey, Deadline: Next Week] Task: Meet with Jonathan and Kenneth to review the PKH budget discrepancy reports and determine a system for automatic updates. [Owner: Angie Daugherty, Deadline: Next Week] Would you like me to draft the "Actual Awards" announcement email for Bailey or the agenda for next Friday’s packaging review?

item.title: 2026-01-30 - Direct Deposit Email Training Meeting - Transcript
item.description: Sheila Burleson: Sorry, I was loading a link and realized you already did one, so let me tell Christine to use yours.Kenneth Kirksey: Oh, got it.Sheila Burleson: Well, maybe she'll know… Hang on. She just got back in from lunch late, because Kim's training went over this morning. So, how are you?Kenneth Kirksey: Good! I just had lunch at Troy's.Sheila Burleson: At where?Kenneth Kirksey: Troy's.Sheila Burleson: Troy's. Ugh, yum. We love Troy's. I'd go eat a big salad!Kenneth Kirksey: I got the open-faced turkey today.Sheila Burleson: How was it?Kenneth Kirksey: Good move.Sheila Burleson: Good. Let me get your other document in here.Christine Garst: Hello.Kenneth Kirksey: Hello!Sheila Burleson: Let me close my door.Christine Garst: How are you, Kenneth?Kenneth Kirksey: I am good.Christine Garst: Good!Sheila Burleson: Okay!Sheila Burleson: So we are taking this on.Kenneth Kirksey: Yup. I shared a link to the instructions with y'all, but I'm going to need to add some things to this as we go.Sheila Burleson: Okay. Did you see those, Christine, in the chat?Christine Garst: Yep.Sheila Burleson: Okay. What do you want us to do? Like, go through it?Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah, and I would say if Christine's going to be doing this, let's let Christine drive.Sheila Burleson: Okay.Christine Garst: Woohoo! Do I need edit access to this document, or just view access?Sheila Burleson: Let him edit. He'll edit as we go, because we don't know where we're going with it.Christine Garst: Right. Okay.Kenneth Kirksey: So, the first thing is… Okay, and there's actually a step before the first step here.Sheila Burleson: Okay.Kenneth Kirksey: Let's do it with direct deposit.Sheila Burleson: Christine, yep. In Banner, pull up ROAUSDF and see if you can make sure you can get in there.Christine Garst: You're going to have to say that slower.Sheila Burleson: Sorry, R-O-A USDF. And it should be a field of grids and numbers.Christine Garst: Oh, no, you want to see what I'm seeing? That's all I got.Sheila Burleson: Hit go.Christine Garst: Error.Sheila Burleson: Oh, well, we need a Banner ID in there. Put mine in, 305-8900… 305-588. Okay, so there are rows and rows, columns and columns of fields that we use for different things.Christine Garst: Okay.Sheila Burleson: And one of those is for a direct deposit. So, it'll be in field 68, based on what Kenneth’s… So you would just tab over on the top where the first tab is highlighted, and find the one that would have 68 in it. And there it is. Student has direct deposit. So that's… I just want to make sure you were in there.Christine Garst: Yep.Sheila Burleson: Okay, so…Kenneth Kirksey: Okay, so the first thing is… go to… and you can go ahead and share your screen, Christine.Christine Garst: Fair.Kenneth Kirksey: And go to Banner.Sheila Burleson: Here's...Kenneth Kirksey: And then go to GLRSLCT.Sheila Burleson: We know that field.Christine Garst: Okay?Kenneth Kirksey: Okay, and then application, Financial aid.Christine Garst: Pretty.Sheila Burleson: Yeah, it's yeah.Christine Garst: I got it, I got it, I got it.Kenneth Kirksey: Nope. Creator is KirkseyKB1.Christine Garst: Is it S-E-Y or SY?Kenneth Kirksey: S-E-Y.Christine Garst: KB1?Sheila Burleson: K as in Ken?Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah.Christine Garst: Oh, yeah. All right.Kenneth Kirksey: Let me just look at something real quick. Make sure I tell you the right population selection. Okay, yeah. Okay, for selection ID, do you know how to search for selection IDs in here? Have you done that before?Sheila Burleson: Drop-down little ellipses, like you've watched me do it.Kenneth Kirksey: Yep.Christine Garst: I have watched you do it, but I haven't done it, which means my brain hasn't learned it.Kenneth Kirksey: User not allowed to access GLISLCT?Sheila Burleson: What?Kenneth Kirksey: Well, you don't need to access this.Sheila Burleson: Well, she's going to need... Stupid.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah, we need to give her access to that.Sheila Burleson: For sure. I don't know why that's not on there. I thought we were golden.Kenneth Kirksey: Should she still have the same Banner access as you, Sheila?Sheila Burleson: It's fine with me, but I have more than you need, but you won't know that unless you do something that you're not supposed to by accident. There's some stuff that… let's just update her to mine. I don't care.Kenneth Kirksey: Okay. So, go to GLBDATAJ.Christine Garst: For the selection ID?Sheila Burleson: No, no, no.Kenneth Kirksey: No, no.Sheila Burleson: X out.Kenneth Kirksey: I need to, yeah, X out.Sheila Burleson: GLBDATAJ. She's not going to have that either.Christine Garst: Nope.Sheila Burleson: She got no Gs. Okay, well…Kenneth Kirksey: Okay, well, Sheila…Sheila Burleson: Looks like I'm driving.Kenneth Kirksey: You want to drive?Sheila Burleson: Either way.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah, and I'm recording this, and so I will save it and share it with y'all, so y'all will have it for reference.Christine Garst: Okay.Sheila Burleson: My face looks like it's glowing.Christine Garst: Haha!Sheila Burleson: Does it look really, really white to you guys?Christine Garst: Yeah. Okay, great.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah, you look like…Sheila Burleson: I wonder why that is.Kenneth Kirksey: You stole my blinds? It's because of the dark background behind you.Sheila Burleson: Weird.Kenneth Kirksey: The balance on the camera is trying to do an average exposure instead of an exposure for the face. I wonder… I think there's actually a way to set that.Sheila Burleson: I got to do something, I feel like I'm… yeah. Oh, that didn't work.Kenneth Kirksey: Let me look at my settings.Sheila Burleson: How about now? Nope.Kenneth Kirksey: That'll work.Sheila Burleson: Oh, I don't know how to get rid of it. There it is. Those are cute!Kenneth Kirksey: Okay, good to go.Sheila Burleson: Okay, well, I'll fiddle with that later. Let me get my banner up, which I've been kicked out of again.Christine Garst: I need to work on DocuWare as well. I tried to log in this morning, and it's telling me that I have an invalid login.Sheila Burleson: When you log into DocuWare, you don't log in the way you think you're supposed to. You need to choose… what is it under there? Google login?Christine Garst: Log in through Microsoft?Sheila Burleson: Microsoft, yes.Christine Garst: Yeah, it won't let me.Sheila Burleson: It won't let you do that either?Christine Garst: No.Sheila Burleson: Hmm, I've always thought that was weird anyway. But…Kenneth Kirksey: I'll make a note to submit a ticket for that. Okay, so application, finaid, Selection, Creator ID, KirkseyKB1, and…Sheila Burleson: that.Kenneth Kirksey: And then selection ID is… well, I closed that window. I think it's students with direct deposit, underscores between the words.Sheila Burleson: Well, dang ya.Kenneth Kirksey: Nope.Sheila Burleson: Huh?Kenneth Kirksey: Deposit, singular. No, we need to be in GLBDATAJ, not GLRSLCT.Sheila Burleson: Oh, I went back to where you told her to go.Kenneth Kirksey: First.Sheila Burleson: So that's different. Where do you want me to be? Is there a parameter?Kenneth Kirksey: Click go. Okay, selection identifier should be students with direct deposit.Sheila Burleson: All right, is it a database or a Python printer?Kenneth Kirksey: Database. And Christine, if you don't… if you leave that blank, you won't be able to get any output.Christine Garst: Hmm.Kenneth Kirksey: So, always put database in there. There are some that have Python, but those are usually pre-populated. Okay, selection ID, application code…Sheila Burleson: That needs to be you.Kenneth Kirksey: And I…Sheila Burleson: It's not Jones, is it?Kenneth Kirksey: No. Creator, obviously, is KirkseyKB1.Sheila Burleson: Is that it? Is that all there is in there?Kenneth Kirksey: That's it. Okay. And then click the save parameter set as… Christine, what that does is, if you have to run this again, it will save what you've already entered, so you don't have to enter everything in again.Christine Garst: Okay.Kenneth Kirksey: And that will add that to the…Sheila Burleson: You want me to run it?Kenneth Kirksey: Yes.Sheila Burleson: What does that mean?Kenneth Kirksey: You have to add the AIDY code.Sheila Burleson: Where is it?Christine Garst: The very bottom.Kenneth Kirksey: The very bottom.Christine Garst: There you go.Sheila Burleson: Didn't see that one. You have to be in that bottom field somewhere, your cursor in that bottom field, or it won't run.Kenneth Kirksey: Nope. Okay, so what this has done is it is running a report of all of the students that currently have direct deposit. And we've indicated that by putting the value in that user-defined field.Sheila Burleson: So, the user-defined field is that number 68 in ROAUSDF. Christine. That's what those are in all of those columns of fields. They're called user-defined fields.Christine Garst: Okay.Sheila Burleson: And that number 68, you explain how it attaches to this job, Kenneth, because I can't explain that.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah, the number… the 68 is just… we've set that field to be the direct deposit field.Christine Garst: Okay.Kenneth Kirksey: If there's a Y in that field, then the student has direct deposit. And we're going to populate that in the next step.Sheila Burleson: What we are doing is we're continuously contacting students and telling them to set up direct deposit. Set it up, set it up, set it up.Christine Garst: Right.Sheila Burleson: As we're sending them, new students are coming in, but old students who didn't do it are still on there, but students who did follow our advice and did it drop off. So we have to clean the list each time, and we're going to do repeats, but we're also going to have some new, and we're going to have some fall off.Christine Garst: Yeah.Sheila Burleson: Okay? And so… Do you want the output for this job?Kenneth Kirksey: Yes, so we need to go to GLAEXTR.Sheila Burleson: Do you want this output?Kenneth Kirksey: No.Sheila Burleson: Do you need to see it for any reason?Kenneth Kirksey: No.Sheila Burleson: Okay.Kenneth Kirksey: Although, well… wait a second, we might be able to get what we want here instead of GLAEXTR.Sheila Burleson: Right.Kenneth Kirksey: Click on… Go back to GLBDATAJ. Okay. And hold on a sec, nope. I'm writing down steps here.Sheila Burleson: Well, don't you want me to open it and see if there's anything worthwhile in here? All it's going to tell us is what just ran.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah, what we're looking for is a count.Sheila Burleson: Okay. Then, yeah, we should… Is that correct based on your prior jobs? So, 30,234?Kenneth Kirksey: Yep. Yeah, we just need to make a note of that number, because we send the before and after numbers to Allison. She wants to know how many we've added.Sheila Burleson: Okay. So is that just pulling data for… Where's that number coming from? That's a large number.Kenneth Kirksey: That's everybody in 25-26 that has a 25-26 direct deposit flag. That'll include students that aren't attending.Sheila Burleson: Okay, are there duplicates in there?Kenneth Kirksey: No.Sheila Burleson: So, it would be anybody who ever had it, even if they're not here, but they were at some point in 24, 25?Kenneth Kirksey: Yes.Sheila Burleson: Or they applied and set all the stuff up and didn't come.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah.Sheila Burleson: Okay, okay. That's a lot. That's a lot of num… that's a lot number. That's like 10,000 more than we should have. Like, 15,000 more than we should have. All right, now what do we do?Kenneth Kirksey: Okay. Okay, then the next step is we get the list of students with direct deposit from Ann Heath.Sheila Burleson: Okay. Have you gotten one?Kenneth Kirksey: Well, we already did January back on January 1st. We get that file at the first of every month.Sheila Burleson: Is she sending these somewhere automatically?Kenneth Kirksey: We request it.Sheila Burleson: Okay. So, is it something like if I chat her right now, she can send it to me?Kenneth Kirksey: Possibly. Give it a shot.Sheila Burleson: So, I need January 1st through January 30th? I need January.Kenneth Kirksey: Well, no, she just sends us… She just sends us the list of students that have direct deposit. We only add the ones that are new.Sheila Burleson: Oh, she just does that…Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah.Sheila Burleson: that around the first of every month.Kenneth Kirksey: Yes.Sheila Burleson: Oh, okay. You… okay. I misunderstood what you said when you were saying we already did January. Do you have a list you can send me? Okay. She does not appear to be online, but let's say we have a list. Can we move forward just to see what the next steps are, or do we need to stop?Kenneth Kirksey: It's going to be a lot easier to do if we have a list. It's not going to make much sense without it.Sheila Burleson: Then I'm not going to waste our time.Kenneth Kirksey: Okay.Sheila Burleson: And since I didn't ask for it in advance, because I didn't really know how that was working, and I should have asked you.Kenneth Kirksey: Huh.Sheila Burleson: And I want Christine to have… yeah. Yeah, the FTP access for Christine. Did you see my request for the secure file transfer for both Christine and Jonathan? He's no longer… he no longer has WinSCP on his machine, because he got a new machine.Kenneth Kirksey: Oh, well, he's still got access, he just doesn't have WinSCP.Sheila Burleson: Right.Kenneth Kirksey: Because he uploads stuff all the time.Sheila Burleson: Yeah, but he's doing it through the new way you're using data load. Remember I told you the other day, he told me that WinSCP was going away?Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah.Sheila Burleson: And he didn't understand that was only for the data load processes, but not for the rest of us. And so I told him, he's like, "Oh, well, I want it back." And I'm like, "You don't have it?" He said, "No, I have a new machine, but I can't access it anymore." So, I don't know. But Christine definitely cannot, so if you could get both of them back.Kenneth Kirksey: I think… well, I think WinSCP is on the software center that you can download it yourself.Sheila Burleson: I think you can, but didn't you tell me that we can't… and then how do we get permissions for our institution?Kenneth Kirksey: Well, that's what I have to submit the ticket to get that.Sheila Burleson: Right, okay. Well, we can go ahead and download, that's not a big deal.Kenneth Kirksey: Actually, no, because for this, no, for this, we're not using her user account, we're using a Finaid account, so I can just give her those credentials. So, while we're here…Sheila Burleson: We start. She needs that for Banner emails.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah.Sheila Burleson: I mean, she's going to need WinSCP for other things.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah, let's go ahead, since we're here already, and we got time, let's just go ahead and install that on her machine.Sheila Burleson: All right!Kenneth Kirksey: So, yeah, Christine, share your screen.Christine Garst: What do you mean? Is she back on the right screen?Sheila Burleson: Turn your cartoons off and pay attention.Christine Garst: That's funny. No, I need to get a camera for… because I'm using my laptop camera, but that little screen is so small. So my zoom is here, but my big screens are here, so I need to get a camera for my…Sheila Burleson: They're in the… they're in the cage. Can I get a key out of… does Debra leave the keys here?Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah, but I don't know that they're accessible.Sheila Burleson: She's got a key to the cage.Kenneth Kirksey: Yep, you have to check with her. Okay, Christine. Yep. Go down to the search bar and type, type in Software Center. Open that… Cameron! Hi, bro.Sheila Burleson: Hmm.Christine Garst: Maybe?Kenneth Kirksey: Are you on the wired network or wireless?Christine Garst: While they're looking at cable. Wireless.Kenneth Kirksey: Jeez.Sheila Burleson: She did her… she did her…Kenneth Kirksey: That's the problem.Sheila Burleson: Why?Kenneth Kirksey: Wireless… the Wi-Fi in that corner of the building's bad.Sheila Burleson: Are you kidding me? I'm like, I'm on it.Christine Garst: I really had a problem.Kenneth Kirksey: You're not in that corner.Sheila Burleson: That corner of the building is bad. Wireless.Kenneth Kirksey: It's not… the connection is not great.Sheila Burleson: Do I need to ethernetter? I think we do with that, did I leave that cord in your other old office, or did you?Christine Garst: I think I might have one in this office. I'm going to dig through some drawers.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah… Whatever. Okay. Go up to the search bar at the top right.Christine Garst: Great, you know? Surge bar in the top right, yeah.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah, type… just start typing WIN, W-I-N, SCP… And then hit enter. Yep, there it is. So, double-click on that. Install.Christine Garst: I think this has been the biggest learning curve for me, of learning the programs, the softwares and the programs. You all speak like a different language.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah, and it'll take you about a year. Well, that's… I've been here two years, and I still ain't 100%.Christine Garst: It's impressive.Kenneth Kirksey: Okay. Where'd Sheila go?Christine Garst: I don't know. She's just gone.Kenneth Kirksey: Okay, well… We'll continue with Adler, she can watch the recording.Christine Garst: Okay.Kenneth Kirksey: Okay, go down to your search bar in the taskbar.Christine Garst: Oh, I hear her.Kenneth Kirksey: Type WinSCP.Christine Garst: Well, I'm coming. Thank you. Okay. Did you find an ether, or is it happening with that? I mean, it's happening. It's not another, okay. We'll do that later. She's coming back. I have a camera now. I'll set that up later.Kenneth Kirksey: He didn't kick me off. Yes, it did. That is inconvenient. Okay. So, yeah, open WinSCP.Christine Garst: Okay.Kenneth Kirksey: All right, so let me pull up my credentials here. Copy and paste this in the Google chat, then. Okay. Put what I just sent you in the chat for the host name.Christine Garst: Oh, boy. Well, let's see… Where'd he go? This one.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah.Christine Garst: Ace.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah, and take out the HTTPS. We just want jsprod.appstate.edu.Christine Garst: Should I take that slash away as well?Kenneth Kirksey: Yes. Okay. The username is P as in Paul, F-I-N-A-I-D.Christine Garst: Okay.Kenneth Kirksey: The password is… Let me see… And this is all lowercase.Christine Garst: Okay.Kenneth Kirksey: S. U. Percent sign…Christine Garst: Okay?Kenneth Kirksey: F-A-M… 101. And then click on the Advanced button. Directories. Click on directories. Okay, and then I am going to send you another thing in the chat to paste in there.Christine Garst: Kay?Kenneth Kirksey: And just copy that.Christine Garst: In remote or local?Kenneth Kirksey: Remote. Okay, and we need to remove all of that HTTPS stuff. Remove everything up to the slash u01 from the front.Christine Garst: Oh.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah. But leave the U01… leave the slash U01, just everything before that. Okay. Now click, click OK. Then click Save. And click Save Password, it says not recommended. I don't care.Christine Garst: Okay.Sheila Burleson: I used to. Yeah, click OK.Kenneth Kirksey: Okay. Now, we should be able to log in. Let's try it. Click Accept. Okay. You're in.Christine Garst: Boom!Kenneth Kirksey: This, and this is the folder where we will place the list of banner IDs that Ann sends us.Christine Garst: Okay.Kenneth Kirksey: And then Banner will pick it up from there.Christine Garst: Yep. So this is what I've seen Sheila do, like 20 times now.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah.Sheila Burleson: Like, pop cells of IDs to send an email. Yeah, we're just going to… are we going to… are we batch posting something, or…Kenneth Kirksey: Yes.Sheila Burleson: we're going to batch post the Y to the field? Yeah. Okay, I gotcha.Kenneth Kirksey: Nope.Sheila Burleson: Do you remember the first time I was showing you how to do an email, and I said, "Oh, I'm doing the wrong… the wrong process?"Christine Garst: Yeah. Yeah.Sheila Burleson: I was trying to batch post instead of upload an email. So you're going to learn it after all!Christine Garst: Yeah. Great.Sheila Burleson: How to batch post.Sheila Burleson: You guys, though, let's take a breather, because I really would rather do it hands-on, and I'm not hearing back from Ann, and I have to get Connor at 3, so I don't want to get in it without, when we get stuck. So can I send another invite for next week, and we just finish up?Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah, when you get the file from Ann.Sheila Burleson: Right. Okay, that's what we'll do. Okay.Kenneth Kirksey: Okay.Sheila Burleson: I think that's a good plan, but thank you for getting that for her, that's huge. Because now we can do other fun stuff.Christine Garst: Yay! Thank you, Kenneth.Kenneth Kirksey: Okay.Sheila Burleson: All right, if we don't talk… weekend!Kenneth Kirksey: Oh, Christine, I was going to ask how the house search was going.Christine Garst: We closed on our house this week! I know!Sheila Burleson: It's so cute!Kenneth Kirksey: Where is it?Christine Garst: It's just off of Brown's Chapel.Sheila Burleson: Okay. Other side of the world from you, and me. Yeah. So pretty.Christine Garst: It's cute, it's a cute little mountain cottage kind of… kind of thing, so…Sheila Burleson: It's adorable.Christine Garst: Oh my gosh.Kenneth Kirksey: Did you have to offer your firstborn as collateral?Christine Garst: But we actually did pretty good on it, I'm proud of us.Kenneth Kirksey: No.Christine Garst: Got a good deal.Sheila Burleson: She negotiated.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah.Christine Garst: Yeah.Sheila Burleson: Great.Christine Garst: We really negotiated.Kenneth Kirksey: Yep.Sheila Burleson: I'm a hackler, so…Kenneth Kirksey: You're fortunate.Christine Garst: Yeah. We were, like, 100K less than the neighbor's house that sold four months ago. So…Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah, people are not getting what they're asking these days.Sheila Burleson: No, the market has changed again, but I'm glad for you.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah.Sheila Burleson: When my son bought his, it was like we couldn't put in an offer fast enough. He lost place after place after place, because people were just buying them sight unseen. It was just… it was ridiculous at top dollar, and he made out okay. I wish we could have waited it out, but he bought a townhouse in Wilmington, and I love it, and I'm happy for him, but it was grueling.Kenneth Kirksey: Well, we've got one of the units in our development. We live in townhomes, too.Sheila Burleson: Hmm.Kenneth Kirksey: He's got his listed for $500K.Sheila Burleson: Wow.Kenneth Kirksey: It's a 2,700 square foot, three bedroom, two bath.Sheila Burleson: That's pretty big. That's a pretty big townhouse. That's as big as my house.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah. And I'm four bedroom. Yeah. Perfect.Sheila Burleson: and a half baths.Kenneth Kirksey: That ain't what he paid for it.Sheila Burleson: That ain't what he pays for it.Kenneth Kirksey: All right, well, y'all have a good weekend.Christine Garst: Thank you. Stay warm.Kenneth Kirksey: Nope, see ya. Bye.

item.title: 2026-01-30 - Direct Deposit Email Training Meeting - Summary
item.description: Sheila Burleson Kenneth Kirksey Christine Garst Direct Deposit Update Process: Training on how to identify and flag students with direct deposit in Banner using the User Defined Fields (specifically field 68 in ROAUSDF). Population Selection (Pop Sel): Running the GLBDATAJ process to generate a count of students currently flagged for direct deposit for the 25-26 aid year. Software Configuration: Installation and credential setup for WinSCP on Christine’s machine to facilitate file transfers to the jsprod server. Access and Permissions: Troubleshooting Christine’s lack of access to specific Banner forms and DocuWare. Do I need edit access to this document, or just view access? (Asked by: Christine Garst) Sheila Burleson advised that Kenneth should retain edit access to update the instructions in real-time as they go through the process. Do I log into DocuWare through Microsoft? (Asked by: Christine Garst) Sheila Burleson confirmed it is a Microsoft login, though Christine noted it was currently returning an "invalid login" error. Where is the AIDY code located? (Asked by: Sheila Burleson) Christine Garst identified that the field is located at the very bottom of the parameter screen. Where is the number [count] coming from? (Asked by: Sheila Burleson) Kenneth Kirksey explained it represents everyone in the 25-26 aid year with a direct deposit flag, including students who may not be attending. Banner Permissions: Kenneth and Sheila agreed to update Christine’s Banner permissions to match Sheila’s to ensure she has access to GLISLCT and GLBDATAJ. WinSCP Credentials: The team decided to use the functional PFINAID account for WinSCP transfers rather than individual user accounts. Training Pause: The training session was paused because the current list of direct deposit students from Ann Heath was not yet available; the process cannot be demonstrated effectively without a live data file. Task: Submit a IT ticket to resolve Christine’s DocuWare "invalid login" issue. [Owner: Kenneth Kirksey] Task: Submit a ticket to restore WinSCP access/permissions for Jonathan on his new machine. [Owner: Kenneth Kirksey] Task: Request the January direct deposit list from Ann Heath. [Owner: Sheila Burleson] Task: Send a follow-up meeting invitation for next week to complete the training once the data file is received. [Owner: Sheila Burleson, Deadline: Next week] Would you like me to draft the follow-up email to Ann Heath or the IT ticket descriptions mentioned in the action items?
