item.title: 2026-01-27 - Duplicate ISIR Processing How To Meeting - AI Generated Checklist
item.description: Based on the transcript provided, here is the step-by-step checklist for processing duplicate ISIR files in Banner Financial Aid.Before starting manual reviews, perform a "clean slate" operation to remove historical backlog. Run Custom Deletion Job: Execute the custom system job to automatically delete older ISIR transactions and keep only the latest one. Note: This clears the "Duplicate" status and moves the remaining record to either "Hold" or "Suspense" for standard processing. Use this process for daily maintenance or when reviewing records that remain after the automated job. Identify Duplicate Records: In the Banner ISIR matching form, look at the record count on the right (e.g., "Record 1 of 2"). If the ID remains the same when arrowing down but the transaction changes, it is a duplicate. Perform Duplicate Check: * [ ] "Block down" twice. Click OK on the duplicate check. Evaluate Transactions: Arrow down to view the different transaction numbers for the student. Check for a valid SAI (Student Aid Index) or other critical data elements. Determine Match Status: If a Match Exists: Select the correct Banner ID and Save. If No Match Exists: Enter "No Match" in the designated field (second street line) to indicate the record has been reviewed. Delete Older Transactions (Optional/Manual): To keep the list manageable, identify the older/less desirable transaction. Navigate to that specific record and use the Delete function in the top right. Save the changes. Note: The remaining single transaction will now be picked up by the standard nightly match process. To ensure data integrity and automated tracking, follow these strict guidelines regarding the Load button. General Rule: Do NOT click the "Load" button. * Individual loading bypasses the nightly batch processes that track C-flags, comment codes, and tracking groups. Exception Handling (Designated Personnel Only): Only the designated lead (e.g., Jonathan) should use the Load button for urgent cases. Manual Follow-up Required: If a manual load is performed, the user MUST manually: Run the Tracking Group process. Add any necessary tracking codes for comment codes. Would you like me to draft a brief summary of the "Load" button risks to share with the rest of the financial aid staff?
item.guid: Finacial Aid Tech Notes/2026-01-27 - Duplicate ISIR Processing How To Meeting - AI Generated Checklist.md

item.title: 2026-01-27 - Duplicate ISIR Processing How To Meeting - Summary
item.description: Sheila Burleson Jennifer Buckles Kenneth Kirksey Jonathan Ibarra Angie Daugherty Kim (referenced as participant/attendee) Duplicate ISIR Navigation: Understanding how to toggle through multiple records for a single student in the Banner system and interpreting the transaction numbers. Clearing Backlogs: Strategies for managing the current volume of 270 duplicate records (and over 1,000 for the 26-27 cycle) to prevent staff from reviewing the same non-matching records repeatedly. Manual vs. Automated Deletion: The pros and cons of running a custom job to delete old ISIR transactions versus manually deleting records during the review process. System Statuses (Hold vs. Suspense): Clarification on how the system handles records with no matches (Hold) versus potential matches (Suspense). The "Load" Button Risks: A technical discussion on why using the manual "Load" button is dangerous due to the potential for missing automated tracking, C-flags, and comment code updates. Budgeting Discrepancies: Addressing why some students were showing out-of-state tuition rates despite being classified as in-state residents. When I arrow down, the ID number changes but the person doesn't. Does that mean there are two records for that person? Jennifer Buckles confirmed this is correct; they are in "duplicate" status. Sheila was seeing record 2 of 2 for a single individual. Is there a possibility that there would be more than two records? Jennifer Buckles confirmed that it is possible to have more than two records if multiple transactions have been submitted. Do we need to look at the transaction number for any reason? Jennifer Buckles explained that transaction numbers are only relevant when deciding which record to delete; generally, the latest transaction is kept. What is the most efficient way to keep the team from looking at duplicate ISIRs every day? Jennifer Buckles suggested deleting the older duplicates. Once only one transaction remains, the record moves out of the duplicate category and into hold or suspense, clearing it from the daily review list. How is the custom job set up to know which record to keep? Jennifer Buckles, Kenneth Kirksey, and Jonathan Ibarra confirmed the job is configured to keep only the latest transaction. What happens to records in "Hold" at the end of the year? Jennifer Buckles noted that records typically just sit in the temp table and are not purged, though some schools choose to purge them. Should we use the "Load" button as described in the instructions? Jennifer Buckles advised against it. Loading manually bypasses the automated nightly process that stamps records for tracking C-flags and comment codes. If the nightly process doesn't run, those tracking elements are missed. Why did in-state students show out-of-state tuition rates in December? Jennifer Buckles and Kenneth Kirksey concluded it was a timing issue; the budget was added while they were out-of-state, and they were changed to in-state afterward without a budget refresh. Cleanup Strategy: The team will run a one-time custom job to "clean the slate" by deleting all but the latest transactions for the current backlog. Ongoing Maintenance: Moving forward, staff will manually delete older transactions during their daily review to prevent records from staying in the duplicate list. "Load" Button Restriction: The "Load" button will not be used by general staff. Its use is restricted to "special circumstances" only. Authorized "Load" User: Jonathan Ibarra was designated as the person authorized to make the call on using the manual load button, with the understanding that he must then manually verify tracking and comment codes. Record Preservation: The team decided to stick with the "keep the latest transaction" rule for students not yet admitted, as the effort to granularly review transactions for non-applicants is not worth the brainpower. Task: Run the custom job to delete duplicate ISIRs (keeping only the latest) to clean the current backlog. [Owner: Kenneth Kirksey, Deadline: Immediately following the meeting] Task: Schedule a meeting with Kim to review the remaining records after the custom job has run. [Owner: Jonathan Ibarra/Angie Daugherty, Deadline: Not Specified] Task: Test the "Delete Record" functionality in the SITEST environment to confirm the correct button/checkbox for manual deletions. [Owner: Financial Aid Team/Sheila, Deadline: Not Specified] Task: Update the written procedure instructions to remove or provide warnings regarding the "Load" button. [Owner: Not Specified, Deadline: Not Specified] Task: Regularly run the RBRPRC report to catch and fix budget discrepancies caused by residency status changes. [Owner: Kenneth Kirksey, Deadline: Recurring] Task: Upload the meeting recording to the drive and distribute the link. [Owner: Kenneth Kirksey, Deadline: Post-meeting] Would you like me to draft a follow-up email to the participants summarizing these action items?
item.guid: Finacial Aid Tech Notes/2026-01-27 - Duplicate ISIR Processing How To Meeting - Summary.md

item.title: 2026-01-27 - Duplicate ISIR Processing How To Meeting - Transcript
item.description: Sheila Burleson: Start with this person. We block down twice. We do a duplicate check, and there isn't anything. So we hit OK. And then the instruction says, arrow down on your keypad once, and here's one of my questions. When I arrow down, that ID number changes, but the person doesn't. Does that mean that there are two records for that person?Jennifer Buckles: Right, that's why they're in duplicate. If you see over on the right, where it says record 2 of 270, those are the two. Okay. If you arrow back up, you'll go back up to the first one.Sheila Burleson: Okay, so that's what I was doing. I was going down-down to get to the next person, because all of them are like that, or they all should be like that.Jennifer Buckles: Correct.Sheila Burleson: Is there a possibility that there would be more than two?Jennifer Buckles: Yes.Sheila Burleson: Okay, and transaction number, we just ignore that, we don't need to look at that for any reason, honestly.Jennifer Buckles: Right.Sheila Burleson: Okay. And that was kind of hanging us up a little bit, too. We're like, what is that?Jennifer Buckles: The only time you would look at transaction number is when you're trying to decide which one you want to delete. So if you're keeping them for now, because that's the way that the process is set up, you try to match. If there's nothing you can match, they kind of stay hanging out in limbo for as long as you want to leave them out there. Periodically, however often you want to do it, you either run that custom job that deletes the older transaction and keeps the newer one, and then it'll roll into suspense, or into, I guess, either into suspense or into hold, if they're not admitted yet.And then, or, you go in manually and you say, okay, we've got a transaction 4 and a transaction 5. Transaction 4 doesn't have a… you know, if you want to get into granular detail, you can look at the actual transactions and decide, well, 4 has a valid SAI, but 5 doesn't. Let's get rid of 5 and keep 4. So you can make that call.Sheila Burleson: So the transaction number is the number of ISIRs that they have submitted with whatever information is on it. Some of them may be valid in terms of having all the elements we want, some of them wouldn't, and we could get rid of those, but we would still not have a match for the person until we get a match for the person.Jennifer Buckles: Right. So that means this one has 5 transactions, but no match in your system. So that either means they're in suspense. So, they already have an ISIR that's been in suspense, and every time they do a new transaction, it goes into duplicate, you review, delete one, keep the other one, and that cycle just keeps happening, or they just added your school on their fourth or fifth transaction.Sheila Burleson: Got it. Okay. So, as we are popping down here, there could be more than two records for the same person.Jennifer Buckles: Yeah, so if you were to arrow down the second time and see the same person again, then you just arrow down. Yeah, so now we got onto a new one. And you can see over there on the right what record you're on.Sheila Burleson: We're on record 3. Okay. And which goes in the sequence of what? So we know we have 270 records, period, right?Jennifer Buckles: Yeah.Sheila Burleson: Okay, so that all makes sense. And so, if they pop up and it's a no match, we just move on, and they're gonna sit in there until or unless.Jennifer Buckles: Until you delete one of the duplicates.Sheila Burleson: Right. Now, here's another question, and this is where we got a little bit more clear on what the holdup was. So the process is not really the holdup. The process works exactly the way you said it did. And you just have to be aware of them. If we have one that pops up that has a potential, but it's not the one, and we put no match in the second street line, it still just kind of sits there until or unless another one pops up. So I think Jonathan's concern is with duplicate PITMs. They could just sit in there and build up and build up. What is the most efficient way for us to keep this from his team having to look at duplicate PITMs every day with the same people that have been reviewed? Is there any efficient way to kind of clear them out?Jennifer Buckles: Okay. PITMs is something completely different.Sheila Burleson: Is that not what we're looking at?Jennifer Buckles: No, this is duplicate ISIRs.Sheila Burleson: Okay, I'm sorry, duplicate ISIRs then.Jennifer Buckles: Yeah, so duplicate PITM is when you've created two different banner IDs for the same person, and that's an entirely different process. So this is just duplicate ISIRs, because Banner does not have the capability to match multiple ISIRs for the same person in the match process. It can only handle one at a time. And so, if there's more than one, it's gonna throw them in the duplicate, whether there's a match or not. It doesn't matter. So you're just reviewing the duplicate ISIRs for possible matches, because Banner won't match them up. Even if a match does exist, it won't match them up. So that's all you're doing, is reviewing for matches.And then, to keep them from getting annoying, the people who are doing this are like, "I've already looked at this person 12 times." You start looking at the same ones over and over again, they still don't have a match, it just kind of feels like you're spinning your wheels. That's when deleting the duplicates comes in handy, because that basically clears out your duplicates, and you don't have to continue to look at the same ones, because then you are only saving one transaction. And because it's one, it will no longer be in the duplicate category; it will either roll to hold or suspense until it has a match.Sheila Burleson: So, if we ran that custom job that would remove the duplicates, how is that job set up to know which record we would want?Jennifer Buckles: It only keeps the latest.Kenneth Kirksey: It just keeps the latest.Jonathan Ibarra: Yep.Sheila Burleson: Okay, so as the pile grows, we would want to, for this student, for example, that has two in there, we would want to look at both of those ISIRs and decide which one is the better of the keep. I mean, that's a lot of work, too. What do you guys do?Jennifer Buckles: Ours is different, because we create banner IDs. So if the person doesn't have a match, we would create an ID and match both ISIRs. So, our process is different. I would probably say keep the latest. To me, these students right now are not admitted, not applied; they don't have a banner ID right now, so they may never come to your school. So, I feel like going through all the work to try to figure out which transaction, which one do we want for somebody that may never even come, it's a lot of work for that.When, let's say you did the last one, and the last one had no SAI, but the one before it did, you can always go back and request the transaction before if you needed to, or have the student fix their ISIR. If they messed it up, they need to fix it. So, those are the options. It's not like you delete it, and now you can never get it back. So, I feel like the trade-off you get, where if you could just have a custom job, it's just gonna wipe them out, and you don't have to sit there and waste your brainpower in trying to figure out which one's the best decision. Just keep the latest one, and keep it rolling.Sheila Burleson: I like that. What do you guys think?Kenneth Kirksey: See, that's what I was thinking, because, of course, we want to try to get away from the custom jobs. But…Sheila Burleson: So, doing what Jen says is when we go through.Kenneth Kirksey: If we have a duplicate, we delete everything but the…Jennifer Buckles: Yeah. So, yeah, you can do that manually. You can do that every day if you wanted to, if you don't want to just let them sit there at all. Every time you review a duplicate, you're looking, there's no match, you've got transaction 1, transaction 2, you can delete transaction 1 and move on to the next student. Next time the match runs, it's going to put that transaction 2 either in hold or suspense.Sheila Burleson: If we were to do that, and we're looking at this person, Hesha Allen, and she has two transactions, and we want to keep 2. We're on number 1. Where would we delete it? Just delete record right there? And save? Right here? Thumbs up, right? So this is transaction 1.Jonathan Ibarra: Top right.Jennifer Buckles: Yeah, there's a delete at the top right. I'm not 100% sure. I would play with that in SITest and see, because I'm not 100% sure whether it's that checkbox. I don't think it's that checkbox.Sheila Burleson: At this point, with 270 records sitting in there, do we feel like we need to go through all 270 of those, Angie, Kim, to make the pile go down and then just start from there, or do we run a custom job, Kenneth, which I know goes against every fiber of your being?Kenneth Kirksey: Well, I don't mind running the custom job, but it's not gonna be there forever.Jonathan Ibarra: I think for right now, it would be most helpful to really…Sheila Burleson: If we got it cleaned up, and there were 30 records in there, that's way more manageable.Jonathan Ibarra: A lot more manageable. Then you could stay on top of it. Right, because right now, for 26-27, there's over a thousand records, and that was my concern of a constant review after review after review after review. And I don't want my team to be going through that, especially at a time where we do have other things that we're working on. I don't want that to be the one that's taken up a lot of time. So that's where my concern was coming in.Kenneth Kirksey: My vote is when you go through the duplicates, remove everything but the newest.Sheila Burleson: Yes, but we want you to run the job first.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah, run the job. We'll run the job first to clean the slate.Sheila Burleson: And then they will… And then as we go forward… And then they will clean as they review.Kenneth Kirksey: And speaking of review, do you want to know how many unsatisfied slate requirements there are out there? Hold down the road. 400. A lot of those people will never show up.Sheila Burleson: We battled that all year.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah, I had a question. On this one, in the first block, down at the bottom right, there's the 1 of 6. That's 1 of 6 what?Jennifer Buckles: Go to… click the arrow, go ahead.Sheila Burleson: Ashley Daniels, that's just one out of how many records there are.Jonathan Ibarra: Each page is gonna have about 50 records.Sheila Burleson: Watch. Yeah. This is record 1 of 270.Kenneth Kirksey: record 51 of 270.Jennifer Buckles: Yeah, it's because you've got your display set to 50 per page.Kenneth Kirksey: Okay, so…Sheila Burleson: Okay, that's just jumping through the list. Yes. Okay. It's not specific to the person you're on at all. It's just following records.Kenneth Kirksey: Gotcha. Okay.Jonathan Ibarra: So, can we make a game plan of just running that custom job, and then we can go through the ones that are sitting out there?Sheila Burleson: Excellent.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah, I'll go ahead and do that right after this meeting.Jonathan Ibarra: I was gonna say, Angie, we can schedule a meeting with Kim, and we'll go over each one of the records. But we could do one right now, just so that everybody kind of knows what we're looking at. Or, Sheila, you had one, I think it was record 12 that you ended up finding a potential match? An example, because I think the ones that we were going through just had no match, no match, no match, no match.Sheila Burleson: No, and we found one that had a potential match that also wasn't a match. You want to see that one?Jonathan Ibarra: Yeah, that way we can kind of…Sheila Burleson: I know the name, Chase Brown. Is there any way for me to get there quickly, Jen?Jonathan Ibarra: Just by putting the social on Zoom, but…Jennifer Buckles: social, I think, is the only one thing you can search by. They might be in alphabetical order. I don't know, maybe if you arrow down, see if you can get to B.Sheila Burleson: Alan.Jennifer Buckles: Yeah, they're in alphabetical order. too far.Sheila Burleson: There he is. Chase Brown. Went down two. Duplicate check. He has a potential, but it's not a match. So, someone… Oh, where did it go?Jonathan Ibarra: So, would this be the one where we would just do it similar with suspense, putting no match? Because this technically was reviewed, but there was no match.Sheila Burleson: Yeah, where did the no match go that was in there before when we looked at it?Kenneth Kirksey: It might be on the previous record.Sheila Burleson: Oh, did I double arrow? I bet I did. Yeah, that's the only downside, because there's two, so you'd have to put no match on both of them, I guess? Yeah, okay, there it is. I did double arrow, so there's the first one. And it was already reviewed no match, but it's also transaction 1. So since we got a transaction 2, we wanna put no match there, right?Jonathan Ibarra: They will delete. Yeah.Jennifer Buckles: Yeah, because since there is a potential match, likely that one would end up in suspense because of the potential match, rather than hold. And so you've already got the no match there, so you wouldn't have to necessarily review it again once it goes into suspense.Sheila Burleson: Tell me about hold.Jennifer Buckles: Hold is what you all do for people where there's nothing. You have no application, no nothing, no social, no name, nothing matches whatsoever. So you just hold onto them. They just go into a different status. It's not suspense, it's not duplicate, it's hold. So they're still there, they're still in the temp table, but they're just on hold. And then every single time the match runs, it re-looks at the whole list to say, is there a match now? If there is a potential match, but they can't exactly match it, it'll put it in suspense. If there's nothing whatsoever that matches, it stays in hold.Sheila Burleson: And do we clear that at the end of a year, or do they just sit there, or does it matter?Jennifer Buckles: I believe they sit there. I don't think you purge anything out.Sheila Burleson: That sounds like us. Okay.Jennifer Buckles: Yeah, some schools purge it out, like, all the records that they don't need.Kenneth Kirksey: I don't know if you could probably go back to prior years and see if there's…Jennifer Buckles: But I know you all didn't always do the hold, so there was one point where you were creating new IDs for everybody.Kenneth Kirksey: for everybody.Jennifer Buckles: Yeah, which ended up causing lots more headaches.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah, because I was on the registrar side of that.Jennifer Buckles: Hmm.Sheila Burleson: Fun with financial aid! So, does everybody feel okay about what we just learned and all that good stuff?Angie Daugherty: Yeah, it's a little clearer.Jonathan Ibarra: It's a little bit clearer. Angie, let's schedule a meeting with Kim whenever, with her availability, and then we'll go through it.Jennifer Buckles: Go into SITEST and play with the delete. I think it's the top delete is what you select, but maybe just double-check that, because I haven't done suspense in a while.Kenneth Kirksey: I think the most important thing to keep in mind is the duplicate is a separate process from the match. From matching. It will only match if you've got one ISIR. If you've got more than one ISIR, it's never going to match that. So, you have to figure out which ISIR you want to keep.Sheila Burleson: Gosh, none of our kids do more than one.Kenneth Kirksey: Now, while we're all here, and we got a couple of minutes, I want us to give us a final decision on that load button.Jonathan Ibarra: The what now?Kenneth Kirksey: Load button.Jonathan Ibarra: Oh.Kenneth Kirksey: Do we ever want to use that load button?Sheila Burleson: What is that?Angie Daugherty: It's on the instructions on payment. On page 7, and it's circled in red. It's after the thing that says, "If there are potential matches, you'll see them in the match results, and you will check the social security number, date of birth, and name to confirm the match. Select the ID as indicated above, and click save." And then the next screenshot has a screen, and it's got the load circled.Jennifer Buckles: So, here's the issue with why that's a question mark. What load is doing, so when you match something, you're just connecting this ISIR with this student, but nothing is actually attached in Renana. There's no record created in Renana. There's a job that has to run that creates that record, and that's when it stamps it with the ISIR was received on this date, and then that stamp date is the date that the data load process uses when it's picking up new ISIRs to track C flags and comment codes and all of that stuff.So if you load individually, and then for whatever reason, the ISIR process doesn't run tonight, the file didn't come in, something crazy happens with Automic, and it just doesn't run, that ISIR that you loaded today does not get run through all those processes to track the C flags, to track the whatever comment flags, whatever comment codes, whatever tracking codes are required. It misses all of that. Then tomorrow, when that process runs, it's picking up tomorrow's date. Well, if it got loaded today, it's never gonna get picked up. So, when you load, and then the ISIR process doesn't run, you could have a disconnect between your tracking elements.So what we did to remedy that is we have a special load that runs before the ISIR load goes. So, I would say, no, you do not want anybody running load because of the potential for it not to get tracking updated. Maybe you just need to update the directions.The advantage of being able to do load when you're doing duplicates is you can only—so when you run the match, it's gonna then put both duplicates back in duplicate unless one is loaded. So, if you got to your two duplicates, and let's say you found a match, you can only match one at a time, you can't match both of them. So you match one, that one has to load, then when the match runs again, it'll match the other one automatically, because now it's the only one out there. But that's gonna take the night of it running in order for the second one to actually be able to load.So let me just talk through that. You have a duplicate that has a match. You match the first one, you just match it, you don't load it, you just match it. Move on to all the rest of your duplicates. Tonight, when the data load runs, the first job that runs is a load job, so it picks up that match you already did and loads it. Then it goes through the whole ISIR process, which is look for new matches, then it'll match the second one, and load those. So it'll load both of them tonight. Then the newest one will get run through all the tracking and all of that, but both would be matched tonight. But you'd have to wait for tonight, so that other one is still going to be hanging out there in your duplicate list until the ISIR process runs tonight. So the only advantage of being able to load on demand is that you could load it, rerun the match, go ahead and match the second one and load it right then. But, if the ISIR process doesn't run tonight, you've just missed all the tracking. So, I feel like the advantage of having it loaded right now versus the risk of missing tracking updates, I feel like it would be better to do that.Now, there may be a case when you've got an urgent, "we've got to get this thing loaded, we know what the comment codes are," and so maybe special people, like you all, would have that option, to where you could load it if you had to, but you know the implications of, "if I'm loading this, I need to make sure all the tracking's updated, just in case something happens with the data load tonight." But I think the more people you have doing that, the more risk of it missing the tracking and the data load.Sheila Burleson: So, no load. No load. Special circumstance only.Kenneth Kirksey: Jonathan's in charge. In special circumstance only, there should be one person that could do it.Jennifer Buckles: Yep. And then that person understands, "I'm loading, so I need to make sure tracking is getting updated. I know exactly what should be tracked, and all of that, just in case."Jonathan Ibarra: Okay.Sheila Burleson: We can designate.Jonathan Ibarra: He could put me as the designate to make that call.Kenneth Kirksey: Okay.Kenneth Kirksey: So if somebody does the manual load, then they need to make sure… because it does the tracking group, packaging groups, budget group.Sheila Burleson: Would those all be manual then, as well, or…Jennifer Buckles: Yes. I would say this is what they would have to do. They would have to run a tracking group, and then add any tracking codes for comment codes that exist. So those were the things. Budget groups are constantly rerun until the student is packaged, so that's not a problem. That isn't based on dates, and packaging groups are rerun until the student is packaged. So those two would get picked up the following day, but tracking groups and tracking codes would not.Jonathan Ibarra: Unless a new ISIR came in, then it'll pick them up.Sheila Burleson: Manual load, manual tracking.Kenneth Kirksey: And while we're all here, I got another question. We had a situation, Jen, where students, when we ran estimated awards in December, they currently show up as an in-state student, but their tuition and fees was the out-of-state rate. And I'm not sure what happened there. They may have been out of state at the time, and then got changed to in-state.Jennifer Buckles: If you re-budget them at that point, like, so at the point where you say, okay, this is an in-state student with out of state, if you re-budget them, does it update their budget?Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah, I ran RBRPRC, and it...Jennifer Buckles: Okay, so yeah, that was it. When they got their budget added, they were out of state, and then at some point changed to in-state.Sheila Burleson: Just a timing issue.Kenneth Kirksey: So that's just a… we need to run that report regularly.Jennifer Buckles: Run a report. They would get automatically rebudgeted at the start of the term, but if you're trying to catch them earlier rather than later, then if you have a report, that would catch.Sheila Burleson: Well, what's interesting is the parents and the students are squawking, and it's like, we haven't finally packaged you yet, so just simmer down now, but we've had an unusual amount.Jennifer Buckles: They can see their cost of attendance?Sheila Burleson: Yes, and they don't understand that it's a cost of attendance, and what we don't want is DISPREVs that would be created. There were 131 in that load, and he updated the PBR, BBC, and all the budgets were updated correctly.Jennifer Buckles: Good. Yeah, so it's just a timing thing then.Kenneth Kirksey: Okay. I'm alright. We're good?Jonathan Ibarra: Yep.Kenneth Kirksey: We're good. And I've recorded this, I will save it, put it on the drive, and send y'all a link.Jonathan Ibarra: Thank you.Sheila Burleson: Thanks for clarification. I like when you walk things through, it makes it easier to understand.Jennifer Buckles: No problem.Kenneth Kirksey: Okay. Good to see you.Jennifer Buckles: You too! Bye.Kenneth Kirksey: Thanks, see y'all.

item.description:
Appalachian State UniversityInterim StaffingPrepared For:Alison Rabil, Associate Vice Chancellor of Enrollment Management and Chief Financial Aid OfficerKenneth Kirksey, Associate DirectorWeekly Report Period1/18/26-1/24/26Prepared byJennifer Buckles, Independent ConsultantWork Performed: Meetings Minimum hour questions SAP A150/D150Review SAP A15/D150 Testing and review. Completed the set up in SITest and ran students that were assigned to D150 in the last SAP evaluation through the new rules. LeeAnn and I reviewed the ones that changed from D150 to something other than A150. We identified a few issues with the rules. I updated the rules to use SORLCUR instead of SGBSTDN. I added a case statement to use a default number for the program hours based on level if SWBCIPC is null. Level U- default value is 120 Level G or G2- default value is 36 Level P or D- default value is 60 A150SELECT J0.SORLCUR_PIDMFROM ( SELECTO.SORLCUR_PIDM,O.SORLCUR_LEVL_CODE,O.SORLCUR_PROGRAMFROM SORLCUR OWHERE O.SORLCUR_PIDM = :PIDMAND O.SORLCUR_LMOD_CODE = 'LEARNER'AND O.SORLCUR_PRIORITY_NO = 1AND O.SORLCUR_CURRENT_CDE = 'Y'AND O.SORLCUR_TERM_CODE = (SELECT MAX(I.SORLCUR_TERM_CODE)FROM SORLCUR IWHERE I.SORLCUR_PIDM = O.SORLCUR_PIDMAND I.SORLCUR_LMOD_CODE = 'LEARNER'AND I.SORLCUR_PRIORITY_NO = 1AND I.SORLCUR_CACT_CODE = 'ACTIVE'AND I.SORLCUR_CURRENT_CDE = 'Y'AND I.SORLCUR_TERM_CODE <= '20'||SUBSTR(:AIDY , 3,2)||'10' )) J0INNER JOIN (SELECT SHRLGPA_PIDM, SHRLGPA_LEVL_CODE, SHRLGPA_HOURS_ATTEMPTED AS HOURS_ATTEMPTEDFROM SHRLGPAWHERE SHRLGPA_GPA_TYPE_IND = 'O') J1ON J1.SHRLGPA_PIDM = J0.SORLCUR_PIDMAND J1.SHRLGPA_LEVL_CODE = J0.SORLCUR_LEVL_CODELEFT JOIN (SELECT SHRLGPA_PIDM, SHRLGPA_LEVL_CODE, SHRLGPA_HOURS_EARNED AS HOURS_EARNEDFROM SHRLGPAWHERE SHRLGPA_GPA_TYPE_IND = 'T') J2ON J2.SHRLGPA_PIDM = J0.SORLCUR_PIDMAND J2.SHRLGPA_LEVL_CODE = J0.SORLCUR_LEVL_CODEINNER JOIN SWBCIPC J3ON J3.SWBCIPC_PROGRAM = J0.SORLCUR_PROGRAMWHERE ( NVL(J1.HOURS_ATTEMPTED,0) + NVL(J2.HOURS_EARNED,0) ) >= 1.25 *(CASEWHEN J3.SWBCIPC_CREDENTIAL_CRED_HOURS IS NOT NULL THEN J3.SWBCIPC_CREDENTIAL_CRED_HOURSWHEN J0.SORLCUR_LEVL_CODE = 'U' THEN 120WHEN J0.SORLCUR_LEVL_CODE IN ('G','G2') THEN 36WHEN J0.SORLCUR_LEVL_CODE IN ('P','D') THEN 60END)AND J0.SORLCUR_PIDM = :PIDMD150SELECT J0.SORLCUR_PIDMFROM (SELECTO.SORLCUR_PIDM,O.SORLCUR_LEVL_CODE,O.SORLCUR_PROGRAMFROM SORLCUR OWHERE O.SORLCUR_PIDM = :PIDMAND O.SORLCUR_LMOD_CODE = 'LEARNER'AND O.SORLCUR_PRIORITY_NO = 1AND O.SORLCUR_CURRENT_CDE = 'Y'AND O.SORLCUR_TERM_CODE = (SELECT MAX(I.SORLCUR_TERM_CODE)FROM SORLCUR IWHERE I.SORLCUR_PIDM = O.SORLCUR_PIDMAND I.SORLCUR_LMOD_CODE = 'LEARNER'AND I.SORLCUR_PRIORITY_NO = 1AND I.SORLCUR_CACT_CODE = 'ACTIVE'AND I.SORLCUR_CURRENT_CDE = 'Y'AND I.SORLCUR_TERM_CODE <= '20'||SUBSTR(:AIDY , 3,2)||'10' )) J0INNER JOIN (SELECT SHRLGPA_PIDM, SHRLGPA_LEVL_CODE, SHRLGPA_HOURS_ATTEMPTED AS HOURS_ATTEMPTEDFROM SHRLGPAWHERE SHRLGPA_GPA_TYPE_IND = 'O') J1ON J1.SHRLGPA_PIDM = J0.SORLCUR_PIDMAND J1.SHRLGPA_LEVL_CODE = J0.SORLCUR_LEVL_CODELEFT JOIN (SELECT SHRLGPA_PIDM, SHRLGPA_LEVL_CODE, SHRLGPA_HOURS_EARNED AS HOURS_EARNEDFROM SHRLGPAWHERE SHRLGPA_GPA_TYPE_IND = 'T') J2ON J2.SHRLGPA_PIDM = J0.SORLCUR_PIDMAND J2.SHRLGPA_LEVL_CODE = J0.SORLCUR_LEVL_CODEINNER JOIN SWBCIPC J3ON J3.SWBCIPC_PROGRAM = J0.SORLCUR_PROGRAMWHERE ( NVL(J1.HOURS_ATTEMPTED,0) + NVL(J2.HOURS_EARNED,0) ) >= 1.4 *(CASEWHEN J3.SWBCIPC_CREDENTIAL_CRED_HOURS IS NOT NULL THEN J3.SWBCIPC_CREDENTIAL_CRED_HOURSWHEN J0.SORLCUR_LEVL_CODE = 'U' THEN 120WHEN J0.SORLCUR_LEVL_CODE IN ('G','G2') THEN 36WHEN J0.SORLCUR_LEVL_CODE IN ('P','D') THEN 60END)AND J0.SORLCUR_PIDM = :PIDM Reviewed AASS rule- LeeAnn reported the AASS rule was a duplicate of the AAS rule. item.title: 2026-01-09 - Scholarship Universe Weekly Update
item.description: Happy Friday! Scholarship Universe is plugging right along. We are discussing review set up with Lauren now and beginning the process of structuring committees in-system. I am combining SU resources with our internal review processes for committee reference. We will be working on the award report that brings scholarship award information from SU into Banner. We've emphasized our need to start this sooner rather than later so that any IT jobs that need Tena's team's assistance can be scheduled accordingly.We briefly reviewed the award report this week, and I feel confident that a script can be written to manage the status of thank-you note requirements in RRAAREQ. We are beginning admin training sessions with college scholarship managers next week. I will be a part of training and documentation this year with the goal of the Scholarship Office managing that aspect in future cycles.Ellucian has resolved the matching problem (🙌) that was causing all questions to be shown to all students regardless of major. They had made an update to the way their system managed SIS data earlier in the year and did not catch this glitch until we brought it up to them. Happy to have that behind us as we move into the spring term.I spoke with a student this week who had difficulty completing her application due to SU compatibility with screen readers. I've escalated the inquiry to Lauren's team and spoken with ODR about any other accessibility issues. I have documentation (attached) from Ellucian confirming the accessibility features of the platform if we ever need it. The student is scheduling time with a FA counselor and I'll be on call to assist as needed with that meeting.Additional announcements via email and social media will go out to students next week when they return for classes. We are a little bit behind last year's numbers (983 vs 1076) but we will monitor as students return and look at utilizing SU's communication features to target populations that have yet to apply. Let me know if you have any ques
item.guid: Finacial Aid Tech Notes/2026-01-09 - Scholarship Universe Weekly Update.md

item.title: 2026-01-18 - DSBREVS being set again after they're cleared
item.description:
From: LeeAnn Barnes To: me, Jennifer Date: Fri, Jan 16, 12:33 PMAny ideas what is causing these to keep popping back on after she clears them?From: Cassi de la Cerda delacerdacl@appstate.edu
To: LeeAnn Barnes barnesla2@appstate.edu Date: Fri, Jan 16, 2026 at 11:43 AMGood Morning LeeAnn,I was wondering if you could help me with these athletes. They keep switching back into (R) overnight and I have put them in (F) 3 days in a row now, it's getting frustrating especially since no new aid has been added. I am attaching a list of my work for 3 days (I got busy) and was not able to send you this until now despite it being from last week. Some may not be repeated but the vast majority of them you will see, are. I would appreciate any help you can give me with this?Thank you in advance!From: Jennifer Buckles To: LeeAnn, me Date: Fri, Jan 16, 1:15 PMHere’s the problem. Award notices don’t get sent unless the student is packaged. If the award notice isn’t sent, the award letter flag on RPAAWRD stays flagged. So to the DSBREV process they look like they’ve had an award change every day. For students who aren’t packaged but are being flagged as DSBREV, you can uncheck the award letter flag on RPAAWRD after review. If there is a real award change the award flag will be re-triggered and they will be marked as DSBREV again.From: LeeAnn Barnes To: Jennifer, me Date: Fri, Jan 16, 1:21 PMThank you so much! I will advise her to uncheck that flag. Glad you got your access back.
item.guid: Finacial Aid Tech Notes/2026-01-18 - DSBREVS being set again after they're cleared.md

item.title: 2025-12-19 - SAP Notes for Spring 2026 - LeeAnn Barnes
item.description: Just wanted to give you an update on SAP for spring and remind you of how things will look.  If you have any questions please let me know. SAP appeals have been added to students who were on an approved appeal/probationary term for fall 2025 (AAF) but failed to earn at least 75% of all attempted hours.  There were 95 students who failed to meet these requirements. Below is what you will now see for these students: RRAAREQ - SAP "R" as of 12/18/25 ROASTAT - Eligibility status tab will have 202610 with one of the following status':  MAU, MAG, D150 STUDENT FORMS - the student will have a SAP appeal requirement and the tracking status of that appeal will be "SAP 2".  This means the student was approved  but failed and now needs to appeal again for a subsequent term for the aid year. What do these students need to provide for their appeal? Regardless of their SAP status of MAU, MAG or D150 - these students need to explain the reasons why they did not earn 75% for fall and must provide documentation that supports those reasons.  If they are D150, they will need to provide more than an academic plan or copy of degreeworks.   They already provided that for their previous appeal.  This time they are appealing for not meeting the probationary requirements. What if a F grade or an incomplete grade gets updated to a passing grade? If a student says they had a F grade or an incomplete update to a passing grade, then let me know and we will review to see if their status should change and if they still need to appeal. Students on an AAF status for fall who were not enrolled remain eligible for spring term and their status will be updated to AAS in ROASTAT. Students on an AAF status for fall and earned at least 75%, BUT are not meeting OVERALL SAP standards will remain eligible for spring and their status will be updated to AAS in ROASTAT. Students on an AAF status for fall and earned at least 75%, AND are meeting OVERALL SAP standards will remain eligible for spring and their status will be updated to AU or AG in ROASTAT. Students on NEW, AU or AG for fall, regardless of their fall grades (even if they failed everything), their status will remain the same.  No new status will be added to ROASTAT.  We do not evaluate these students until the ANNUAL process at the end of spring term. Students on MAU or MAG who were enrolled in Fall; regardless if their fall grades improve their overall SAP status, their SAP will not be evaluated again until the ANNUAL process at the end of spring term so if they want to be considered for spring eligibility, they may appeal. Students on D150 will also need to to appeal for to be considered for spring eligibility. I hope everyone has a wonderful break and spends lots of time with the ones you love!Thanks,LeeAnn
item.guid: Finacial Aid Tech Notes/2025-12-19 - SAP Notes for Spring 2026 - LeeAnn Barnes.md

item.title: 2025-11-08 - Blue Icon Weekly Report to App State University-Interim Staffing 11-8-25
item.description:
Appalachian State UniversityInterim StaffingPrepared For:Alison Rabil, Associate Vice Chancellor of Enrollment Management and Chief Financial Aid OfficerKenneth Kirksey, Associate DirectorWeekly Report Period11/2/25-11/8/25Prepared byJennifer Buckles, Independent ConsultantWork Performed:1. Planning


-- CURRENT VS PREVIOUS SAI CHANGE SELECT R1.RCRAPP1_PIDM FROM RCRAPP1 R1 JOIN RORSTAT RS ON RS.RORSTAT_PIDM = R1.RCRAPP1_PIDM AND RS.RORSTAT_AIDY_CODE = R1.RCRAPP1_AIDY_CODE WHERE R1.RCRAPP1_CREATE_DATE > RS.RORSTAT_PCKG_COMP_DATE AND R1.RCRAPP1_CURR_REC_IND = 'Y' AND R1.RCRAPP1_AIDY_CODE = :AIDY AND R1.RCRAPP1_PIDM = :PIDM AND NOT EXISTS ( /* FIND A MATCH WHERE CURRENT SAI = PREVIOUS SAI FOR THIS EXACT CURRENT RECORD. IF SUCH A MATCH EXISTS, WE EXCLUDE THE PIDM; OTHERWISE WE RETURN IT. */ SELECT 1 FROM ( /* CURRENT SAI FOR THE EXACT CURRENT RCRAPP1 ROW */ SELECT A.RCRAPP2_PELL_PGI AS CURRENT_SAI FROM RCRAPP2 A WHERE A.RCRAPP2_PIDM = R1.RCRAPP1_PIDM AND A.RCRAPP2_AIDY_CODE = R1.RCRAPP1_AIDY_CODE AND A.RCRAPP2_INFC_CODE = R1.RCRAPP1_INFC_CODE AND A.RCRAPP2_SEQ_NO = R1.RCRAPP1_SEQ_NO ) CUR JOIN ( /* PREVIOUS SAI ON THE MOST RECENT NON-CURRENT RCRAPP1 ROW */ SELECT C.RCRAPP2_PELL_PGI AS PREVIOUS_SAI FROM RCRAPP2 C JOIN RCRAPP1 D ON D.RCRAPP1_PIDM = C.RCRAPP2_PIDM AND D.RCRAPP1_AIDY_CODE = C.RCRAPP2_AIDY_CODE AND D.RCRAPP1_INFC_CODE = C.RCRAPP2_INFC_CODE AND D.RCRAPP1_SEQ_NO = C.RCRAPP2_SEQ_NO WHERE D.RCRAPP1_PIDM = R1.RCRAPP1_PIDM AND D.RCRAPP1_AIDY_CODE = R1.RCRAPP1_AIDY_CODE AND D.RCRAPP1_INFC_CODE = R1.RCRAPP1_INFC_CODE AND D.RCRAPP1_CURR_REC_IND = 'N' AND D.RCRAPP1_SEQ_NO = ( SELECT MAX(N.RCRAPP1_SEQ_NO) FROM RCRAPP1 N WHERE N.RCRAPP1_PIDM = R1.RCRAPP1_PIDM AND N.RCRAPP1_AIDY_CODE = R1.RCRAPP1_AIDY_CODE AND N.RCRAPP1_INFC_CODE = R1.RCRAPP1_INFC_CODE AND N.RCRAPP1_CURR_REC_IND = 'N' ) ) PREV ON ( PREV.PREVIOUS_SAI = CUR.CURRENT_SAI OR ( PREV.PREVIOUS_SAI IS NULL AND CUR.CURRENT_SAI IS NULL ) ) )




Update RPROPTS to allow packaging and disbursement if cflag exists.

Reviewed the FSA list of comment code that trigger a cflag and confirmed that each one is assigned a tracking code in the ISIR load RORPOST App State is still reviewing to make a determination about what status the recurring cflag needs to be set to.

As expected most of them were placed in the DEFALT group. This will allow them to get picked up by the DSBREV process.

Set up two schedules for 2526 and 2627 to run weekly. Schedules are currently inactive pending App State review and finalization of frequency/timing.
The following jobs need to be added to Automic so that I can create the chains to set up the process flows when TD Client is fully automated: RERORIG, REREX5c, RERIM5c, RERGRIM, RERGRNT, RLRDLIM, RLRDLRC, RNRTMNI App State to review and activate Entrance counseling jobs in the2526 and 2627 Dataload chains App State to update reports to no longer pull the RNARS cflag (RCRAPP2_ELIGIBILITY_MSG) but just by the tracking codes App State to add jobs to Automic to complete TDClient chains Create Pell Reconciliation Documentation Create Packaging Review Documentation Continue working to create Automic chains for the Banner portions of the chains that can be automated when TDClient is set up on Automic Import of COD files Export CRAA file Pell Reconciliation DL Reconciliation Export Transfer Monitoring Import Transfer Monitoring Create a budget rule for licensure expenses Create a budget rule for freshman tuition

I don't anticipate any changes to how we are doing it right now, but we are moving to a new dynamic form format in the spring. If these dates change, I will let you know.Thanks again,JayneHi Jane,I'm working on setting up for our 2627 aid year and have a couple of questions about the intent to not return dates. If the form closes at 11:59 pm on Aug 29, for instance, how quickly will those forms be processed and the INTR entered in Banner? I just want to make sure we don't stop processing INTRs before y'all get them all entered.We should have those processed within within 48 hours typically. Do you have the INTR form open and close dates for the 2627 academic year yet? Thanks! For 26-27 academic year, the open/close dates for INTENT formsAll Campus and Student Types except Flight PathFall 2026 - Opens midnight March 24, 2026 / Closesat 11:59on August 16, 2026Spring 2027 - Opens midnight on October 22, 2026 / Closes at 11:59 on January 10, 2027Summer I 2027 -Opens midnight March 23, 2027 / Closesat 11:59on May 23, 2027Summer II 2027 -Opens midnight March 23, 2027 / Closes at 11:59on July 5, 2027F light PathFall 1 2026 - Opens midnight on March 22, 2026 / Closes at 11:59 on August 16, 2026Fall 2 2026 - Opens midnight on August 17, 2026 / Closes at 11:59 on October 13, 2026Spring 1 2027 - Opens midnight on November 13, 2026 / Closes at 11:59 on January 10, 2027Spring 2 2027 - Opens midnight on February 8, 2027 / Closes at 11:59 on March 14, 2027Summer 2027 - Opens midnight on April 12, 2027 / Closes at 11:59 on May 23, 2027

item.title: 2025-12-09 - Meeting - PKH Disbursement Dates and Memos - Transcript
item.description: LeeAnn Barnes: Can you hear me?Kenneth Kirksey: Yep.LeeAnn Barnes: I don't know who's in charge of setting the memo dates, but we've always used the drop/add date, just from looking at the history.Jennifer Buckles: So, do you know if student accounts is driving that date? Because they need those memos removed so people can pay their balances.LeeAnn Barnes: Probably.Jennifer Buckles: You can only pick one memo date. So for PKH, if we pick the early date, that means their Part of Term 2 items will stop memoing.LeeAnn Barnes: It looks like what we did last year for PKH is we set the KO2 date.Jennifer Buckles: Right, the second one. But that also means if any K01 disbursements haven't dispersed, they'll continue to memo throughout that time until you hit that second date. I wasn't sure if that causes problems somewhere if that aid continues to memo after the August date.LeeAnn Barnes: I don't know.Kenneth Kirksey: Is that an Adam question?LeeAnn Barnes: As far as why we don't want it to memo?Jennifer Buckles: Well, I guess if that's what you did this past year, we would have already known if it caused problems.LeeAnn Barnes: And what we did this year was we paid students who were enrolled in K01 and K02 upfront, so they should have already been paid.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah, see, that's the difference. We're doing two different disbursements this year.LeeAnn Barnes: No, they're getting paid—unless they were… I don't know, I'm confusing myself.Jennifer Buckles: Did it change to only one disbursement?LeeAnn Barnes: It's one disbursement.Jennifer Buckles: And that's why we did the plus-minus dates. So that if they start in Part of Term 2, they'll get it scheduled with Part of Term 2. But if they're in one or both, they'll get it all at once.LeeAnn Barnes: Yes.Jennifer Buckles: Okay, so we don't need two disbursement dates anymore. But you do still need a memo date that accommodates that second part of term.LeeAnn Barnes: Yes, that's what I was talking about. When you mentioned the disbursement thing, I was talking about the memo date.Kenneth Kirksey: Okay, so let me go back. Let me pull up my Rorsair. Here's what I set up for Rorsair, because my notes said to set it for the KO1 and KO2 disbursements.Jennifer Buckles: From that meeting we had... Okay, Rorsair is your loan periods. This is just for loans.LeeAnn Barnes: And that would be correct, right?Jennifer Buckles: No.LeeAnn Barnes: No.Jennifer Buckles: I don't think you're splitting them anymore. I think you're just doing one fall disbursement, one spring disbursement, and one summer disbursement. You're handling the people who start later with the plus-minus days so that they don't get their stuff early. You were trying to handle that manually by splitting the disbursements, but it caused problems because they get the bill all upfront, then their disbursements are split, and they're not getting their refunds or all their funds. So since you're billing for all upfront, you were just going to pay all at the same time, as long as they had already started classes, which the plus-minus days will control.LeeAnn Barnes: Yes. It's coming back to me now. Thank you.Kenneth Kirksey: So, for Rorsair, what disbursement dates do we need then?Jennifer Buckles: They should match RFRDFA. Do you have RFRDFA set up for PKH?Kenneth Kirksey: No, I was waiting for us to settle on what the memo expiration date needed to be.Jennifer Buckles: I thought we already did this on 25-26, where we changed it to one disbursement for PKH.Kenneth Kirksey: Yes.Jennifer Buckles: Okay, so we definitely will not be going back to two for 26-27.LeeAnn Barnes: Yeah, let's look at 25-26.Kenneth Kirksey: Okay, so here's 25-26. And that was the day after the K02 drop/add.LeeAnn Barnes: That's the memo expiration date, so that should be the drop/add date for KO2.Jennifer Buckles: Yeah. So I think that's what you'd want to do, just like that. That way, if they are a KO2 start, they don't lose their memo too early. Because if you use the August date and they're a KO2 start, they won't have their disbursement yet, and their memo goes away for a couple of months, so it looks like they owe the balance.LeeAnn Barnes: Right.Jennifer Buckles: So yeah, I think the 26-27 version of this is what you want to do.Kenneth Kirksey: Okay.LeeAnn Barnes: And then those disbursement dates would be down below.Jennifer Buckles: Yeah, so you'd have your August, your January, your May, and then you just have your plus-minus, or your minus 10 dates.Kenneth Kirksey: For the PKH, we did say the minus 10. But you do have to enter a disbursement date.Jennifer Buckles: Yes, it has to have a date. If they're not registered, it can't calculate the minus 10, so that disbursement date there becomes the default. So if a disbursement record gets created before they register, it will date it with that. It's not going to disburse because they're not enrolled, but it has to have a date to create that record on either RAP Award or Reladlor.Kenneth Kirksey: Okay, so for PKH RFRDFA 25-26... let me look at Rorsair 25-26. Okay, so our disbursement dates were... see, that's where things are confusing me. We only had a single disbursement date for PKH in fall 2025; it was 8/22. But for 26-27, we have a fall disbursement and then a fall two disbursement.Jennifer Buckles: Right, but that's what the minus 10 is going to do. It's only for the people who are only Part of Term 2, not the people who are in both.Kenneth Kirksey: Okay, so how do we...Jennifer Buckles: I think this year you're accomplishing that with ROA holds. You're putting holds on people in Part of Term 2 who are not enrolled. This past fall, what happened was at drop/add or minimum hours, all their aid got canceled because they weren't enrolled. But then we realized they were PKH, and they still could enroll. So the new plan for spring was, at minimum hours, if they're not enrolled but they're PKH, you're not going to cancel them, but you're going to put an ROA hold on them that will expire with the PKH Part of Term 2 disbursement date.Kenneth Kirksey: So, for 26-27, do we just do the same thing in Rorsair, except add the minus 10 for all the terms?Jennifer Buckles: Correct.Kenneth Kirksey: So it'll look like this, with the right disbursement dates. But there are two PKH disbursement dates. The 2025-40…Jennifer Buckles: The first one. You put the first one as the default, and then the minus 10 will adjust the ones that don't fit that one. As long as that first one lines up with minus 10 from the PKH date. That's the other thing I wasn't 100% sure about. That date that's listed there, is that minus 10 from the start date of PKH? No, it's not. It's plus 3.LeeAnn Barnes: I'm lost.Jennifer Buckles: The first day of classes is the 17th. PKH disbursement is the 20th. But we were talking about minus 10, meaning schedule it 10 days before the start of their classes.Kenneth Kirksey: Right.Jennifer Buckles: So you need to clarify which one that is. Do we want them dispersing 10 days before they start or three days after? I do remember a discussion about the three days after.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah, and I remember us going back and forth and talking about it.Jennifer Buckles: What day of the week that would be, and all of this, but I don't remember what was settled.LeeAnn Barnes: I can't remember either.Jennifer Buckles: So if this document is the bible here where you need to follow these dates, then you need to use plus 3 instead of minus 10. And the plus 3 would apply for that second one too. Because if they don't start till 10/14, it would automatically schedule them for 10/17. So it's the same for both, which is good. If it's not the same for both, you have to pick a number because it will do the same for both.LeeAnn Barnes: So, go back to that RFRDFA screen or the Rorsair screen. I just want to make sure I understand. Where it says disbursement date, you would put the first day of the class, and then put minus...?Jennifer Buckles: No, you would put the first disbursement date.LeeAnn Barnes: Okay.Jennifer Buckles: So that date is only used when they're not enrolled because it has to have a date. It's a placeholder. Then, once they're enrolled, it will automatically add or minus the days from their first start of class.LeeAnn Barnes: Okay, that makes sense.Jennifer Buckles: So if you put 8/22 there, and then you're telling it plus 3, it would schedule everybody to 8/22 until they register. When they register and start classes on 8/17, it'll add 3 and reschedule to that new date. Normally, I like to make the first date match that first disbursement. So if I'm going to be doing 8/20, I would put 8/20 in as the default date and then plus 3 for my calculation. That way, the majority of students don't even need to be rescheduled. Their default date will be the correct date. It's just the ones that are KO2 starts that will need to be rescheduled. If you do a random date and everybody has to be rescheduled, I feel like that's just more chances that something doesn't get rescheduled in time or gets dispersed on the wrong date.LeeAnn Barnes: Makes sense.Kenneth Kirksey: So, question is, did we land on minus 10 or plus 3? Let me see.Jennifer Buckles: Do you have the transcript from that meeting?LeeAnn Barnes: I don't remember.Kenneth Kirksey: Okay, this one says minus 10, and that was on September 30th.Jennifer Buckles: Who creates that calendar document that you have with all those dates on it?LeeAnn Barnes: It's based on the academic calendar that's posted by student accounts. It's on the website.Jennifer Buckles: So that PKH disbursement date is public?LeeAnn Barnes: No, that's not on there. Our office comes up with the disbursement date.Kenneth Kirksey: Okay, now here's the meeting from October 22nd, and it says plus 3.Jennifer Buckles: Who's going to make the call?LeeAnn Barnes: I'm thinking it's the plus 3. I think that's what it should be. I think that's an Allison call, for sure, but I'm pretty positive that's the way she wanted it set up from the get-go.Kenneth Kirksey: And then Jen, you said it's a good practice to make the hard-coded disbursement date the same as that plus 3 date.Jennifer Buckles: For the first disbursement, yes. So for 26-27, I believe that was 8/20. So 8/20 would be your date, and then plus 3. Classes start on the 17th, so it should schedule everybody to the 20th.Kenneth Kirksey: So for Rorsair, our first day of class fall disbursement is 8/20, so yeah, that's the plus 3. What would our KO2 disbursement date be?Jennifer Buckles: You don't put one in Rorsair.Kenneth Kirksey: Okay.Jennifer Buckles: So your KO2 people, until they register, their disbursements are going to be scheduled for 8/20 because it's going to use that default date. As soon as they register and Banner sees their first start date is 10/14, it will then reschedule their disbursements to 10/17.Kenneth Kirksey: I got it. So, same thing in RFRDFA?Jennifer Buckles: Correct.Kenneth Kirksey: We only put the disbursement date for the first one. And then once they register, it will see they started on the 14th, so we'll disperse on the 17th.Jennifer Buckles: Correct. But that should be 2026, right? Not 27.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah. Okay. I think I've got it now. This is not complicated at all.LeeAnn Barnes: They don't spell it out anywhere, really.Kenneth Kirksey: PKH is the bane of my existence.LeeAnn Barnes: Yeah, I think it's the bane of all of us.Kenneth Kirksey: I'm not sure which is worse, though, PKH or Summer.Jennifer Buckles: I'd take PKH over summer any day, especially the way you guys do summer.LeeAnn Barnes: Yes.Kenneth Kirksey: Okay, well... Oh, I found out—LeeAnn and I were sitting here watching the deer today, and I found out why I have deer come up here behind my office so much. There's either a guy or a lady in this house right behind my office that is bringing them corn and spreading it out on the driveway. There were like three deer up there, and I saw this person walking toward them, and they didn't run away.LeeAnn Barnes: That's funny.Kenneth Kirksey: Okay, well, thank y'all very much. I will fix this. This isn't going to happen today, so I'll just have to run it tomorrow sometime.Jennifer Buckles: Yep.LeeAnn Barnes: Alright.Kenneth Kirksey: Alright, thank you, y'all.LeeAnn Barnes: Alright, bye.Kenneth Kirksey: See you later. Bye.

item.title: 2025-12-09 - Meeting - PKH Disbursement Dates and Memos - Summary
item.description: LeeAnn Barnes Kenneth Kirksey Jennifer Buckles PKH Memo Date Configuration: Determining the appropriate expiration date for financial aid memos to accommodate students starting in different parts of the term (Part of Term 1 vs. Part of Term 2/KO2). Disbursement Strategy: Moving from split disbursements to a single disbursement model using "plus/minus" day logic to control the release of funds based on student start dates. System Setup (Rorsair & RFRDFA): Configuration of loan periods and fund disbursement rules for the 2026-2027 academic year. Calculation Logic: Deciding between a "Minus 10 days" or "Plus 3 days" rule for scheduling disbursements relative to class start dates. Who is responsible for setting memo dates? (LeeAnn Barnes) Student Accounts likely drives this date because they need memos removed to process balance payments. (Jennifer Buckles) Do we need two separate disbursement dates for PKH in the system? (Kenneth Kirksey) No. The process has changed to a single disbursement per term (Fall, Spring, Summer). The specific timing for students starting later (Part of Term 2) is handled via "plus/minus" date logic rather than manual split disbursements. (Jennifer Buckles) What should be entered as the default disbursement date in Rorsair and RFRDFA? (Kenneth Kirksey) Enter the date of the first disbursement (e.g., 8/20/26). This serves as a placeholder until the student registers; once registered, the system calculates the actual date based on the start of classes. (Jennifer Buckles) Did the team settle on "Minus 10" or "Plus 3" days for the disbursement calculation? (Kenneth Kirksey) The team agreed on Plus 3 (disbursing 3 days after the start of class). This aligns with Allison's preference and previous meeting notes from October 22nd. (LeeAnn Barnes & Jennifer Buckles) How should RFRDFA be set up for Part of Term 2 (KO2) starts? (Kenneth Kirksey) Do not enter a specific second date. The default date (Part of Term 1 date) will apply initially. When the system detects a KO2 start date (e.g., 10/14), the "Plus 3" logic will automatically reschedule the disbursement to the correct date (e.g., 10/17). (Jennifer Buckles) Memo Expiration Date: For the 2026-2027 year, the memo expiration date will be set to the drop/add date of the second part of the term (KO2). This prevents memos from expiring too early for students who start later in the semester. Disbursement Logic: The disbursement calculation rule is officially set to "Plus 3" (3 days after the start of classes). Default Date Configuration: In Rorsair and RFRDFA, the hard-coded default disbursement date will match the first disbursement date of the term (e.g., 8/20 for Fall 2026). Single Disbursement Model: The team confirmed they are not returning to a split disbursement model for 2026-2027; they will rely on the system's calculation logic to handle different start dates. Task: Update the Rorsair and RFRDFA configurations for the 2026-2027 aid year to reflect the single disbursement setup with the "Plus 3" day calculation rule. Owner: Kenneth Kirksey Deadline: Tomorrow (Processing was deferred until the day following the meeting).

item.title: 2025-12-09 - Zoom Transcript - Estimated Awards
item.description: Kenneth Kirksey: Good morning!Jonathan Ibarra: Good morning!Kenneth Kirksey: Sorry, I couldn't… my computer restarted because of an update, and then my camera wouldn't come on.Jonathan Ibarra: Technology.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah.Jennifer Buckles: We're glad we can see your smiling face.Kenneth Kirksey: And I didn't get eaten by sharks or alligators.Jennifer Buckles: Yeah, we're especially glad about that.Kenneth Kirksey: So, what do we have left to do on the estimated awards?Jonathan Ibarra: Basically, right now, it's just one last test. We wanted to wait until we got some of the institutional scholarships awarded, but Wendy came across an issue, so I'll let her talk a little bit about that.Wendy Ray: So, using the Banner portal and/or mass uploading those means that Lindley has to run FASH. With the new process, she has to manually add grouping to every single student. So, we have over 7,000 scholarships we're getting ready to offer. She's going to have to run FASH on them. If they don't have a group, she's going to have to manually add it.Jennifer Buckles: Why don't you wait until we do the grouping? Because you haven't run grouping at all for 26-27. We have it set up so that even if they don't have a FAFSA, they'll get a standard group.Jonathan Ibarra: I could have sworn that was included in the review of the test that we've been looking at during SI tests. But I'm assuming you mean in production, you haven't really done any grouping in production.Jennifer Buckles: I believe they're just loading ISIRs and not running groups at all.Kenneth Kirksey: No.Wendy Ray: So can we run groups so that Lindley doesn't have to manually do that when she runs FASH? Or does that mean they're packaged?Jonathan Ibarra: No.Wendy Ray: Okay, two different things.Jonathan Ibarra: Jen, how soon can we do that?Jennifer Buckles: While he's looking at that, do your students have to be able to see their scholarships in the portal?Wendy Ray: We don't want them to see them.Jennifer Buckles: Okay, good. Because if we put them in this estimate freshman packaging group, it's a visible to them. I just wanted to make sure you weren't directing them, "Hey, go out here and accept your scholarship," and they go in there and they can't see it.Wendy Ray: No. They will be able to see their terms and conditions in Slate. It's not connected to their estimated package at all right now.Kenneth Kirksey: Why does FASH depend on grouping?Wendy Ray: That was the new process that you worked with Lindley and the pop sels, and all of that.Kenneth Kirksey: Oh, okay, yeah, I remember. It's been a minute.Jennifer Buckles: I do think we need to run a test of running the estimated packaging on top of awards that are posted through FASH. I know that if you batch post in Banner, or if you manually add an award in Banner, running packaging on top of that won't touch it. I'm assuming it won't with FASH as well, but we didn't test that. You guys do that all the time; you run through FASH and then package on top of it all the time, so I'm not too concerned about it being a problem. It would just make me feel better to know we ran a full simulation of what it was going to be like.Kenneth Kirksey: Okay, so what we have been running, let me zoom in a little bit. We've just been running the RTP, RCPTP. We have not been running fixate periods, fixed year in college, SAP, or data load.Kenneth Kirksey: Jen, is there any reason for us not to run the group assignments?Jennifer Buckles: Not that I know of. Have you completely finished the checklist? Like, there's no outstanding setup items that need to be done?Kenneth Kirksey: Let me go back and double-check.Jennifer Buckles: I think we were waiting on—part of the delay was budgets. We were waiting for more finalized budget numbers. I know Leanne has updated everything that she can at this point. The couple of outstanding things for the budgets are the new freshman amount, what that's going to be. I've got the rule built, but I didn't want to put it in production until we knew the amount because it just didn't jibe with what was already in there for the other people that are not freshmen. So I just wanted confirmation on that.But if we went ahead and awarded budgets now, they'll continuously get updated until they're packaged. That's not a deal-breaker where we need to wait for that. Until they get packaged, they'll keep getting their budget amounts. But for these freshmen, they're going to get a package date when we do the estimated packaging, so they won't get re-budgeted until we change them from their estimate to the real package. Then they'll get an updated budget.Kenneth Kirksey: I can enable this, and I know on the first run, I'll have to go back and set the dates so it picks up everybody we've done to this point. But I can go ahead and do that, and then we'll just enable this so it'll be running daily.Jennifer Buckles: You'll want to make sure this is probably part of your checklist, but that all your award posts in Banner have the new, the right periods on them from the rule. The only other note I would have on this grouping is the standard group. We pulled that out into a separate chain. I ran it once while you were out for 25-26. That's the one where if the pop sel pulls zero and then the groups run, it fails and aborts the whole chain. So we wanted that separate from the ISIR load chain so it wouldn't cause problems. It's now that separate chain. So running this would take care of the people who have FAFSAs, but then you would also need to run that standard chain to get everybody in a standard group.Kenneth Kirksey: Right. Okay. I will go ahead and check the checklist to make sure we've got everything set up, and then run groups. After I run groups, we'll double-check to make sure everybody's grouped, and then Lindley can run FASH.Wendy Ray: Yeah, if you can just let me know when groups are done, then I will get some... I have two AES awards added because one has a FAFSA and one does not. We just wanted to double-check that before I did the mass upload, because the mass upload is over 7,000.Kenneth Kirksey: And then once we do scholarships, we'll do the estimated packaging over top of that. So that will take into account... will that change the amounts?Jennifer Buckles: Yeah, potentially. Their need could be changed if they now have a scholarship, so they may not be as eligible for the same sub or whatever.Wendy Ray: I think that was the whole thought process—is adding scholarships before we ran estimated so that we did not have to process and work overbudgets.Jennifer Buckles: I would also say I wouldn't waste time working overbudgets on estimated packages because they're going to all get redone anyway. But I don't know if we have DISBRV running. It will probably pick it up, but it won't recognize it as an estimated package unless we put something in there. I don't know if DISBRV is running for 26-27 yet.Kenneth Kirksey: No.Jonathan Ibarra: So what's the timeline on this?Kenneth Kirksey: I would say I probably need today to double-check and make sure we've done everything in the checklist. Then I'd go ahead and run all of this this evening, so we could have it in the SI test.Jennifer Buckles: Yeah, but we wouldn't do that, ideally, until some scholarship awards had been pushed. So it's kind of like, we need this grouping to run so that then you can run the FASH to push the scholarships, because then they'll be grouped and you don't have to do manual grouping. Then we can run the packaging test. We just need that sequence to happen.Jonathan Ibarra: Kenneth, what is the cutoff time for anything to reflect on SI test from production?Kenneth Kirksey: 6 p.m.Wendy Ray: Okay. As long as you could give us 30 minutes to get the FASH run, I think we would be okay.Kenneth Kirksey: Can do.Jonathan Ibarra: Sounds good.Kenneth Kirksey: All right, well, I have my assignment for today.Wendy Ray: Okay.Kenneth Kirksey: All right, thank you.
