item.title: 2025-12-09 - Zoom Tasks - Estimated Awards
item.description: The team is currently in the preparatory phase for the 2026-2027 (26-27) academic year estimated awards cycle. ISIR Loading: The system is currently running the basic ISIR load processes (RTP, RCPTP). Disabled Processes: Several downstream processes are currently disabled or have not yet been run for the 26-27 aid year, including: Fixate periods. Fixed year in college. Satisfactory Academic Progress (SAP). Data loads. Packaging Group Assignments. Scholarship Management (FASH): The institutional scholarship process involves mass uploading awards (over 7,000 records) or using the Banner portal. This process relies on the underlying Banner "Packaging Group" to function efficiently. Budgeting: Budgets are mostly finalized, with the exception of the final freshman amount. However, the system allows for budgeting to update continuously until a package is locked. The most critical immediate issue is a workflow inefficiency regarding the FASH (Fund Awarding Scholarship) process. The Issue: FASH relies on students having an assigned "Packaging Group" in Banner to post awards automatically. Because the "Grouping" process has not been run for the 26-27 aid year, students currently have no group assigned. The Consequence: If the mass upload of 7,000+ scholarships is attempted without existing groups, the Financial Aid staff (specifically Lindley) would be forced to manually add a packaging group to every single student record. This is a significant waste of time and introduces high potential for human error. The Issue: There is a risk of inefficient workflow if "Estimated Packaging" is run before institutional scholarships are posted. The Consequence: If a student is packaged with need-based aid first, and then a scholarship is added later, the student may become "over-budget" or "over-awarded." This requires staff to manually "work overbudgets" to reduce other aid. The Issue: The "Standard Group" process (for students without a FAFSA) was previously part of the main ISIR load chain. The Risk: If the population selection (pop sel) for this group pulls zero records, it causes the entire ISIR load chain to fail and abort. To resolve the manual processing bottleneck and ensure accurate packaging, the team agreed to the following solutions:The technical team will run the Grouping process for all 26-27 students before the scholarship upload occurs. This includes both: ISIR Groups: Students with a valid FAFSA. Standard Groups: Students without a FAFSA (assigned a generic group). Outcome: This ensures that when FASH is run, the system recognizes the students' groups and posts awards automatically, eliminating the need for Lindley to manually touch 7,000 records. The workflow will be strictly sequenced to minimize rework: Group Assignment: Run grouping for all students. FASH Upload: Post institutional scholarships. Estimated Packaging: Run packaging after scholarships are on the record. Outcome: The packaging engine will "see" the scholarship as an existing resource and calculate remaining need/eligibility correctly the first time, preventing over-award situations. The "Standard Group" process has been isolated into its own execution chain. It is no longer dependent on the ISIR load chain. This mitigates the risk of the main data load failing if no students qualify for the standard group on a specific day. Validation Report: After running groups, a validation check is required to ensure both FAFSA and Non-FAFSA students have a group assigned. Budget Rules: Ensure the "New Freshman" budget rule is built (completed by Jennifer), even if the final dollar amount is pending. Banner Financial Aid: Ensure all Award periods are correct on the award forms. Verify DISBRV (Disbursement Review) is not running for 26-27 yet to prevent interference. AppWorx / Job Scheduling: Standard Group Chain: Must be configured as a standalone chain separate from the ISIR load. Daily Schedule: Enable the Grouping process to run daily moving forward. For the Technical Lead (Kenneth): Pre-Flight Checklist: Review the 26-27 Setup Checklist to ensure no outstanding configuration items remain (other than the known budget variance). Configure Grouping Dates: Access the Grouping process parameters. Set the dates to look retroactively to the beginning of the cycle to catch all students loaded up to this point. Execute Grouping Chains: Step A: Run the ISIR Grouping process (for FAFSA students). Step B: Run the Standard Grouping chain (for non-FAFSA students). Enable Daily Schedule: Update the scheduler to ensure these grouping processes run automatically every night. Notify Business Unit: Inform Wendy/Lindley immediately upon completion (Target: Before 5:30 PM). For the Financial Aid Team (Wendy/Lindley): Validation: Once notified by Kenneth, check two specific test cases: One student with a FAFSA (confirm AES award adds correctly). One student without a FAFSA (confirm AES award adds correctly). Execute FASH Upload: Proceed with the mass upload of the 7,000+ scholarship records. Deadline: This must be completed at least 30 minutes prior to the 6:00 PM SI Test environment refresh.
item.guid: Finacial Aid Tech Notes/2025-12-09 - Zoom Tasks - Estimated Awards.md

item.title: 2025-12-09 - Zoom Summary - Estimated Awards
item.description: Kenneth Kirksey Jonathan Ibarra Jennifer Buckles Wendy Ray FASH Grouping Issue: The current challenge regarding the need to manually add groups to over 7,000 students to process scholarships (FASH) for the 26-27 aid year. Process Automation: The proposal to run the grouping process in production to automate the assignment of groups, removing the need for manual entry by staff member Lindley. Sequence of Operations: Defining the correct order of processing: Grouping FASH (Scholarships) Estimated Packaging. Budget & Rules: Status of freshman budget amounts and rules; rules are built but awaiting final amounts before moving to production. SI Test Environment Timeline: Coordinating a timeline to complete these tasks in production today so they reflect in the SI Test environment after the 6:00 PM refresh. What is left to do on the estimated awards? (Kenneth Kirksey) There is one last test required. The team wanted to wait for institutional scholarships to be awarded, but a grouping issue within FASH needs to be resolved first. (Jonathan Ibarra / Wendy Ray) Can the team run groups so Lindley does not have to manually add them when running FASH? (Wendy Ray) Yes, Kenneth can enable this process, but he must first double-check the setup checklist to ensure everything is ready. (Kenneth Kirksey) Do students have to be able to see their scholarships in the portal? (Jennifer Buckles) No, they do not need to see them in the portal. They will see their terms and conditions in Slate; it is not connected to the estimated package at this time. (Wendy Ray) Is there any reason not to run the group assignments now? (Kenneth Kirksey) No, provided the checklist is completed and there are no outstanding setup items. (Jennifer Buckles) Will running estimated packaging over top of scholarships change the amounts? (Kenneth Kirksey) Yes, potentially. A student's need may change if they have a scholarship, which is why scholarships should be added before running estimated packaging to avoid working overbudgets. (Jennifer Buckles) What is the cutoff time for data in production to reflect on the SI test environment? (Jonathan Ibarra) 6:00 PM. (Kenneth Kirksey) Run Grouping in Production: The team agreed to run the grouping process in production immediately to facilitate the mass upload of scholarships via FASH without manual entry. Operational Sequence: The team established the order of operations: 1) Run Grouping, 2) Run FASH (Scholarships), 3) Run Estimated Packaging. Freshman Budget Rules: The rule for new freshman amounts is built but will remain out of production until the final budget amount is confirmed. Standard Group Chain: The "Standard Group" process must be run as a separate chain from the ISIR load to prevent system failures if the population selection pulls zero records. Task: Review the setup checklist and ensure all award posts in Banner have the correct periods. [Owner: Kenneth Kirksey, Deadline: Today] Task: Enable and run the Grouping process (including the separate Standard Group chain) in production. [Owner: Kenneth Kirksey, Deadline: Today, prior to 5:30 PM] Task: Run FASH to mass upload over 7,000 scholarships once grouping is confirmed. [Owner: Wendy Ray/Lindley, Deadline: Today, before the 6:00 PM SI cutoff] Task: Notify Wendy Ray when the grouping process is complete. [Owner: Kenneth Kirksey, Deadline: Today]
item.guid: Finacial Aid Tech Notes/2025-12-09 - Zoom Summary - Estimated Awards.md

item.title: 2025-11-10 - Comment Codes and CFLAGs - Email - Jenn
item.description:
From: Jennifer Buckles jennbucklesconsulting@gmail.comTo: me, Angie, JonathanDate: Nov 4, 2025, 6:41 PMFor the Cflag process changes, I need to know which of these comment codes you would want to be reset to R if a new transaction comes in and the comment code still exists.Comment Code Tracking Comment Text 252 BANKRU The National Student Loan Data System (NSLDS®) database indicates that you have one or more federal student loans in an active bankruptcy status. Before you can receive additional federal student loans, you must contact your college’s or career school’s financial aid office. 253 DL253 Based upon data provided by the National Student Loan Data System (NSLDS®) database and your grade level, we determined that you may have received a total amount of federal student loans (graduate and/or undergraduate) that exceeds the loan limits established for the federal student loan programs. 255 DL255 Based upon data provided by the National Student Loan Data System (NSLDS®) database and your grade level, we determined that you may have received a total amount of federal student loans (graduate and/or undergraduate) that exceeds the loan limits established for the federal student loan programs. However, you may have reaffirmed the excess debt with your loan servicer, restoring your eligibility to participate in the federal student aid programs. 256 DL256 Based upon data provided by the National Student Loan Data System (NSLDS®) database and your grade level, we determined that you may have received a total amount of undergraduate federal student loans that exceeds the loan limits established for the federal student loan programs. 258 DL258 Based upon data provided by the National Student Loan Data System (NSLDS®) database and your grade level, we determined that you may have received a total amount of undergraduate federal student loans that exceeds the loan limits established for the federal student loan programs. However, you may have reaffirmed the excess debt with your loan servicer, restoring your eligibility to participate in the federal student aid programs. 260 DL260 Based upon data provided by the National Student Loan Data System (NSLDS®) database and your grade level, we determined that you may have received subsidized federal student loans greater than loan limits established for the federal student loan programs. 261 DL261 Based upon data provided by the National Student Loan Data System (NSLDS®) database, your grade level, and your dependency status, we determined that you may have received federal student loans in excess of loan limits established for the federal student loan programs. 264 PELLEU The limit to the total amount of Federal Pell Grants that a student may receive is the equivalent of six school years. Based upon information reported to the National Student Loan Data System (NSLDS®) database by the schools you have attended, you have received a total amount of Federal Pell Grants that is close to the cumulative total you can receive. For this reason, your eligibility for more Federal Pell Grants may be limited. 265 PELLEU The limit to the total amount of Federal Pell Grants that a student may receive is the equivalent of six school years. Based upon information reported to the National Student Loan Data System (NSLDS®) database by the schools you have attended, you may have received a total amount of Federal Pell Grants that equals or exceeds the allowable total.
From: Angie Daugherty daughertyak@appstate.eduTo: Jennifer, me, JonathanDate: Nov 5, 2025, 8:11 AMPELLEU 264 and 265 can be taken off. We do not need them to reset if they have already been resolved. The C Flag is aid year specific, correct? If a student has a C flag for 25/26 resolved and also has it for 26/27 would the 26/27 C Flag remain requested until we resolve it? I just want to clarify that. Thank you Jen for all of your work with us. Angie
From: Jonathan Ibarra ibarrajr@appstate.eduTo: Angie, Jennifer, meDate: Nov 5, 2025, 9:33 AMJen,For the DLxxx and BANKRU tracking, please reset those to an R when a NEW transaction comes in. Thank you!
From: Jennifer Buckles jennbucklesconsulting@gmail.comTo: Jonathan, Angie, meDate: Nov 5, 2025, 2:25 PMDo you want them changed to R or P or something else to indicate it’s a secondary review? I thought it might be helpful to distinguish between the ones getting tracked for the first time and the ones that were already tracked and had a new ISIR come in. If it’s easier to just have them all the same, that’s fine too. Just wanted to make sure. Do you require the student to submit something when the requirement is in R status or do you look at the R’s automatically?
From: Jonathan Ibarra ibarrajr@appstate.eduTo: Jennifer, Angie, meDate: Nov 5, 2025, 2:29 PMJen,I use P's as well for those whom I have reviewed and notified the students to take action, whether it's reaffirmation or confirmation to adjust the excess Subsidized to Unsubsidized Loan. If possible, we can use a different letter. The WebFocus report pulls them up with an R status. We may need to have the WebFocus report "LNEX BY AIDE 2425" to include P and any status that will be used for secondary review for NEW ISIR received.
From: Jennifer Buckles jennbucklesconsulting@gmail.comTo: Jonathan, Angie, meDate: Nov 6, 2025, 7:02 PMYou only have 4 unused characters left for tracking statuses (0, 8, K, Q). Do you want to use one of these for the secondary cflag review or save them for something in the future and just stick with R for all cflag reviews?
From: Angie Daugherty daughertyak@appstate.eduTo: Jennifer, Jonathan, meDate: Nov 7, 2025, 8:46 AMIf we use R, would all new transactions revert back or just ones that had already been reviewed once? Angie
From: Jennifer Buckles jennbucklesconsulting@gmail.comTo: Angie, Jonathan, meDate: Nov 7, 2025, 8:53 AMAll new transactions with the comment codes Jonathan indicated he wanted to be set for re-review would be set back to R. If we need to be more precise than that, I just need to know what you want to happen.
From: Angie Daugherty daughertyak@appstate.eduTo: Jennifer, Jonathan, meDate: Nov 7, 2025, 11:55 AMI defer to Jonathan on this one. He is out of the office today but will let you know what is decided soon. Angie
From: Jonathan Ibarra ibarrajr@appstate.eduTo: Angie, Jennifer, meDate: Nov 8, 2025, 9:40 AMJen,Here's my question on this. If I decide to stick with one of the four remaining letters to indicate a re-review, is there a way to identify them in case they have been reviewed a second time for data purposes to see how many we received in a given academic year? Otherwise, I may decide to set back to an R for two reasons. One reason is either way, I have to review them just to be certain. The second reason is that I don't trust NSLDS necessarily, where the information I have reviewed at the time changes spontaneously, a lot from the consolidation that occurred, where the amounts increase much more than initially reviewed. The deciding factor for the 4 remaining letters is whether it is easy to identify after they have been reviewed or not. If so, then let's do it. If not, let's stick with the R's.
From: Jennifer Buckles jennbucklesconsulting@gmail.comTo: Jonathan, Angie, meDate: Nov 8, 2025, 1:39 PMNo, the process would just be changing the status if the tracking code already exists or adding the tracking code if it doesn’t. So we can either make them the same status to indicate they need review or use one tracking code if the tracking code already exists and another if the tracking code doesn’t exist.So, if you review and change it to a P or and S and another ISIR comes in, it would be set back to R (or whatever code you use for secondary review).
From: Jonathan Ibarra ibarrajr@appstate.eduTo: Jennifer, Angie, meDate: Nov 10, 2025, 8:33 AMJen,To avoid confusion, let's stick with the R instead of using the remaining 4 letters. Thank you!

item.title: 2025-09-05 - Fix RZPNCUL crashing with Oracle invalid month error
item.description:
Jonathan notes that state grants EFT didn't run on Wed and State grants didn't award last night, and packaging didn't run last night. Checked Appworx logs FINAID_DATALOAD_MASTER FA_STATE_GRANTS_EFT
In both cases RZPNCUL aborted Checked Appworx logs for RZPNCUL for those jobs Starting RZPNCUL MC:16.0 Run Sequence Number: Encountered Abort Condition Message is: validateDetail: Open spbpersCur Oracle Error: ORA-01843: not a valid month Remembered ITS installed Banner patches on Tuesday Retrieved cert file CERT-002906-26-2025-08-28-01.00.00.GTF1 from FTP server. RZPNCUL sucessfully loaded this file on 8/28. Ran that file through RZPNCUL in SITEST. Got the error. Tried the same with CERT-002906-26-2025-07-24-16.59.01.GTF. Also got the error Conclusion: The Banner patches from Monday are a likely cause of the problem.
Submitted ticket to ITS: https://jira.appstate.edu/projects/ATSD/queues/issue/ATSD-211326 Linda Herron found and fixed the issue: We ran a Banner Upgrade on Sept 2 - 10pm. As part of that upgrade all "C" programs had to be recompiled. Unfortunately our exsting script picked up an older version on rzpncul.pc under $BANENR_HOME/finaid/c. The newer version from July this year was in $BANNER_LINKS and $BANNER_HOME/modsmgr/finaid/c. Working on getting the $BANNER_HOME code tree in sync and fixing the ASU custom compile script. Recompiled RZPNCUL and RZPNCCF from the July 24th 2025 version.(in $BANNER_LINKS) After Linda's fix, I ran RZPNCUL via Jobsub in SITEST on CERT-002906-26-2025-09-04-01.00.00.GTF. RZPNCUL completed successfully. I then ran the full FA_STATE_GRANT_AWARDS_2526 chain in Appworx PROD. It completed successfully. Since the RZPNCUL issue caused Appworx to cancel FINAID_APP2G, FA_PACKAGING, and FA_FIRST_AWARD_NOTICE, I ran those manually one at a time in Appworx. The RZPNCUL issue casued Appworx to cancel FA_STATE_GRANTS_EFT to cancel on 9/3. I ran that job manually in Appworx.
item.guid: Finacial Aid Tech Notes/2025-09-05 - Fix RZPNCUL crashing with Oracle invalid month error.md

item.title: 2025-10-29 - Email - DSBREV no FAFSA
item.description: From: LeeAnn Barnes To: to Jennifer, me Date: Oct 28, 2025, 11:33 AMHey Jenn,I cannot remember.  Does the DSBREV process exclude students with no FAFSA?  Leslie asked about this student 900995370.  They do not have a DSBREV but they are over COA.  Institutional scholarships aren't allowed to be over COA.  900995370 D. DWUMAThanks, LeeAnnFrom: Jennifer Buckles To: to LeeAnn, me Date: Oct 28, 2025, 9:11 PMI don’t believe there is anything requiring a FAFSA for DSBREV.  I think it’s the blank tracking group causing the student not to get picked up.  I’m guessing the standard budget was added manually before we began running these students through tracking groups and assigning the STNDRD budgets in Automic.  Now students get added to a default tracking group before they get the standard budget.  I’ve run tracking groups on this student to see if that allows them to get picked up in DSBREV.  I’m not sure what time DSBREV runs though, so I don’t know if I made it in time for tonight.  If DSBREV runs after 9pm, check this one on Wednesday to see if it was added.  If it runs before 9pm, won’t be updated until whatever time it runs again on Wednesday.From: LeeAnn Barnes To: to Leslie, Jennifer, me Date: Oct 29, 2025, 9:37 AMIt looks like it did pick them up and DSBREV was added.  Is there a way for us to find any others that may be in the same situation, so we don't miss anyone?  Thank you, LeeAnnFrom: Jennifer Buckles To: to LeeAnn, me, Leslie Date: Oct 29, 2025, 10:46 AMYes, we can run a popsel to pick up students with STNDRD budgets and no tracking group and run the through tracking grouping.

item.title: 2025-10-27 - Why Add RCRTP27 to Front of Data Load Process
item.description: So this was so that when Dawn matches suspense, if she matches suspense and loads them that day, and then something happens and the ISIR load doesn't run that night, everybody that she loads gets missed, because then they have that timestamp. So this was to allow her to match suspense all she wants, not load them, but attach that load to the first part of the actual Automic process. So that if it didn't run that night, let's say it got delayed and it ran the next day, or for some reason you intentionally turned it off because of something else that was going on, and it didn't get run until the next day, whenever it did run, it would load her suspense records first. Then pull in the new file, run, load those so they would all have that same date, and all go through that day's daily load process.
item.guid: Finacial Aid Tech Notes/2025-10-27 - Why Add RCRTP27 to Front of Data Load Process.md

item.title: 2025-08-25 - FAFSA Reject Code 68 - Update from ED
item.description:
Forum: Banner Financial AidGood morning, FA Community!On August 21, 2025, the Department of Education released an important update regarding FAFSA Reject Code 68, an issue many institutions have encountered during this processing year.To support institutions in understanding the scenarios that trigger this reject code—and the potential actions that can be taken to resolve it—ED has provided detailed guidance.You can find the announcement and additional information at the link below:
Update about Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA®) Reject Code 68ContextFAFSA Reject Code 68, which indicates that a student’s Student Aid Index (SAI) is blank, but the transaction is not rejected, can be confusing for students and financial aid administrators (FAAs). Over the past several months, the U.S. Department of Education (ED) has assigned Reject Code 68 to records as it works to resolve a set of related processing issues. ED is working to better classify the issues that lead to this rejection so that FAAs have clear steps to resolve these cases in the near term and so that ED can implement a longer-term solution. In the meantime, this announcement lays out the causes and current next steps for resolving scenarios associated with Reject Code 68.Reject Code 68 Scenarios and Suggested Steps for RemediationWhen a Reject Code 68 error occurs, it is often paired with one of two comment codes: 329 or 303. These rejections are likely due to one of the following scenarios:Comment Code 303 Missing Tax Filing Status: When the parent answers the “Parent Tax Filing Status” question as “Did not and will not file any tax return – no earned income” and a state of residence of FC (Foreign Country). Comment Code 329 StudentAid.gov Account is flagged: Occasionally, Federal Student Aid (FSA) may flag accounts to protect customers’ personally identifiable information. An update will be made in December to make the next steps clearer to the user. Parent Paper Signature on Electronic FAFSA Form: When a FAFSA form that has been submitted online is rejected for a missing parent signature, a parent who then provides that signature via a paper correction will result in a Reject Code 68.
Pending Match Status: The user's Social Security Administration (SSA) match status in their StudentAid.gov account is listed as PENDING. This was resolved with the Aug. 3 release of real-time matching (see APP-25-18), but there may still be lingering issues. The following tables provide a detailed overview of each issue, how to identify it, and the potential solution.Comment Code 303Comment Code 329FAAs who have questions or continue to have issues should contact the FPS Help Desk and be ready to provide the students’ transaction IDs so that a ticket can be opened and researched further for the specific user(s). Phone: 800-330-5947 Fax: 319-665-7662
Email: support@fps.ed.gov; for questions specific to TFA, email TFASupport@ed.gov. Office Hours: 8 a.m. to 8 p.m. ET, Monday through Friday ED is continuing to review how we handle these errors and will work to provide further guidance about ways to resolve each issue.We appreciate your patience throughout this process.Mark Kichline, Senior Product Manager, Banner Financial Aid
item.guid: Finacial Aid Tech Notes/2025-08-25 - FAFSA Reject Code 68 - Update from ED.md
