item.title: 2025-10-27 - Why Students with CFlags aren't having requirements added in RRRAREQ
item.description: When students are packaged, we lock the student's ISIRs Then we get a new ISIR for the student. Then that next day, Dawn goes through the output and reviews all the locked records, and looks at it and says, "Okay, if the SAI didn't change, I'm gonna go ahead and make the new one the current record." Because it got loaded the day before, it doesn't get picked up in that night's process to say, "We got a new ISIR, run it through the batch posts and see if there's any C flags or tracking codes that need to be added." Jennifer Buckles: And we either have a report to pull those, or, the alternative is to evaluate why do we lock the records for packaged students. So there are... there are some reasons to do that, but I feel like your processes have changed a little bit, so that may not make the most sense. We don't... we don't lock records for packaged students, we lock verification. So, once they're verified, we lock those FAFSAs, but we don't lock every packaged student, because then you just end up spending all your time unlocking them and loading the ISIRs that didn't have any SAI changes.When before, the mindset, or the policy that you guys had was, "We don't load it unless we need to." Now the policy is, you load it unless there's a reason not to, so you're loading more than you're not loading, so locking it is just kind of creating a ripple effect of extra work that needs to be done, or taken care of, or followed up with reports. So that may be a discussion that you want to have, is: Do we need to lock all these records for package shoots?Jennifer Buckles: If the... if you decide not to, a consideration is that you would need to have a report that could show you... which... she has this on her needs analysis report that she has, but if the SAI changes from one transaction to the next, and they've already been packaged. Somebody's got to look at those, because if you're just loading them over top, the SAI changes, that could change your eligibility, but typically that wouldn't be a Dawn report, that would be somebody in the packaging area, because that person needs to evaluate their eligibility for all the awards. So it's not necessarily something the ISIR load person is doing, but it's more of a packaging report, that "We got a new transaction with a new SAI, we need to make sure the student's still eligible for their awards."So, it's not a quick, easy decision, because there's give and take with both sides of it, but it may be something you want to discuss if it makes sense to continue locking everyone who's packaged, or should you just follow up on people who have SAI changes after they've been packaged.Kenneth Kirksey: Okay, I'll talk with them, but we may need to just sit down and talk about that.
item.guid: Finacial Aid Tech Notes/2025-10-27 - Why Students with CFlags aren't having requirements added in RRRAREQ.md

item.title: 2025-07-18 - Meeting - R2T4 - Jenn, LeeAnn, Kenneth - Notes
item.description: For Official Withdrawals Webfocus report - Withdrawals by Term Every other day Put data in google sheet review to see if they have financial aid process returns For federal Aid - Go to COD - do calculation there Complete Title IV Withdrawal Form COD Generates PDF with calculations of what needs to be returned For state aid - go to state portal Enter student info portal generates calcuations Outside scholarships Send to Becky Returns Pell or state aid - rpaawrd - lock - roaimmp Change offered and accepted amt roaimmp Loans - rladlor No returns Acog institutional scholarships Athletics We do calculations for return Ath sometimes returns, sometimes not View returns on RSIAREV Notes in ROACOMM ROAUSDF Amounts entered Set ready to send mailer Email sent by RZPRT24 Fall, spring, summer withdrawal See video Manual Exit Notification Are these amounts used in email to student? If we use banner, these amounts will be stored in a table We can pull this data so they don’t have to re-enter values in ROAUSDF Argos can send email based on report values Banner Communication manager? double check SFAWDRL Can we use this to track unofficial withdrawal Enrollment Status - WU - Unoffical withdrawal How/when does registrar mark students as unofficial withdrawal? What consequences How many r2t4 per term? 300 to 350 official withdrawal Unofficial Based on all f report run at end of term Same process for calculaiton and return Advantage in doing in Banner - can batchStill have to manually adjust in RPAAWRDBanner Article on R2T4 Setup - https://elluciansupport.service-now.com/customer_center?sys_kb_id=c47132ba83286250926912d0deaad344&id=kb_article_viewUsing Banner probably won’t work for summer. Banner R2T4 doesn’t do part of term Banner R2T4 - Run based on popsel - Output shows what needs to be returned - Process - Set up in PROD - Setup will mirror to SITEST - Continue using current process - Test new process in Banner - Can run job in simulation mode in PRODSimulation Mode - Run in prod in simulation mode - check values - run in actual modeIf incorrect refunds written to banner, can do another calculation that will create another refund.Next Steps Have IT look at custom job What automic job is processing R2T4? Do we have Banner Communication manager Jenn - Set up in Prod Jenn - How to use SFAWDRL for unofficial withdrawals Registrar sets unofficial withdrawal status Jenn will see if there’s a batch way to populate unofficial withdrawals
item.guid: Finacial Aid Tech Notes/2025-07-18 - Meeting - R2T4 - Jenn, LeeAnn, Kenneth - Notes.md

item.title: 2025-07-18 - Meeting - R2T4 - Jenn, LeeAnn, Kenneth - AI Summary
item.description: Jennifer updated a process to treat students with an "E" status as out-of-state for transportation purposes. LeeAnn confirmed that recalculating the budget should now pull the correct values. A full recalculation for all students is planned for early August. Discussion about whether Pell files should already be sent. Jennifer noted Pell is easier to update than loans and should be sent if loans are already being processed. Uncertainty about whether there’s a specific date or reason for delay. LeeAnn explained the current manual process for handling official and unofficial withdrawals: Pulling reports from the registrar. Reviewing financial aid status. Performing calculations on the COD website. Entering results into Banner and Google Sheets. Kenneth requested a walkthrough of the process, which LeeAnn provided via screen sharing. Jennifer suggested using Banner’s built-in R2T4 processing to automate calculations. Benefits include: Batch processing. Pulling data directly from Banner (e.g., charges, aid, dates). Reducing manual data entry and errors. Concerns about summer term and part-of-term complexities were raised. Plan to: Set up R2T4 processing in production. Test in SI Test environment using real data. Compare Banner calculations with COD results. Gradually transition to using Banner for actual processing. Simulation mode in Banner allows safe testing before committing changes. Current process uses a custom job to notify students of R2T4 balances. Discussion about whether Banner’s Communication Manager or other tools (e.g., Argos) could replace or improve this. Jennifer confirmed that specific balance notifications are likely a federal requirement. Registrar currently populates withdrawal data for official withdrawals. Discussion about having them also handle unofficial withdrawals using the SAFA Withdrawal screen. Jennifer shared how her institution handles this with batch processing and reports. Some setup is global (per aid year), while others (like term dates and break days) must be updated each term. Kenneth requested documentation of setup tasks for each aid year and term to add to the process calendar. Jennifer will begin setup based on Ellucian documentation. Kenneth will investigate the custom job and Banner Communication Manager. LeeAnn will coordinate with the registrar and prepare break day data. Team will reconvene after fall term begins to assess progress.
item.guid: Finacial Aid Tech Notes/2025-07-18 - Meeting - R2T4 - Jenn, LeeAnn, Kenneth - AI Summary.md

item.title: 2025-10-01 - Meeting with LeeAnn & Jen - Test R2T4 in PROD Banner
item.description: Review the R2T4 in RPAAWRD Look for awards that didn't pay Look at withdrawal record in SFAWDRL (for testing) If withdrawal code is missing Percent attended over 60% Verify original charges RPATIVC Options menu (wheel) - > Simulation Mode Check TIV Calculation details, do they match the manual TIV calculation from COD? Options menu (wheel) - > Calculate and save Mode This just does the calculations, we have to then process the return Can do multiple calculate and saves. New calculations will be saved in a separate sequence number. See [Banner Financial Aid Quick Reference: Using Return of Title IV In Banner] https://elluciansupport.service-now.com/customer_center?sys_kb_id=10fca79bc3c47a10f5463eaf050131f1&id=kb_article_view&spa=1 for how to access different sequence numbers. RPRTIVC Batch job for calculating R2T4 Run on students that need r2t4 Create report for reviewing withdrawals, and then create manual popsel OR create popsel of students withdrawn that have TIV aid Jenn recommends doing the report so we can see which students need R2T4 Show LeeAnn how to use GLRSLCT and GLAEXTER to create manual popsel. Mode: A = Simulation, U = calculate and save We don't cancel aid for spring for students that R2T4 in fall It's institutional preference whether we cancel this or not If we have more people actually return in spring than not, not canceling will save us work But leaving the aid for spring could affect the student's eligibility if they move to another institution Look at using Banner Communication Manager to send R2T4 emails. Currently being sent by RZPR2T4. Next Steps Have processors run students in COD Then run in PROD in Simulation If everything is okay, switch to Banner We'll keep doing in COD for Fall and checking against Banner R2T4. We'll do a hard switch to Banner in Spring Look at using Banner Communication Manager to send R2T4 emails. Currently being sent by RZPR2T4.
item.guid: Finacial Aid Tech Notes/2025-10-01 - Meeting with LeeAnn & Jen - Test R2T4 in PROD Banner.md

item.title: 2025-10-07 - Zoom - FAFSA Receipt, Locking GED and HS Updates - Transcript
item.description: Kenneth Kirksey: Jen, while we're waiting for Dawn, Allison asked me a question: How can the students see that we have received their FAFSA?Jennifer Buckles: While you have the aid year invisible, they can't.Kenneth Kirksey: Right.Jennifer Buckles: But once you turn it on, you track it on RawRec.Dawn: Where do we set up the estimated budgets for 26-27?Kenneth Kirksey: The RPB something. I'd have to go look at the...Dawn: So, are we sure that Leanne has not put it in there?Kenneth Kirksey: Yes.Dawn: Okay, so because those are going to... we basically have them.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah.Dawn: So we just needed to put them in there.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah.Dawn: Okay, I'll work with her next week when she comes back on that.Kenneth Kirksey: So, if we're not running the tracking group process, they're not going to see that we've got their FAFSA.Jennifer Buckles: Right. Although, I think there is a piece of the ISIR load that actually adds that to tracking, and it's not a batch post. But again, while it's invisible, they can't see anything.Kenneth Kirksey: But if we turn on Info Access... is that going to show things we don't want them seeing?Jennifer Buckles: I can't imagine. I mean, because you're not packaging yet, right?Kenneth Kirksey: Nope.Jennifer Buckles: So, if you turned on Info Access and you had not run the batch posting yet, then there would be nothing for them to see.Jennifer Buckles: Then once you run batch posting, they would be able to see their tracking requirements, and then that's going to then push them to Student Forms. If you haven't uploaded your ISIRs to Student Forms yet, you could have a disconnect there. So you just kind of need to make sure before you post tracking codes that are going to direct them elsewhere to complete requirements, you're ready for them to actually complete those requirements. Like, if it's linked to a form, like a PDF or something, that that form is correct, or if it's linked to Student Forms, that those ISIRs have been loaded. So you kind of have to align all of that and push it out all at once.But I believe the FAFSA gets tracked in your actual ISIR load, not the grouping batch post process.Kenneth Kirksey: So, and that got me thinking, too, if we start loading these, Student Forms is going to pick them up as well.Jennifer Buckles: Yes, unless the file is not in whatever folder it's looking for at the time it looks for it.Kenneth Kirksey: And so, what is Student Forms going to start showing them?Jennifer Buckles: Yeah, it won't show anything until you load the ISIR there.Kenneth Kirksey: Okay, and once they've loaded the ISIRs... it's going to show... comment codes?Jennifer Buckles: Well, the requirements attached to any comment codes, yeah. So when they log in, it'll automatically show them whatever they need to complete, whether it's verification or C-Flag or whatever.Kenneth Kirksey: And, but since we haven't... weren't running the tracking process, we're not going to have those in RawRec.Jennifer Buckles: Correct. But if the student goes into Student Forms, and you have Student Forms turned on to where they can go in and access their 26-27 ISIR there, you have logic APIs set up that will push that action tracking code back to Banner, if it doesn't already exist.But the thing with that is, they don't know to get in there—for new students anyway—unless you have the tracking code on Banner. Returning students would already have an account, and so they might get a reminder email or a notification email because they've already set up their phone number and email and attached themselves to an ISIR. But new students wouldn't have had the opportunity to do that yet. So, some students can get in there and get notifications early if you've got it turned on, and then new students wouldn't be able to unless you've got the tracking code in Banner.Kenneth Kirksey: Okay, yeah, and I think we have new students interacting with Slate, not self-service.Jennifer Buckles: But they still... does Slate show them their financial aid requirements from RawRec?Kenneth Kirksey: I don't think so.Jennifer Buckles: So they have to get into self-service at some point to do their financial aid requirements.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah. Which I think is... that's once they've been admitted.Kenneth Kirksey: What Allison just wants to stop is all the phone calls asking, "Have you received my FAFSA yet?"Jennifer Buckles: Yeah. I don't know that there's a good way to do that, because even if you make it visible, they're still going to call. They're still going to ask. You could push out an email notification to say, "Hey, we got it," but they're still going to call. They just don't read the notification. You're still going to have those that are extremely concerned and want to make sure it's there. But, I mean, you could make it as transparent as possible, and that might cut down on some of them.Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah. Okay.Kenneth Kirksey: All right, well, to the topic at hand. Jonathan, can you explain what you said in the meeting the other day about why we're locking the high school and GED updates?Jonathan Ibarra: Yes, so, one of the general eligibility criteria for students to be able to receive Title IV aid is they have to have a high school diploma or equivalency, like a GED. And on their FAFSA applications, there has to be a response that indicates that they do.But this was one of the issues that was, maybe in 24-25 when it all started, where students were reporting "none of the above." So, because of that, it puts them ineligible to receive Title IV aid, or even for us to disperse. So for those students that are indicating that, we're basically telling them that they need to make a correction. And a lot of times, they do have a high school diploma or GED, but for whatever reason, their answers are coming out as "none of the above."But for students that do make the correction, we do need to have that ISIR, just because in order for us to issue their Title IV aid, we need to have that on record. Otherwise, if we get an ISIR that does not have that, we're not able to process their loans, nor would we be able to issue their Pell Grants. And if we do, then we're out of compliance because we're not technically allowed to issue their aid if they don't have that answer questioned correctly.Jennifer Buckles: That makes sense why you would load them, but why are you locking them?Jonathan Ibarra: In terms of locking it, the reason why is because we need to have that when we send the files for loans. We need to have that as the ISIR that we're using, as well as for Pell. Otherwise, if we're not, we're still utilizing the ISIR from the prior one that is causing the whole issue, which is the ATB that comes into play.Jennifer Buckles: It doesn't need to be locked to be loaded. So, like, thinking of students not even packaged yet. Dawn's instructions were "lock them, no matter what. Packaged, not packaged, doesn't matter. Lock the ISIR." Why would you need that locked if they haven't even been packaged yet?Jonathan Ibarra: I'm going based on ones that have already been packaged, but we can't disperse their aid. Not the ones that haven't.Jennifer Buckles: Okay, I mean, because when she asked for clarification, like, "even if they haven't been packaged, you want them locked?" You said yes. So that's where the confusion's coming from.Jonathan Ibarra: Oh, okay. I... let me think. I think I said that just because even if they haven't been packaged, if we're getting an ISIR update just because the reason behind it is because they updated the high school, we would still want that. There shouldn't really be any change of their SAI whatsoever.Jennifer Buckles: Right. If they're not packaged, that update of their high school is automatically loaded. The only reason it's not loaded is if it's locked already. The only reason it's locked is if it's been packaged. So, if we're talking about people who have not been packaged yet, that means their ISIR's not locked. Any updates are going to automatically get loaded, so they're automatically made the current record.So there's no reason to go in and lock it if they haven't been packaged. That new transaction with the high school update automatically made the current... it's there. It's the current record. And then maybe they're still in verification or whatever. Once that gets completed, they get packaged, and then that gets locked. But by locking it prematurely, you're kind of making Dawn do more work to review locked records that she doesn't necessarily need to do.Jonathan Ibarra: Okay, I see what you mean. That's on my end, because I think my response was more so of, "we want to utilize that transaction," but not-realizing that some of those records that haven't been packaged have not been locked.Jennifer Buckles: Yeah. And then, if they have already been locked, and the ISIR comes in with a high school update, she would automatically be reviewing them in the SAI change process. So she's looking at all locked records that have a new update. She's looking at them regardless of the reason. She's looking at every single one of them and going through an SAI comparison. If there's no SAI change whatsoever, she's loading it. Just loading it, and locking that, because it was previously locked.So, she wouldn't necessarily need to go back through and then look for high school updates, because they would have already been loaded. The only ones that wouldn't be loaded is if they came in, they maybe changed their high school, and then changed something on their income, and that changed their SAI. And for those, you wouldn't want her to load them, because they need to do the FAFSA change first.Jonathan Ibarra: Absolutely. Yeah, so, like, in the past, we have had this issue where we had students asking us, "Hey, I submitted my correction, can you please process my award," and I can see that we have the ISIRs, but it's not being currently used. So that's where the conversation of, "if we do get an update ISIR and it does reflect high school, we definitely want to use it." But that was just more so because I didn't find them and knowing the ones that did do the correction.Jennifer Buckles: Because in the past, she wouldn't load them unless there was a reason to load them. Now, she's loading them unless there's a reason not to.Jonathan Ibarra: Correct, yeah.Jennifer Buckles: So, I don't think she needs to go through and specifically look for high school updates anymore, because they'll automatically get loaded. And if they don't, there's a reason, like an SAI change or there's something wrong with it.Jonathan Ibarra: That makes sense.Jennifer Buckles: So, I think, Dawn, you can take that review... just look at all your locked records like you normally do. Any GED or high school updates would be in that group, and as long as there's no SAI change, you're loading them automatically. And if they're not already locked, they automatically get loaded. So they're already automatically made the current record. So I don't think you need to go back behind them and lock them prematurely before they're packaged. That simplifies that locked records process that needs analysis a little bit, anyway.Kenneth Kirksey: We'll take any simplifications we can.Jennifer Buckles: But if you notice, like, after doing this, if you notice something's not getting loaded, revisit. Because you should not have records coming in with only high school and GED changes that are not loaded. If that's the only thing changing, whether they were locked prior or not locked prior, they should be loaded regardless. So you should not have an issue going forward, and Dawn won't have to do anything special to make sure they're loaded, because they'll just get loaded in the regular review that she does. But if something happens, and it's like, "Okay, this should have been loaded and it's not," let's go circle back and revisit, because that shouldn't be happening.Jonathan Ibarra: That makes sense.Kenneth Kirksey: And while we were on here... Dawn, I'd emailed Jen yesterday about those students with the verification requirement that weren't in a verified tracking group. And she reminded me, those are the ones that you've worked in suspense, and so they're not getting re-run through the tracking process.Jennifer Buckles: Yeah, it's the ones that she's working in the locked records. Because the suspense ones do get run through. Because it goes by the date the ISIR was loaded. And so when she works suspense today, she's actually loading those ISIRs today, the ones she's matching. So they have a date of today. Even though technically the ISIR was pulled in yesterday or last night, it didn't get actually loaded to an ID until today. And so those get stamped with today's date. Then tonight, when the ISIR load runs, it picks those up and runs them through the group. So suspense is fine.Jennifer Buckles: But it's the ones that she's doing on the needs analysis report. Those get loaded last night, but they aren't made the active ISIR, the current record, because they were previously locked. So when she's doing the review of the locked records, she's making ISIRs that were loaded yesterday current today, but they still have a load date of yesterday. And so they don't get picked up in tonight's process.So, Kenneth, I was going to ask you, do you want me to try to create a way to pick those up, kind of in a separate group and run them through as well, or include them in the overall group, to get their batch post done so we don't have to do that manually?Kenneth Kirksey: Yeah.Jennifer Buckles: I think we'd be able to identify them. If nothing else, we could just look for... well, I don't know. I have to think of how we might be able to pick those up. I was trying to think, maybe we could look for an ID other than Banworks that has made a change to it. Maybe that would pick this group up. But I might have to play around with that a little bit.Dawn: What happens if suspense doesn't get completed that day? Or say there's a duplicate PID that has to be resolved before you get it matched, and it's matched, say, a week from now? Or, you know, say the suspense didn't get done one day, and it's maybe Monday before it gets done. What happens to those?Jennifer Buckles: Yeah, the important part is that "data load part 3" that you do after you match it. So, once that data load part 3 runs, that's the date stamp that they get. So if that's not done... like if they, for some reason, they haven't applied yet... they don't apply for a month, and you're holding on to their ISIR for a month, or whatever, there's an issue and it sits in there. As long as it's sitting in there, it's fine. The date you run that data load 3 and actually load it, that's the date that the ISIR was loaded or created in Banner, and that's the date that all the processes—the grouping process and the pop-selects that run them through the batch post—that's the date it uses.Dawn: So, is there a problem if, for example, say I run the RCR to load everything, and then we do not process that night because we're stopping processes for Kathy? Is that a problem?Jennifer Buckles: Yeah. Then those people won't get run through grouping.Dawn: And then if I don't do it, then I have to redo the suspense all over again, because they'll just go back. So what do we do about that? Just don't do suspense on the days that we know that we're not processing for Kathy or something?Jennifer Buckles: Do you know that ahead of time?Dawn: We do.Jennifer Buckles: I think if you know it ahead of time, you could. I'd want to think through this a little bit, but I was thinking, what if you ran your match... you did all your matching up for whatever pieces you're doing, and you didn't load? You didn't run that data load 3. But we add a data load 3 to the beginning of the ISIR chain. So it would load any that you had previously matched before it runs the match again.So it would load anything that you had done. Then it would pull in the new file, run the match, load the new file. Then it would pick up everybody. So it would pick up anything that was in the match from when you did it—whether you matched them two days ago or today—because you didn't load them, they just sit there in the match until they're actually loaded or the match is run again.Dawn: Oh, I see what you're saying. I can run the match, but if I don't run the RCR for a couple of days, they still... they don't go back to...Jennifer Buckles: As long as the match isn't run again. So what I'm saying is...Dawn: Oh, run the RCR before you run the...Jennifer Buckles: Yeah, in the automatic process. Right now, you run... there's the RCP where you import the file, you run the match, then you run the RCR (RCRTP) to load them. If you left it like that, once you run that match, it's going to undo anything you had done and not loaded.But, if we do RCR first to load anything you previously matched, then pull in the new file, then re-run the match, then run the data load part 3 to actually load the new file, everybody in that group—including the ones you matched and the ones that the new process matched—they would all have today's date on them, and so they'd all get picked up.Kenneth Kirksey: What is the Data Load 3?Dawn: The RCRTP, is that what you're talking about?Kenneth Kirksey: Okay. So that runs as part of the chain. Are you running it again after you...Dawn: After I do the RCP match, I have to run the RCR to actually load them.Jennifer Buckles: Because if she doesn't, and we just let the chain run, when it hits that RCP match, it basically re-runs the match, and it undoes whatever manual matching she's done in suspense. It'll run them back through the rules and then put them back in suspense again. So, that's why you have to load that data load part 3 to actually say, "Okay, take this match and save it and load it into that student's record."So if you added that Part 3 first, that would save Dawn from having to run it at all. She could just do match, match, match, and then she'd be done. When the ISIR load chain runs that night, it runs Data Load Part 3 to load any from Dawn's match, then it runs the normal "load the ISIR file, run the match, run the load." And then everything from both of those loads would have today's date on them.Kenneth Kirksey: That makes sense.Jennifer Buckles: Yeah. And then it wouldn't matter if you had to skip a day, or if something happened and the process didn't run, you wouldn't lose all those records, whether she had loaded them or not.Kenneth Kirksey: Okay, well, you can add that to your work-on things.Jennifer Buckles: Okay.Kenneth Kirksey: All right. Did y'all have any other questions or anything?Jonathan Ibarra: Nope, but I do apologize for the confusion that I caused.Kenneth Kirksey: If we all knew what we were doing, this wouldn't be financial aid.Jennifer Buckles: I'll just clarify: Dawn, just keep doing what you're doing until we get the new process for the data load part updated, because I don't want to lose any of those records.Dawn: Okay.Kenneth Kirksey: Okay. All right. We'll see y'all later.Dawn: Thanks, guys.Jonathan Ibarra: Thanks.Kenneth Kirksey: Bye.
item.guid: Finacial Aid Tech Notes/2025-10-07 - Zoom - FAFSA Receipt, Locking GED and HS Updates - Transcript.md

item.title: 2025-10-07 - Zoom - FAFSA Receipt, Locking GED and HS Updates - Summary
item.description: Here is a professional summary of the meeting transcript. Kenneth Kirksey Jennifer Buckles Dawn Jonathan Ibarra Current methods for students to see their FAFSA receipt status and the limitations of the "invisible" aid year. The challenge of reducing student phone calls asking, "Have you received my FAFSA?" The relationship and timing dependencies between Banner (RawRec), Info Access, and Student Forms. Clarification of the process for loading and locking ISIRs with High School Diploma or GED updates. A procedural issue where manually updated locked records (from the needs analysis report) are skipped by the nightly tracking group process. A procedural issue with ISIR suspense processing, where manually matched records can be lost if a nightly process is skipped. (Kenneth, on behalf of Allison) How can students see that we have received their FAFSA? (Jennifer) They cannot see it while the aid year is invisible. Once the aid year is visible, it is tracked on RawRec. (Dawn) Where do we set up the estimated budgets for 26-27? (Kenneth) In an "RPB" form. He confirmed Leanne has not put them in yet. (Kenneth) If we turn on Info Access... is that going to show things we don't want them seeing? (Jennifer) It is unlikely, as packaging has not started. (Kenneth) What is Student Forms going to start showing them [once ISIRs are loaded]? (Jennifer) It will show the requirements attached to any comment codes, such as verification or C-Flags. (Kenneth) Jonathan, can you explain... why we're locking the high school and GED updates? (Jonathan) A high school diploma or equivalent is a Title IV eligibility requirement. If a student corrects their FAFSA, that corrected ISIR must be on record to process their loans and Pell Grants to remain in compliance. (Jennifer) That makes sense why you would load them, but why are you locking them? (Jonathan) His initial answer was based on already-packaged students, believing the ISIR needed to be locked to be the one used for disbursing aid. (Jennifer) Why would you need that locked if they haven't even been packaged yet? (Jonathan) He acknowledged this was a misunderstanding. He had not realized that non-packaged records are not locked and that their updates (like a high school correction) are loaded automatically. (Kenneth) Do you [Jennifer] want to... create a way to pick those [manually updated locked records] up... to get their batch post done? (Jennifer) Yes, she will work on a way to identify and include them in the process. (Dawn) What happens if suspense doesn't get completed that day? Or... say the suspense didn't get done one day... What happens to those? (Jennifer) As long as "Data Load Part 3" (RCRTP) has not been run, the records sit in the match. However, if the nightly chain runs its own match (RCP) before Dawn's records are loaded, her manual matching work will be undone and put back in suspense. (Dawn) So, is there a problem if... we do not process that night because we're stopping processes for Kathy? (Jennifer) Yes. The people from that day's load won't be run through the tracking group process. High School/GED ISIR Locking: The process will be simplified. Prematurely locking ISIRs for non-packaged students is unnecessary and will stop. The ISIR update will load automatically and become the current record. For packaged (locked) students, Dawn will no longer perform a separate review for high school/GED updates. These updates will be handled during her standard "locked records" (needs analysis) review. If there is no SAI change, the new ISIR will be loaded (and re-locked) as part of that existing process. ISIR Suspense Process: A new automated process was approved to handle manually matched suspense records. The "Data Load Part 3" (RCRTP) step will be added to the beginning of the nightly ISIR load chain. This will load all of Dawn's manually matched records (giving them the current date) before the chain pulls in and processes the new daily ISIR file. Task: Enter the 26-27 estimated budgets. [Owner: Dawn (working with Leanne), Deadline: Next week, when Leanne returns]. Task: Follow the new, simplified procedure for handling ISIRs with High School/GED updates (i.e., stop premature locking and handle updates during the normal locked-record review). [Owner: Dawn, Deadline: Ongoing]. Task: Investigate and create a method to automatically include manually updated locked records (from the needs analysis report) in the nightly tracking group process. [Owner: Jennifer, Deadline: TBD]. Task: Modify the automated nightly ISIR load chain to run the "Data Load Part 3" (RCRTP) step before the chain imports and matches the new file. [Owner: Jennifer, Deadline: TBD]. Task: Continue the current suspense process (manually running RCRTP after matching) until the automated ISIR chain is updated by Jennifer. [Owner: Dawn, Deadline: Until notified].
item.guid: Finacial Aid Tech Notes/2025-10-07 - Zoom - FAFSA Receipt, Locking GED and HS Updates - Summary.md

item.title: 2025-10-18 - How Handle ISIRs Loaded Next Day - Jenn
item.description: Reviewed how to handle ISIR’s loaded next day because transaction was lockedI could not determine a great way to pick these records up. My recommendation is that Dawn adds to her process to ROAIMMP the tracking group and add “ACTION” to RRAAREQ when the ISIR goes from “not selected for verification” to “selected for verification.” There is an existing report that will pick up anyone who is missed when the transaction is loaded.
item.guid: Finacial Aid Tech Notes/2025-10-18 - How Handle ISIRs Loaded Next Day - Jenn.md

item.title: 2025-10-07 - Military Tuition Discount
item.description: From: Alison Rabil To: Jennifer, me, Sheila, JonathanLooks like App is interested in implementing a tuition discount for all active military who would like to enroll in any of our programs at App. The max tuition rate is $250/credit, so the discount will affect out of state online and flight path students most (other military who are in state already get a special tuition rate, I believe).Question is, do we pull our budgets from the tuition amounts charged so that this may be a non-issue for us? If registrar codes the students as active military and student accounts picks them up and applies the discounted rate, can we pick up that rate for our CoA in our current process?Most of these students are using their military benefits to pay their costs, but presumably we'd still need to budget them and award any funding they might be eligible for, right?They want to put this in place for fall 2026 and they are going to put a working group together but wanted to see what questions this brings up in terms of our possible process changes.let me know what you think--and don't put a lot of brain energy into it--but off the top of your head what is this going to affect?Thanks! Looking forward to the day when we're just repeating what we did last year--but not yet!!From: Jennifer Buckles To: Alison, me, Sheila, JonathanYes, you pull in actual tuition for budgets. Before fees are assessed, you estimate full time tuition based on residency, level, and campus. So, it’s possible that your estimates would be inaccurate for these students but would be corrected when the actual fees are pulled into the budgets.From: Alison Rabil To: [All]Great. Thanks, Jenn. Unless anyone has an objection, I can live with it being inaccurate at the beginning estimate and corrected with the actual.From: Sheila Burleson To: Alison, Jennifer, me, Jonathanagreed.
item.guid: Finacial Aid Tech Notes/2025-10-07 - Military Tuition Discount.md

item.title: 2025-09-30 - Guidance on the Use of Federal Tax Information (FTI), Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA®) Data, and Non-FAFSA Data
item.description:
Publication Date September 30, 2025 DCL ID GEN-25-08 SubjectGuidance on the Use of Federal Tax Information (FTI), Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA®) Data, and Non-FAFSA DataSummaryThis letter provides information on the permitted access, disclosure, and use of FTI, FAFSA data, and non-FAFSA data by institutions of higher education (schools), state higher education agencies that administer state-based financial aid (state agencies), and contractors under the Higher Education Act (HEA), the Internal Revenue Code (IRC), the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA), and the Privacy Act of 1974 (Privacy Act).Dear Colleague:As explained in Electronic Announcement (EA) GENERAL-23-34, the HEA and IRC were amended by the Fostering Undergraduate Talent by Unlocking Resources for Education Act (FUTURE Act) and the Consolidated Appropriations Acts of 2021 (in the section called the FAFSA Simplification Act) and 2022. Among the requirements of these revisions is that FAFSA applicants and contributors (i.e., an applicant’s parent(s) or spouse, as relevant) approve the disclosure and use of data they enter on the FAFSA form as well as the FTI that is transferred from the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) for determining eligibility for federal student aid. This letter expands on the guidance in the above EA, and it replaces outright EA GENERAL-24-129, which explained the treatment of FAFSA and non-FAFSA data but not FTI. This Dear Colleague Letter (DCL) and the EAs cited herein comprise the U.S Department of Education’s (Department’s) current guidance on this topic.Other than statutory and regulatory requirements included in the document, the contents of this guidance do not have the force and effect of law and are not meant to bind the public. This document is intended only to provide clarity to the public regarding existing requirements under the law or agency policies.Types of InformationIt is important to understand the distinctions between the types of data mentioned above because there are different usage rules for each data type under the HEA, IRC, and FERPA. When determining whether a use or disclosure is allowable, the most restrictive statute applies.
FAFSA data is all information entered on the application or transferred from the previous year’s application. It also includes most data that the FAFSA Processing System (FPS) derives from the application, such as Federal Pell Grant eligibility and the Student Aid Index (SAI). In general, FAFSA data is what appears on the Institutional Student Information Record (ISIR) that is not FTI. For a full list of the ISIR information, see the ISIR Guide, which is Volume 6 of the FAFSA Specifications Guide. FTI is all the data received from the IRS via the FUTURE Act Direct Data Exchange (FA-DDX) as well as data that the FPS directly derives that could be used to reverse calculate FTI, such as the student or parent payroll tax allowance. These items are specifically listed in EA GENERAL-23-34; the FA-DDX items were included when the EA was originally published in 2023, and the directly derived data were added at the beginning of 2025. The EA also explains the protocol for handling FTI, which includes labeling it as “CUI//SP-TAX” (Controlled Unclassified Information/Specified Tax). The Department will label FTI fields on the ISIR, and FTI must also be labeled as CUI//SP-TAX by our partners; these labels must follow FTI wherever it is accessed, stored, or redisclosed with the written consent of the student as explained below. Note that not all tax data are FTI; manually entered tax data, such as those from a foreign tax return or from an IRS return that was not eligible for the data exchange, are considered FAFSA data. The FUTURE Act allowed the Department for the first time to maintain FTI in its systems; the FTI must be used and safeguarded according to the strict requirements of the IRC and the HEA. Prior to the 2024–2025 award year, when the FA-DDX was implemented, all tax data were considered FAFSA data, even when transferred by the now-retired IRS Data Retrieval Tool (IRS DRT), because it was either directly entered by the student or parent or, in the case of the DRT, they agreed to the transfer of the data from the IRS, which they then could view and edit. In the current environment, they are not able to view or edit data transferred via the FA-DDX. Non-FAFSA, institutional, or school data are the terms for information that is originated by schools or other entities. This includes total aid awarded, grant and loan receipt and amounts, and unmet financial need. While some of this information, such as Pell Grant receipt and amount, is reported to Department systems, such as the National Student Loan Data System (NSLDS®), it is not considered FAFSA data because it originates from schools rather than from the ISIR. By contrast, Pell Grant eligibility is considered FAFSA data since it is part of the ISIR and is derived from information entered on the FAFSA form. In this context, the IRC governs the use and access of FTI, while the HEA and the Privacy Act cover FAFSA data use as well as FTI.
The Privacy Act applies to federal agencies and governs information about individuals that is in a “record” contained in a “system of records” (see 5 U.S.C. §§ 552a(a)(1)–(7), (b), and (e)). Information that the Privacy Act protects cannot be disclosed by federal agencies without prior written consent unless one of the statutory exceptions applies. Under one exception, a federal agency may publish in the Federal Register a “routine use” for the information in a system of records notice (SORN) that outlines how the agency may disclose the information without prior written consent so long as the routine use is compatible with the purpose for which the agency collected the information. The Department’s routine uses for FAFSA data are outlined in the Aid Awareness and Application Processing (AAAP) (18-11-21) SORN, and the routine uses for FTI data are outlined in the FUTURE Act System (FAS) (18-11-23) SORN.FERPA and its implementing regulations protect the privacy of student education records at all educational institutions and agencies that receive funds under a Department program. This protection encompasses FTI and FAFSA data as well as an institution’s financial aid records on a student. FERPA is more broadly applicable, but generally less restrictive, than the HEA and IRC.The Department’s FERPA regulations (see 34 C.F.R. § 99.3) define education records, parent, and student, noting that the latter means anyone who is attending or has attended an educational agency or institution and for whom the agency or institution maintains education records. A person’s records at a school he or she has applied to but not attended are therefore not education records protected by FERPA. When a student reaches 18 years of age or attends a school at any age, he or she becomes an “eligible student,” and all rights accorded to, and consent required of, parents under FERPA transfer from the parent to the student. (34 C.F.R. §§ 99.3, 99.5(a)(1)).FTI and FAFSA Data Use Without Additional Student Consent
It is helpful to separate those activities that schools and state agencies are entitled to and expected to perform without additional consent from students (beyond the approval students provide when completing the FAFSA form) from those activities that require such consent. See EA GENERAL-24-149 for guidance about the form and collection methods of this additional consent. We also discuss it further below.Application, Award, and Administration of Aid: Schools and state agencies and their respective contractors may receive and use FTI and FAFSA data for the application, award, and administration of financial aid, consistent with the HEA, Privacy Act, and FERPA, and as outlined in their Student Aid Internet Gateway (SAIG) agreements. According to HEA section 483, state agencies are to use FTI and FAFSA data “solely for the application, award, and administration of state-based financial aid for which the applicant is eligible,” while schools are to use the same information “solely for the application, award, and administration of financial aid to the applicant.” The language in both cases is similar though more general for schools, which are responsible for creating and administering a student’s entire aid package, while the purview of state agencies is to focus on their own aid programs. The law also specifies research uses for FAFSA data, which will be explained further below. The Department interprets “the application, award, and administration of aid” to be the administrative and business functions necessary to deliver federal, state, and institutional financial aid efficiently and effectively to students. These functions may include but are not limited to: managing aid applications, eligibility, verification, and packaging and assisting students with those processes; processing and disbursing federal, state, or institutional financial aid; monitoring the academic progress of aid  recipients and enforcing other aid requirements (e.g., satisfactory academic progress  or SAP); complying with mandatory reporting for participation in aid programs, such as the Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System (IPEDS) reporting and net price calculator publishing under HEA sections 487 and 132 respectively; performing analyses necessary to the administration of financial aid programs by leveraging FTI and FAFSA data to estimate and model how financial aid will be allocated by the school or state agency; and conducting audits and program evaluations necessary for the efficient and effective administration of those student aid programs. The above duties are largely, but not entirely, school functions, and often the financial aid office performs them, but other personnel in offices or programs within a school who have duties related to the application, award, or administration of financial aid will be involved too. This includes, but is not limited to, those in the admissions and business (or bursar’s) offices, support programs, athletic and academic departments (e.g., awarding scholarships), and offices responsible for mandatory monitoring and reporting related to aid administration (e.g., SAP and IPEDS). Also included are contractors administering any aspect of a school’s or state agency’s aid-related activities; the contractors must assume all appropriate safeguards and responsibilities, including liability for any civil and criminal penalties under the HEA, IRC, and Privacy Act.In handling FTI and FAFSA data, the principle of “least privilege” should apply. Users should only have access to and make use of the data if it is necessary for them to perform their duties related to the application, award, and administration of aid or, for FAFSA data, applicable research. This will minimize potential security risks and breaches. The SAIG agreements schools and state agencies signed clarify who can access and use FAFSA data and FTI. The authorized personnel mentioned in state agency SAIG agreements and the administrators described in school SAIG agreements must be under the direct control of or bound by written agreement to the state agency or school. The SAIG agreements detail the responsibilities of authorized personnel and administrators and any penalties that might apply for failure to execute those responsibilities.Because of the special sensitivity of FTI and the penalties involved for even inadvertently mishandling the data, schools and state agencies should limit those accessing FTI to financial aid administrators (FAAs) as much as possible even though a variety of offices may have duties related to the application, award, and administration of aid. For example, a school’s financial aid office should use FTI to calculate eligibility for monetary scholarships that might be administered by other parts of the institution such as athletics or academic departments or an alumni association. Offices like institutional research that hold responsibility for required reporting such as IPEDS are permitted to access FTI, but the school must ensure they have taken all necessary steps to ensure the appropriate use of FTI, which also includes ensuring staff fully understand their responsibilities for protecting FTI. All individuals within a school or state agency who access FTI are required to take all applicable training.
In addition, the Department will ensure the security of FTI by holding schools and state agencies to the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) Special Publication 800.171, Rev. 3 (Protecting Controlled Unclassified Information in Nonfederal Systems and Organizations) CUI security standards, and they, in turn, will be required to ensure that any external entities that receive FTI from them are held to the same standards. This requirement may narrow the outside entities that are able to receive FTI because they may not meet the NIST standards and because the school or state agency may lack the oversight to ensure compliance. The Department will provide more information about this requirement in the future. As of the publication of this letter, there are not yet any compliance obligations regarding NIST SP 800.171.Research: Both state agencies and schools can use FAFSA data, but not FTI, to perform research without student consent as long as the research activities pertain to college attendance, persistence, and completion. The research cannot release any individually identifiable information about students. Contractors or third-party servicers that otherwise already have access to student FAFSA data due to their role in aid application, award, and administration may also perform this research under the direction of the school or state agency. This could involve, for example, a school using student-level FAFSA data to conduct a study about program completion of Pell-eligible students, as long as any results of the study that are released do not contain any identifiable information about the students involved.This function can also include the creation of de-identified, aggregate statistics (of FAFSA data but not FTI) that a school makes publicly available by posting them to its website or releasing them to another party for the purpose of college attendance, persistence, and completion, such as an organization that uses the statistics to provide the public more information about the schools that released them. Such statistics are a research product that is being used with the implicit purpose of encouraging attendance at the schools that publish them.FAFSA Completion Efforts: State agencies, in collaboration with local education agencies (LEAs) or secondary schools, may use only students' identifying information from the FAFSA form to check if a graduating student has submitted the application. Per the state agency SAIG agreement, identifying information means: the applicant’s first and last name, date of birth, and ZIP code; FAFSA submitted and processed dates; selected for verification flag; and a FAFSA completion flag as determined by the state agency (e.g., FAFSA not submitted, FAFSA complete, or FAFSA incomplete). The state agency should consult its SAIG agreement for more details on how to properly redisclose and use identifying information from the FAFSA form for this purpose. The LEA or secondary school must comply, as applicable, with FERPA requirements if it discloses any personally identifiable information (PII) from students’ education records to the state agency. There is no provision in the HEA for colleges performing this function.
Means-tested Benefits Outreach: As explained in EA GENERAL-24-93, state agencies and schools can use FAFSA data such as the Student Aid Index (SAI) and Pell Grant eligibility to determine which students they will contact about possible eligibility for means-tested benefits like the Child Tax Credit and Medicaid. They should minimize the FAFSA information and number of personnel needed for this function.Designated Scholarship Organizations: While this DCL is concerned with institutions of higher education and state agencies, it bears noting that HEA section 483(a)(2)(D) refers to scholarship organizations that are authorized to receive ISIR data, including FTI, directly from the Department due to a prior designation from the Secretary of Education. There are only two: the United Negro College Fund and Hispanic Scholarship Fund can receive ISIR data without additional prior written consent of the applicant. However, these entities are not permitted to further disclose FAFSA data or FTI for any other purpose beyond the application, award, and administration of their specific aid programs. They will also be required to adhere to the NIST SP 800.171 CUI security standards in their handling of FTI.FTI and FAFSA Data Use that Requires Student ConsentAs noted above, the consent process is described in EA GENERAL-24-149, and it applies to both schools and state agencies. However, there are some differences between what the obtaining of student consent allows the two kinds of organizations to do.Sharing Data for Assistance from Government Agencies and Other Entities: Under HEA section 483, state agencies, with student consent, may share FAFSA data (excluding FTI) with federal, state, local government agencies, or tribal organizations to help students receive assistance for any component of the cost of attendance (COA). That may include financial or non-monetary assistance, including means-tested benefits. A public college or university that qualifies as a government agency (i.e., its employees are government employees) may be eligible for this redisclosure by a state higher education agency. This would be helpful, for instance, for TRIO programs that are run by public institutions (not private nonprofit or for-profit schools) but that do not already have access to FAFSA data because they do not provide monetary support to students and therefore do not participate in the application, award, and administration of aid. Such TRIO programs could receive FAFSA data from the state agency with written consent.Under HEA section 494, schools that obtain student consent may share both FAFSA data and FTI with the same organizations as state agencies, to help students receive financial assistance (but not non-monetary assistance), including means-tested benefits, for any component of the COA. And unlike state agencies, schools may also share FAFSA data and FTI with external scholarship-granting organizations, including tribal organizations. This highlights schools’ wider purview in coordinating the entire financial aid package for students, including the scholarships provided by non-governmental organizations. However, as stated, schools will be required to ensure that any external entities that receive FTI are held to the NIST SP 800-171 CUI security standards.Any person or organization receiving such information from state agencies or schools may only use that information for the express purpose(s) intended by the students’ consent.School-only Provisions With Student Consent: There are a few actions that apply only to schools. Normally students who complete an application will receive a FAFSA Submission Summary (FSS, the document that replaced the Student Aid Report mentioned in the law) that lists the data they entered on the application but does not contain their FTI. Under the HEA, students who give consent can receive a complete, unredacted copy of their record that includes their FTI (likely a copy of their ISIR) from their school, and they are free to further disclose that document as they choose.Also, students who provide consent may have a discussion of their FAFSA data and FTI with their school that includes an advisor or other individual that they choose to participate in the discussion, which may be someone internal or external to the institution, such as TRIO or other program personnel.As noted above, a third-party servicer that has access to FAFSA data may perform research pertaining to college attendance, persistence, and completion on behalf of a school or state agency. Under HEA section 483(a)(3)(C)(iii), a school may, with student consent, share FAFSA data but not FTI with an external entity that is not a third-party servicer to perform that research.As with governmental agencies and scholarship organizations receiving information with student consent, the advisor and the external research entity mentioned above shall only use the information they receive for the purpose for which consent was granted by the student.A scholarship-granting organization, government or tribal agency, or the advisor mentioned above that receives information via a school that has obtained a student’s written consent cannot redisclose the information to any other person without the additional express written permission of, or request by, the student.FERPA and the Use of Non-FAFSA or Institutional DataAs explained above, information that is not created by the Department but that may reside in Department systems is considered non-FAFSA or school data and is not governed by the same HEA or IRC restrictions as FAFSA data and FTI. Because the HEA and IRC are more restrictive than FERPA regarding the use of FAFSA data and FTI, it was not necessary in that discussion to explain how that use satisfies the FERPA statutes and regulations. However, when determining the uses of institutional data, on which the IRC and HEA are silent, it is necessary to discuss the FERPA rules.
As outlined in the Department’s An Eligible Student Guide to the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA), a school may not disclose PII from eligible students’ education records without their prior written consent unless an exception to the consent requirement is met. The Department’s FERPA regulations (see 34 CFR 99.31) describe the exceptions to general consent, such as disclosures to school officials who the school has determined have legitimate educational interests in the education records; disclosures in connection with an eligible student’s application for, or receipt of, financial aid; and disclosures to organizations conducting certain types of studies for, or on behalf of, the school. Please note that this guidance does not provide comprehensive details of all the requirements necessary to implement a FERPA exception (e.g., both the studies and audit or evaluation exceptions under FERPA have requirements for what must be included in a written agreement). More information on these requirements can be found through the Department’s student privacy website. 
It may benefit schools to use institutional data instead of similar FAFSA data if they are able because that could offer more flexibility. Consider, for example, a school that wanted to have an outside researcher do work under the FERPA studies exception that examined Pell-eligible students. If the school sorted the students according to those to whom it disbursed Pell Grants rather than those whose ISIRs had a Pell eligibility flag of Y, it would not need student consent because the former is school data while the latter is FAFSA data from the ISIR. As noted above, the studies exception mandates the criteria that must be met, such as what the studies can cover and the details of the agreement between the school and the outside researcher. See §99.31(a)(6).Similar rationales about the flexibility available for the use of school data can be made for other FERPA exceptions, such as the school official exception. For example, while schools could use FAFSA data and FTI to administer a TRIO program like Student Support Services because it offers funds to students, which falls under the application, award, and administration of aid, FAFSA data and FTI cannot be used to determine eligibility for TRIO programs that do not offer aid. In those cases, it might be possible to use non-FAFSA data and the school official exception to determine student eligibility for non-monetary TRIO benefits, such as tutoring and counseling.
Correcting the FAFSA: Under FERPA, eligible students have the right to seek to amend inaccurate information in their education records. For FAFSA data, this is accomplished either by students or FAAs according to the guidance in Chapter 4 of the Application and Verification Guide, a volume of the FSA Handbook. However, while FTI is part of a student’s education record, because the Department received it directly from the IRS and shared it with schools, it is by definition accurate tax data, and there is no correcting it. Students who believe their SAI has been calculated incorrectly should contact their school financial aid office. If they are contesting the accuracy of their FTI, the school should refer them to the IRS. If they need to file an amended tax return, the school can refer them to a tax professional.In cases where students request and are granted a professional judgment (PJ) adjustment by their school because the FTI, which is from the prior-prior year, does not reflect their current financial situation, the action that the FAA takes suppresses the FTI in the ISIR and instead uses more current income information. In PJ situations, because the tax data is provided by the student (or parent or spouse), it is considered FAFSA data rather than FTI.Certain NSLDS Data Use Provisions Unchanged: It is important to note that neither the FUTURE Act nor the FAFSA Simplification Act amended some specific prohibitions in the HEA. Paragraph (d)(2) of Section 485B of the HEA still prohibits nongovernmental researchers and policy analysts from accessing PII from NSLDS, and paragraph (d)(5)(B) still prohibits the use of NSLDS data for marketing purposes.Student Consent
The guidance above refers to two consent processes: one for the disclosure of information under FERPA and one for HEA disclosures. The regulations explain the contents of student consent under FERPA in §99.30, and the HEA explains what student consent for FTI/FAFSA data sharing must contain in section 494(c)(4)(B). Institutions of higher education can use the same process to obtain written consent that adheres to the requirements of the HEA and FERPA from applicants who are eligible students under both statutes.Under the HEA, written consent requires a separate, written document (which may be in an electronic format) signed and dated by the applicant. The written consent must state the information being disclosed, and if that includes FTI it must specifically say so. The consent must also state the purpose for the disclosure and that the information may only be used for this purpose. Written consent is required to be maintained for a period of at least three years from the student’s last date of attendance at the institution and made available to the Department upon request.Written consent from an eligible student under FERPA must specify the records that may be disclosed, state the purpose of the disclosure, and identify the party or class of parties to whom the disclosure may be made. Upon students' request, the agency or institution shall provide them with a copy of the records disclosed. The signed and dated consent may be in an electronic form that identifies and authenticates the students as the source of the electronic consent and indicates their approval of the information contained in it.For More Information
The Department appreciates stakeholders’ cooperation and continued role in safeguarding the integrity of the Title IV programs and protecting the sensitive information, including FTI, provided by students and their families. If you need additional information or have specific questions, visit FSA’s Partner Connect Help Center and select the Topic “Policy Guidance” on the Contact Customer Support form. Further discussion of all the key terms, definitions, and systems related to the FAFSA Simplification and FUTURE acts is available in EA GENERAL-23-63.
For more information on FERPA, including what exceptions to the general consent requirement might be relevant, and other student privacy issues, visit studentprivacy.ed.gov. FERPA questions can be submitted at studentprivacy.ed.gov/contact.Dr. Christopher J. McCaghren Acting Assistant Secretary Office of Postsecondary Education

item.title: 2025-05-25 - Summer Grants EFT - State Grants EFT
item.description: Added job RZRNCEC - Summer to process flow Added prompts for Summer Term, Summer Start Date, Summer End date Jonathan put data file for state on FTP server - DISB-002906-03-YYYY-MM-DD-HH.MM.SS.GTF On running RZPNCUL 3 job aborted Message is: ABORT: File = DISB-002906-03-YYYY-MM-DD-HH.MM.SS.GTF. Line Number = 2. Invalid detail record enrollment period. it didn't recognize SUM as a valid aid period IN DISB-002906-03-YYYY-MM-DD-HH.MM.SS.GTF, changed SUM to WNTR RZPNCUL 3 aborted again. ORA-01400: cannot insert NULL into ("FAISMGR"."RZTNCEF"."RZTNCEF_TERM_CODE") I hadn't set the value for the winter term code prompt in any of the RZPNCUL jobs Set Winter Term to prompt #15 in all RZPNCUL jobs Success

item.title: 2025-05-21 - Meet with Jonathan - Incorrect Summer Award
item.description: Student 901006879 is enrolled for 4 & 6 hrs for summer 1 and summer 2 The state grant roster has the student at half time enrollment and current award = 1146 The current award was calculated on the student's previous enrollment for 7 hours in summer 1 So the rule is calculating their max award as 1146 / (7/12) = 3472, which is incorrect, because the student is now only enrolled in 4 hours for summer 1. The state grant roster doesn't provide the number of enrolled hours it used to calculate the current award So we have to send a new certification file with the updated enrollment hours to the state they have to process the file and we have to download the new roster data and import into banner Once that is done, the rzrncta_grant_amt will show the correct amount for the student's hours and the rule will calculate the award correctly Jonathan want's for us to run a new certification file daily until we lock hours at drop add This problem will go away when the state finally gets the state grant interfaced implemented, as it will handle these calculations.
item.guid: Finacial Aid Tech Notes/2025-05-21 - Meet with Jonathan - Incorrect Summer Award.md

item.title: 2025-09-15 - Meeting - Review Tranfer Monitoring Process

item.title: 2025-09-23 - ROASTAT - Expected Housing Status Lock not working properly
item.description: ISSUE: When the Lock indicator for the Expected Housing Status is checked on ROASTAT, the page still allows the Expected Housing Status to be updated even though the status is locked for the period.REPLICATION STEPS: Go to ROASTAT for 2627 Navigate to the Period Status tab Check the Expected Housing Status Lock for one of the periods and save Go to the Expected Housing Status for the same period and update the value and saveEXPECTED RESULT: The Expected Housing Status should not be updateable for the period since it is locked.ACTUAL RESULT: The Expected Housing Status is updateable for the period even though it is locked.WORKAROUND: NoneADDITIONAL INFORMATION: If the Expected Housing Status Lock is set for the period and the student is in a population where the Expected Housing Status is attempting to be posted, the RORBPST process does not update the status and properly gives the message that the Expected Housing Status is locked.https://elluciansupport.service-now.com/customer_center?id=standard_ticket_customer_center&table=ellucian_product_defect&sys_id=e4d00f71934c7a140ff9ff947aba10d6&view=sp

item.title: 2025-09-11 - Email - PKH Disbursements - Jenn & Sheila
item.description: Happy Tuesday!Can you take a look at this for me? I have a PKH student that is receiving a grant (VSAC). Trevor Ferrell 900855569. We add those grant awards with detail code 80162. Under the awards schedule in RPAAWRD, the award has three line items, FA/SP/SU. We need to disburse this award for FA/SP only. I can certainly change it manually, but wanted you to take a look.. is the student's budget group driving the disbursement schedule for all aid? Sorry if I am confusing - let me know your thoughts? Thanks!I’m adding Kenneth to this as well. Aid period determines the award schedule. RFRASCH is how you can set up fund code specific award schedules that are different from the default schedule for that aid period.Thanks - did not realize I left KK off!I did look at RFRASCH but did not see anything for this fund - that is why I am puzzled. Am I missing something?If you want to set up a schedule for that fund that is different than RFRDEFA, you have to set it up on RFRASCH. If there is not a fund specific schedule on RFRASCH, Banner will use the default schedule on RFRDEFA.So you’ll need to get the alternative schedule set up on RFRASCH and reschedule any awards that already exist. New awards will be split up according to RFRASCH once it is established.Got it - thanks!Sorry - last thing. I understand setting new disbursement schedules. But for this fund, we don't want anything alternative; just FA/SP 50% each. I guess my question is, why does this student have it on three disbursement schedules (FA/SP/SU) at all, if there is no alternative RFRASCH for this fund code? He is PKH, but????Because PKH RFRDEFA is set up for 3 disbursements. So it is an alternative schedule for PKH students since the normal PKH schedule is FA/SP/SU.AHH - forgot we set up RFRDEFA for PKH terms. So what is best for outside scholarships or grants, for PKHers; for us to manually adjust in RPAAWRD or use RFRASCH for PKH? I am thinking about Becky - our outside stuff is designed for FA/SP.. if we just assume summer enrollment for PKH for these funds, like we do for the fed, and set them up in RFRASCH and the student does not attend, they have lost out on funds that were initially designed to disburse in half, AND we would have to potentially return funds. My preference would be to change the disbursement to 50% FA/SP - what are your thoughts?I’d recommend setting up a FA/SP disbursement schedule for any fund code that you want to automatically schedule as 50/50. For outside scholarships, I know that’s a lot of fund codes so that may not be practical until we consolidate into the new Outside Scholarship fund codes.Thanks for the input. So far, that population does not receive the motherlode of outside aid, but it is something we should look into. The out-of-state grants, for example, can all be set up that way for sure!X Thanks again!
item.guid: Finacial Aid Tech Notes/2025-09-11 - Email - PKH Disbursements - Jenn & Sheila.md

item.title: 2025-07-19 - Students Missing Periods in ROASTAT period status - RZAFASH - Jenn Buckles
item.description: Staff are reporting students missing their periods on the period status tab of ROASTAT.  This is an issue that occurred last year and we weren’t sure if it was going to re-occur this year since the award year set up was completed before awarding began.  All the students with missing periods have scholarships added before the FAFSA was received.  I believe the custom job (RZAFASH) that is used to push the scholarships to RPAAWRD isn’t completing all the updates behind the tables to populate the periods on ROASTAT.  You could re-instate the Automic chain that fixes the periods as a temporary fix.  I believe that RZAFASH job is causing these issues if the student doesn’t already have a FAFSA at the time of posting.  I recommend discontinuing the custom job or continue running the fix to populate the missing periods.
item.guid: Finacial Aid Tech Notes/2025-07-19 - Students Missing Periods in ROASTAT period status - RZAFASH - Jenn Buckles.md

item.title: 2025-08-04 - Meeting - Loan Reallocations
item.description: Loan Reallocation Purpose We spend a lot of time reallocating funds for loans For any threshhold eligibility propose: $200 cap - don't adjust if their eligibility is lower Student has $200 more eligibility in subsidized loan that we gave them Don't reallocate to unsub unless they have >= $200 unsub eligibility unsub to sub We end up with a number of $1 refunds Takes time to manage them Mostly paper checks Most don't get cashed Reallocation is not a Federal Requirement, but it part of our policies Do process every semester, after drop add So we know how much unmet need they have Must be enrolled at least half time Students haven't used unsub, but have sub taken out We want to re allocate the sub loan to unsub Why we end up with $1 When original amount is odd amount Banner is calculating the origination fee $1 different between sub and unsub Happens when you're taking part of a loan and creating a whole new loan amount. How to mitigate If you're moving part of loan, don't create a new loan, instead add to existing loan It's a lot of work There's no easy answer How to make it easier Work the loans more frequently Start as soon as you adjust budgets for actuals We can start before disbursement Depends on population We wait until after drop add minimize dsbrevs all aid, scholarships added so we have correct unmet need How we do it now: Start when drop add ends Until spring registration starts Modify Brio Loan Reallocations Query 1 Add classification Pull only people without outstanding packaging rquirement Pull only people only enrolled hafl time or greater Remove graduate students Add Aggregate loan limits - RNASL Add Cost of Attendance Add Total Aid Received Query 2 RNASL - aggregate New report No unmet need Only Undergraduates And award equals cost of attendance And haven't maxed sub for grade level - aggregrate RNASL And haven't maxed sub for year - Annual In our heads We have to stop at 3 pm Send unsub loan file to COD Removing loans to create eligibility Wait for file back from COD Send sub loan file to COD Create reports this week
item.guid: Finacial Aid Tech Notes/2025-08-04 - Meeting - Loan Reallocations.md

item.title: 2025-08-05 - Create Pell LEU File to Send to State
item.description: Combine data from two files 2025-26 State Grant Roster Jonathan downloads this from state grant portal Pell Lifetime Eligibility Used Report LeeAnn downloads this from COD Create new file "Pell LEU GT 400 File Upload" in Excel File format: Copy the 'Current Social Security Number' and 'Lifetime Eligibility Used Columns' to the new spreadsheet Copy the SSNs from the 2025-26 State Grant Roster list and pasted them beneath the ssns in column A of the new spreadsheet. Select Column a in the new spreadsheet, then select Conditional Formatting -> Highlight Cells Rules -> Duplicate Values Filter Column a by Cell Color -> No fill Delete all the found rows. This leaves only the students in the Pell Lifetime Eligibility Used report that are also in the 2025-26 state grant roster. Fill ACYR column in new spreadsheet with 2026 Fill SCH Code column with 002906 Fill SCH branch column with 00. Make sure the column format is Text so that it will show both zeroes. Send file to Jonathan via file share.

item.title: 2025-08-08 - State Grants not disbursing - RZPNCUL fails
item.description: Work on state grants disbursement - we disburse on Sunday Aug 10 The problem: From yesterday - we can't import DISB file via RZPNCUL We currently have a disbursement rule set for 80039 RZRNCEF_PIDM = PIDM AND RZRNCEF_TERM_CODE = TERM AND RZRNCEF_GRANT_TYPE = 'UNC' This rule ensures we only disburse to students for which we have received payment from the state. RZRNCEF is populated by loading the DISB file via RZPNCUL And since we can't load the DISB file, we won't be able to disburse NC Next awards with the disbursement rule in place. Wes informed me that we're the only school that uses the DISB file. I sent an email to the FA Banner Leads list asking how other institutions prevent disbursing funds for which they have not received payment from the state. Solution - proposed by Jonathan Run cert daily
item.guid: Finacial Aid Tech Notes/2025-08-08 - State Grants not disbursing - RZPNCUL fails.md

item.title: 2025-09-09 - FAQ 1-3KZ156 - GLRLETR log file has error "$LOG ambiguous redirect" when run from Applications Manager 1
item.description: This article is for clients using the older scripted Banner Integration AW_BANNER.  It does NOT apply to the Banner Agent Running GLRLETR from Appworx can give this error: * BANNERLOG STARTS HERE **** /u01/ban7/links/glrletr.shl: line 31: $LOG: ambiguous redirect /u01/ban7/links/glrletr.shl: line 42: $LOG: ambiguous redirect This can happen if the GLRLETR module is defined with BANNERSHL as the Program Type. With this program type, the environment variable $LOG is not being set . Workaround is to change the program type to BANNERSH: Verify that Program Type BANNERSH exists (if BANNERSH exists, skip to Step 2).  If it doesn't, then create it: a. Go to Object Admin/Development/Program Types b. Highlight the existing BANNERSHL, then choose Copy. c. Change the Name field from "BANNERSHL" to "BANNERSH". Don't change any other values. Click OK. Edit the GLRLETR module - On the General tab, change the program type from BANNERSHL to BANNERSH Test GLRLETR By changing the program type, it will go through a different part of the AW_BANNER script which will define the $LOG value and the job should run. Related FAQ: 1-4Z54CG: AppWorx - GLRLETR.lis file is going to the $AW_HOME/out directory instead of the job submission directory
item.guid: Finacial Aid Tech Notes/2025-09-09 - FAQ 1-3KZ156 - GLRLETR log file has error "$LOG ambiguous redirect" when run from Applications Manager 1.md
